text: For more than an hour, the candidates for the Democratic nomination in 2020 gathered at Los Angeles’ Staples Center to take part in the second presidential debate on Oct. 15. Democratic voters are likely to cast their ballot before then but, before then, have plenty of other things to consider.Here’s a look at some of the things that will come up during the debate and the things they have said about race relations, the climate and the economy, and everything in between.The first presidential debate, in June, was dominated by issues like sexual misconduct, racial injustice and white privilege.But in the last debate, the stage was expanded to include three more African American candidates: former Vice President Joe Biden; Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.); and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.).That means that the first six of the first 14 candidates qualified for the second debate. With that amount of candidates, there will be plenty of hot topics.Here is a roundup of the most notable quotes from both the Democratic candidates and the moderator from the debate:Democratic presidential candidate Beto O’Rourke speaks onstage at a debate hosted by PBS on Oct. 15, 2019, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)The environmentHarris is the only female candidate who has been to the summit of Mount Everest, but she’s only addressed climate change in one of her campaigns: during her 2018 Senate campaign in California, she called climate change “the most important issue” facing the country and called for a Green New Deal to address its impact on communities such as the Navajo Nation in Arizona.“But just think of all the people who are going to suffer, who are going to die, who are going to be pushed into living in the streets,” Harris said last week. “What are we going to do about this?”The answer isn’t necessarily to ban fracking, but to pass laws in every state that require it to be a necessary part of the process, she said. She also said she’d support a ban on the use of the pesticide neonicotinoid.Climate change and energyThis isn’t a debate the Democratic nominee should lose, because it is the central theme of the next four years.

Afghan President Hamid Karzai’s re-election bid lacks legitimacy, the head of the country’s interim government has said.In a speech Friday, Abdullah Abdullah, chairman of the country’s High Council for National Reconciliation, told a gathering in Jalalabad that only legitimate elected officials can run for president, but that in this year’s race Karzai “is disqualified.”“Karzai is not valid. He has no legitimacy,” Abdullah said, according to AFP, which was traveling with him on his way to the Afghan presidential palace.He reiterated his contention that Karzai was a puppet master to Ashraf Ghani, the incumbent, and that he was only seeking his re-election to continue being “Afghanistan’s poodle.”Abdullah said Ghani would have been better off for now by accepting a cease-fire between the Taliban and government forces, and then running a transparent election. “If a legitimate president wants to run, then the people should choose him. If the election is a fraud, then the people should punish those who committed the fraud,” he said.Abdullah’s statement contradicted what Ghani said about his former chief of staff on Sunday, who was being held for alleged embezzlement. Ghani said that his former chief of staff had fled the country and was still at large. But it also contradicted what his deputy, Abdul Raouf, who was seen driving the fugitive’s car, had said in his own interview with Radio Free Afghanistan.When Raouf, a longtime Ghani ally, asked about the whereabouts of Khalil Alikhil, the former deputy governor of the eastern province of Ghazni, he said it was “still not safe.”“There are still two or three people around the former governor, but they were captured during the battle and there is no security around them,” Raouf told Radio Free Afghanistan. He said the Afghan government was “not able to find anything” about Khalil Alikhil.Karzai said he would continue to insist that Ghani recognize the authority of the government and the High Council for National Reconciliation.“

The French far right has uncovered some potentially damning information on their Russian financiers. The revelations are the result of a recent investigation conducted by the leader of the National Front, Marine Le Pen, as well as her party’s chief spokesman.The alleged ruse was to expose a shadowy network of financiers from the so-called “Calais camp” in France.

Photo: The U.S. Government.The U.S. State Department has released a new video on the "role of natural hair" in the U.S. "We should celebrate our natural hair and embrace our natural beauty," states a voiceover at the top of the new "Natural Hair USA" commercial.Natural hair is the same thing as hair that's pulled out with pliers, or is combed through. Many African Americans believe that natural hair is more natural, therefore more beautiful. For African Americans, natural hair has been a major sign of self-determination and self-respect.The video, created by the State Department's African American Affairs Division and directed by the National Museum of African American History and Culture, begins with the question: "What does African American hair mean to you?" and goes on to explain various aspects of African American hair, such as African American braids, afros, and natural hairstyles.The new commercial also features various African American celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow, who recently made a documentary called "Lupus" about natural hair.Gwyneth Paltrow was quoted in the commercial as saying, "Black Americans have such a proud history of natural hair and we need to continue to celebrate that."Paltrow said that Afro-dancers and afro-singers use "natural hairstyles that we wear ourselves."The video also mentions the Afro-dance group Black Image, which was founded by a number of African-American musicians like Erykah Badu.Badu told the State Department's African American Affairs Division that African-American Afro-dance has "the energy, the strength, the power, and the authenticity that Afro-dance has. It's one of the fastest growing forms of the movement."Black Image is "one of the major forces pushing for change, from the grassroots to government officials, with a particular focus on social justice issues like police brutality, civil and human rights, and justice for the elderly."

- WRCBtv.com | Chattanooga News, Weather & SportsPHILADELPHIA (AP) - Attorney General William Barr will appear before the Senate judiciary committee for a hearing on the special counsel's Russia report.Barr told lawmakers at a private dinner on Tuesday that he would provide the panel with the unredacted version of special counsel Robert Mueller's report.Barr had promised the committee he would not redact the document and that it would be made public on Thursday.Mueller is a Republican and he did not issue a report in March on whether the Trump campaign conspired with Russia to tilt the 2016 election in Trump's favor. He was appointed by former Republican President George W. Bush.Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.Related VideoSIGN UP FOR OUR NEWSLETTER: Email | Connect with #WDTV on Twitter!

KANO, Nigeria—At least 22 people were killed Friday by a suicide bombing in northern Nigeria at a mosque, police said, the first such attack in the country.A suicide bomber struck inside the mosque, in the city of Madagali in Kano, the police said.

Five British men have been sentenced to life in prison by a judge in the Middle Eastern kingdom of Jordan for a plan to blow up a crowded market area, officials said.The five were sentenced late Friday by a military court in the southern city of Nassib on charges of attempting to kill security and civilian targets, according to a judicial source.The five men, including a 23-year-old who was in a wheelchair, were found guilty of trying to kill police officials and soldiers in a thwarted terrorist act, said a judicial source.They were part of an 11-man group, including a 19-year-old arrested at the scene, that was planning to blow up a busy market area to attack security personnel and military targets in the southern port city of Eilat, said a judicial source.A spokesman for Britain’s Foreign and Commonwealth Office said he had no information about the men.The five suspects, one British national and four Jordanians, were found guilty of attempting to kill security and civilian targets in the city of Nassib, the judicial source said.The suspects were found guilty of several charges, including attempting to kill security and civilian targets, as well as incitement and the recruitment of minors, the judicial source added.The five men, arrested in different parts of the kingdom on March 24, had denied involvement and said they were innocent.A similar attack in the northern city of Ma'ale Adumim was foiled by security forces.A court hearing in October found six men guilty of attempting to kill security targets and setting off a car bomb in the southern town of Sidon, which has been hit by three major attacks in the past year.Jordan, which is a close military ally of the West, faces a wave of attacks in recent years blamed on militants linked to the Islamic State group.In the latest incident, gunmen killed two policemen in the town of Qatif, which is in the south.

By Michael S. HendersonThis past July, The Compilation CD, "Best Of" Lucky Dube, a tribute to the late Lucky Dube (1919-2009), was released through a fan-supported company's website. The album, featuring nearly 300 of Lucky's greatest hits, has been well-received by listeners since it was first released on June 2, 2008, and now, as of this writing, is available as a download."This is the best compilation I've ever done," explained Lucky's son, Daryll, in an exclusive interview with Vibes. "I think the fan community is going to really enjoy it. It's going to bring them Lucky's best songs, and it's going to give them a real appreciation of what he gave them.""I really like the fact that he's on the CD," Daryll continued. "The fans are going to get to hear some of the lesser known Lucky Dube songs that they might not normally hear. I think they're going to love it."When I asked Daryll if he had any concerns about his son's career choice, he answered with a resounding, "Not at all." Daryll explains, "It's the best thing for me and the best thing for the music. I think that in any sort of career you choose, you need to have a little of each so you're not getting stale. He's got a lot of good songs on there."Daryll added that Lucky's songs have been selected in such a way to be easily heard. "The best part is that the songs are going to be available to them at their fingertips, because there is no CD being made. This one is going to take care of that problem."Daryll explained that Lucky's songs have been carefully chosen for their relevance to the musical world. "You're going to be able to recognize some of them, or you're not, and you're also going to hear some new songs. Some of the music is going to be a little old, some of the songs will be a little new. It's going to be good to have another album by him."For Daryll, Lucky is a "legend" who will continue to live on in the hearts of fans. "He's been the greatest songwriter of his generation," he explained.

Three Southern California Catholic dioceses say they have been targeted by a lawsuit alleging that they covered up the widespread sexual abuse of minors by priests in their churches, an allegation the dioceses deny.In a statement Tuesday, the dioceses of San Bernardino, Santa Barbara and Orange said they have done what they can to help victims of abuse by clergy, and that they continue to cooperate with law enforcement, as well as the investigation of clergy accused of abusing children.But the lawsuit filed Tuesday by two victims' rights attorneys contends that a series of bishops in Southern California covered up widespread abuse by priests and then concealed their cover-up by hiding documents, making it impossible for victims to report abuses or to seek justice. The lawsuit filed in Orange County alleges that more than 300 children in the Los Angeles Archdiocese may have been abused at the hands of Catholic priests over an 80-year span beginning in 1949.The lawsuit alleges that the dioceses, particularly in Southern California, covered up abusive priests by failing to keep accurate records of allegations of abuse and hiding documents about how the dioceses handled allegations. The plaintiffs allege that the dioceses allowed abusive priests to continue working within parishes and that they were also unwilling to deal with the victims and report cases of abuse.The allegations include that some dioceses allowed the abusive priests to continue working while they continued to be members of the community and kept church documents about allegations of abuse and attempts to cover up accusations from church officials.The lawsuits contend that the dioceses failed to investigate or protect the children who had been abused or did nothing about the records of abuse by abusing priests that they had already kept."These children have suffered the most grievous of injuries," according to the lawsuit, filed by two law firms, the National Child & Family Coalition in Sacramento and the Law Center for Children & Families in Los Angeles.The case seeks to force the Diocese of Orange to make public all records relating to claims of abuse against priests and to pay damages to all victims.The Orange Diocese denied the allegations in a statement Tuesday."While the Orange Diocese cannot, and will not, comment on the specific details of each case regarding which our priests are alleged to have abused children, we welcome the opportunity to examine the accusations," said Bishop John F. Vincenzo of Orange.Bishop Victor J.

KABUL, Afghanistan—Afghanistan is trying to eliminate private security companies, officials and officials said Tuesday.Officials said that in a meeting held in Kabul on Tuesday the government issued a decree abolishing a company that had been providing security and protection to high-ranking government officials.Afghanistan has a law that bans any private security company from providing security to the government.The meeting came after an increase in attacks and a deadly siege by suspected Taliban militants against the Interior Ministry.Afghan President Hamid Karzai and other high-ranking officials also attended the meeting. They gave instructions to improve security in various parts of Kabul.Kabul has been hit hard by an increase in violence in recent weeks, in which a car bomb near the Ministry of Interior has killed at least five people.The Taliban in January took over the Afghan presidential palace, which was previously held by Karzai's rival.According to reports, the Taliban released a video on Monday that showed them taking a group of children and their parents hostage, saying they would demand a release of prisoners they had held in recent attacks.The release of the hostages would be part of the process of Afghan leaders making peace, according to a group called the Peace Council.

An American man allegedly wrote a fake bomb threat against the U.S. Embassy in Berlin, Germany, which he later sent to the FBI in Washington, D.C.The suspect, a 20-year-old German national named Daniel Fuhrman, was arrested by officers of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in the German capital on Friday, the agency said.Authorities say he gave the alleged bomb threat to the German Embassy, writing "a letter, attached to an envelope and addressed to the embassy staff, threatening to cause serious damage to the U.S.

By KELLY LUNAKTroy High School’s dance program is a safe place for its dance students in a tough neighborhood in Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood where an estimated one in four youths are victims of violence or other kinds of serious crime.In recent years, Troy High School’s dance program has been transformed by two young choreographers, Jennifer Brown and Erin Noyes, whose passion and experience in dance programming has created a safe place for students to learn and to learn to perform the most challenging styles of modern and classical dance, including dance that uses only body language, movement, and dance elements such as musical and visual expression.“

Sen. John McCain has a reputation for being an old, hardy fighter. But on the eve of his 83rd birthday, the Arizona Republican is still willing to spend his days on the floor of the Senate debating health care.Even though he's admitted to battling a rare form of cancer that's affecting his brain and lungs, McCain has kept fighting for the Senate's bill that would allow Americans to keep their current insurance plans even if they lose their jobs."I'd be lying to you if I said there hasn't been a debate or discussion about this bill," said Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, who is helping to draft the legislation."The key points in all these conversations has been to make sure that people can keep their health care plan," Lee told reporters on the sidelines of a bill-writing forum on Monday. "It's a question of whether we have the ability to find a common ground that can move through this Congress. We just hope that as many Republicans and as many Democrats as possible can come to the table and support this bill."The legislation has a good chance of getting the 60 votes needed to pass the Senate. It was narrowly approved for consideration last week in the House, but it's uncertain how strong the support will be in the Senate.McCain's fellow Arizona Republican, Sen. Jeff Flake, said he is committed to working with his colleague, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, to try and pass the legislation."I believe strongly in this, and I know that Orrin Hatch will work with me on it, to get this bill across the finish line," Flake told a gathering at the John McCain Presidential Library on Monday. "It's hard. You have to convince a lot of people. But I am convinced that it needs to happen."The legislation still faces a tough hurdle. Some senators have already said they will filibuster the measure once it reaches the Senate floor, and other moderate Republicans are worried about the bill's tax-hike elements.Still, McCain remains a stalwart, and on Monday, Hatch said it's still possible the legislation will be approved."I don't think it's all that difficult to pass this bill if you have a really good bill written to make sure people can keep their current plans," said Hatch, the No. 2 Republican in the chamber.

On October 9, 2001, President Bush declared a national emergency in response to the anthrax attacks. The president stated that he was concerned about the threat of biological weapons. The government set up a national bioterrorism advisory committee to review whether the government should adopt any emergency measures in response to the danger from biological agents. The committee reviewed the various issues that are associated with responding to the bioterrorist threat. The committee's report, entitled "Bioterrorism Advisory Committee Recommendations," can be accessed at the following link http://www.epa.gov/bio/bio-response.htm. The committee recommended a broad program of research, with a focus on improving technologies used to detect and destroy bioweapons, and ways to secure the nation's infrastructure.President Bush also established the National Biohazard Management Council, a group made up of members from various federal agencies to advise on possible national and international biological hazards. The council's recommendations were accepted by the federal government, and a program was instituted to provide training on biohazard preparedness to federal employees and civilian contractors.The National Biohazard Management Council will continue to be concerned with the need to develop bioterrorism response capabilities and will continue to consult with state and local biodefense programs for assistance.

Beijing is looking to put an end to a long list of state-owned firms across China implicated in corruption scandals.The State Council on Friday issued new regulations to inspect the assets of major state enterprises in a move aimed at rooting out corruption.The State Council said it would strengthen its coordination with the country's Central Military Government to prevent the theft of state assets by the armed forces and law enforcement agencies.The regulations also require state-owned enterprises to establish a special department and promote new technologies to reduce losses of state-owned enterprises through mergers and acquisitions.Some recent incidents, such as the one involving the Guosheng Group, have caused controversy about the extent to which the national security apparatus can spy on Chinese citizens and businesses for use in anti-corruption efforts.Authorities said Guosheng is one of the Guosheng Group companies, along with the Dalian Xingdao Group and Jiangsu Tianyong Group, that had provided equipment to the North Korean nuclear program in 2014-2015.

, and Offer Gift of Ties for DonorsIn a new partnership with a local bank, the French capital’s Basilica of Saint-Laurent will be among the first in France to take contactless payments using mobile phones, in a bid to attract donations.A series of small plastic objects dubbed ‘tickets’, are being installed around the Basilica. They will have to be used once to register, and be given to any person who wants to take them, according to the site, in exchange for money.The basilica’s website said: “The first payment is given to the individual who takes the ticket and gives it to the first person to come and take it. A further payment is made at a later time when the same ticket is taken by another person.”The bank is offering a series of tie designs that can be given to the donors to mark their support.The website explained: “The Basilica is seeking donations, either in the form of cash, goods, or services. It is not expected to be able to collect money for the projects.”Basilica officials said that donations would also be accepted at the door of the basilica, and that all donations would be used for the various parish projects.According to the basilica, the idea is that the new cards will be used as a “paperless” channel, allowing donors to easily transfer funds from their bank accounts to the church’s coffers.The basilica will take the cards from their respective banks.The cards will have a QR code and a unique identification number which will be sent to the bank.

A collection of a century's worth of possessions belonging to India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, will be auctioned off.India's Nehru House will be sold off on August 8th as the last remaining piece of a collection of property that includes the personal effects belonging to India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru.Sellers had earlier set an asking price of $8 million (about Rs 64 crore) for the house, and India's Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) agreed to that amount.The final price will likely be somewhere in the ballpark of $1.8 million, experts said.The items will be sold separately as three lots, and one lot will go for $8 million (about Rs. 64 crore) and another set will go for $1.8 million (about Rs. 64 crore) and the third set of items will go for $1 million.The items to be auctioned are the personal belongings of India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, with a few gifts from his wife Indira Gandhi also included in the lot.The Nehru House is located in New Delhi and is known for being a "socially, politically and economically vibrant house".Last year, the house was demolished to make way for a metro station in the Delhi Metro zone. The auction of items is said to be a prelude to a museum at the house.Some of the items that will be auctioned are Nehru's diaries and a portrait of his wife and former prime minister Indira Gandhi which were bequeathed to the Nehru House by the then British government of India, a statement from the auction house said."The Nehru House is not the only house in New Delhi. It is also the only house with a museum attached to it and an air-conditioned museum," the statement read.According to a 2015 report in a publication in India, the Nehru House was "already in the doldrums, with most of its original furnishings now in a ruinous state".

byThe Exaggerator took another step forward.The 5-year-old gelding claimed his second Preakness Stakes title, and fifth in the series.The victory gives him 15 wins in a career that began in 2014.The win gives the horse a 9-5 advantage in the series and a 13-10 advantage in the overall stakes.This is the first time that the horse, ridden by David Miller, has won the Preakness Stakes. Miller became the first rider to win the Preakness Stakes with a riding partner and riding a horse.The victory, which also won the Kentucky Derby, is his third Derby in a row.

, And Economic GrowthFormer President Hugo Chavez held a weekly Facebook Live with his supporters to discuss various political and economic issues. The last discussion of his term was about the impact of Venezuela's economic policies.Venezuela is in the middle of a political and economic crisis. Many people worry that its economy will collapse. This is a difficult time to talk about Venezuela, says Chavez, because there are so many issues to discuss. "In the U.S. we talk about term limits," he says, but that's not the case in Venezuela. We know that term limits are not going to happen in the U.S., but in countries like India, Brazil, or Venezuela they will.There's a very wide difference between a country like the U.S. and Venezuela, but that doesn't mean that they have the same economic policies.

After Nearly 10 Years Without A Form of GovernmentMozambique’s president, Filipe Nyusi, who has already been in office for nearly 10 years, said he wanted a new government before November, to help fight the jihadist attacks that have rocked the north since 2011.As Mozambique continues to battle the attacks of ISIS-supported groups, it must prepare for elections in 2018, and is not only going to win the battle, but will also use the new elections to set up new governing institutions and develop political and governance structures.Mozambique has long been ruled under a hybrid form of government, alternating between multiparty and single-party systems. The elections have been regularly delayed, and have been postponed three times since the beginning of the jihadist attacks of 2011 in the south.Mozambique is in a state of turmoil, with more than 1,000 dead, hundreds of thousands displaced, and an uncertain future for the country.

, Urges for Immediate, Rapid Access to Safe Water and SanitationNew York, DC - World Food Programme (WFP) Secretary-General William T. Hurd on Monday called for a humanitarian intervention in the Central African Republic (CAR) to protect the population from the ravages of violence and restore services to communities and communities affected by conflict and insecurity."The destruction of lives and livelihoods is a human rights violation," he said in a statement.More than 4 million people face severe acute malnutrition - the most serious form of malnutrition. More than 800,000 people need urgent humanitarian assistance to recover.With the threat of armed conflict and disease looming, WFP is focusing on providing food security, water and sanitation, hygiene and nutrition, health, protection, social cohesion and economic recovery."These are key to ending the violence, restoring health, social cohesion and economic recovery and preventing further human rights violations," he said."The needs of the most vulnerable are being ignored while the worst impacts of the violence are being felt by the least powerful people. And the consequences of this are unfolding now," he said."The international community cannot tolerate this human rights abuse and must do everything in its power to stop it and to end the suffering of so many people," he said.The Secretary-General said the crisis must not be allowed to continue and it is essential for the United Nations, its international partners, donors and people of good will to come to the aid of millions of people in need.He said he would not rest until those that need assistance most were cared for - and the suffering of so many people is halted and their suffering and their suffering is finally ended.Ahead of the official launch of the United Nations Humanitarian Response for the Central African Republic on Tuesday, William T. Hurd said that over the last three years, he has seen the suffering of millions of people, particularly women and children in CAR."This is a humanitarian crisis, one I fear could spiral out of control. It is one that requires a coordinated and ambitious international response," he said.He stressed that the Central African Republic is a "front-line state" facing violence, insecurity, hunger and conflict.The Secretary-General said that the "only possible solution" to this humanitarian crisis is through an inclusive, peaceful democratic process to elect a representative government that would be held accountable by the international community."

HAVANA — Cuba's President Miguel Díaz-Canel has publicly announced his support for same-sex marriage, a development that has not been seen in recent years in the country.The first Cuban president to endorse such an issue was Miguel Antonio Díaz y Luna, who during his presidency supported the same-sex unions. Díaz y Luna was the grandson of Fidel Castro, the former leader of the Revolution, and a figure in the Cuban Communist Party.After a long period of silence, Díaz-Canel released an official declaration regarding the issue.

in Israel PrisonThe former prime minister was freed for his second trial in Israel's most senior court but still faces up to six months in jail.On Wednesday morning, the Israeli Supreme Court ordered a retrial for Ehud Olmert on charges of bribery, breach of trust and embezzlement, as well as the possibility of more jail time.While on the first trial the judge did not hand down any jail time, Olmert was convicted in 2009 of embezzlement and breach of trust.However, on Wednesday he was found guilty of bribery as well as of corruption charges in another trial. He was also found guilty of using his position for a private benefit – namely giving a tip to an investigator.Olmert's lawyer said it was another "victory" for Olmert. "We will appeal this," the lawyer added.'We'll appeal this. We'll try to bring in another aspect of the case that is relevant."Olmert said he was "proud" at the verdict, adding that he remained steadfast in his conviction and conviction.He also denied to using the trial to get his own way, saying that he was a "very strong" politician and "didn't care what happened".

Islamabad [Pakistan], February 25 (ANI): At least 21 people have been killed in a suspected US drone strike in Pakistan's tribal region bordering Afghanistan, sources said on Wednesday.A senior official said that the "target" is "unknown" and the target location is a "major town" and that there are "no civilian casualties".There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.The latest strikes comes just days before US President Joe Biden delivers his State of the Union address on February 25.Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan is scheduled to meet with his counterparts in Paris, France, on February 26 for the second round of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit. The leaders of the 20-member APEC will also meet to review global economic cooperation projects and plan for the future.

(AFRICAN EXAMINER) – A Nigerian family has spoken out after saying they believe a secret recording of their missing daughter is a last surviving image of Dapchi girls.In an audio of the last family’s conversation with another family member, the family claimed they believed Dapchi girls’ secret recording is evidence of the Dapchi tragedy.Dapchi girls were abducted by suspected Boko Haram Islamists on January 16. They were reportedly released several days later in February.The family member who was contacted by the family said the family believed the girl has been sent to another country.“I was not able to get through to her on WhatsApp, but my brother told me that she said someone was trying to tell her the person that is keeping her is telling her to not do a certain thing,” he said.He said: “She was telling me the person telling her this is going to get her killed, and that she should call the police.”He said the girl was asked to call the girl that her husband is in the army, and who is the woman that is keeping her.“She was also told not to report to anybody,” he said.The family member told the story to the AP that same day.“In the voice recording, what was the girl’s husband saying and why was he so angry? Did she give out any names? We need to know. She also told me the phone number that she is receiving calls from and the voice coming from was not her husband’s voice. They are not speaking with her voice.”The family member also revealed that the family member who confirmed the recording was not able to get through to the girl as WhatsApp had not been working and the phone number had been disconnected.“She told me she is sure that Dapchi girls are alive and talking. We need to find them and make sure they are safe. I know it will take a long time to get hold of the video because DAPCHI GIRLS ARE ALIVE AND TALKING!”The family member said he would report the matter to the appropriate authorities.Earlier this year, five Dapchi girls, including the missing Dapchi girl, were found dead in a forest.

After 3.5 Million Voters Cast BallotsWASHINGTON (UrduPoint News / Sputnik - 20th January, 2020) United States elections are peaceful and secure even though millions of Americans voted for President Donald Trump, the US Electoral College has certified the results, a source familiar with the election told Sputnik on Friday.The source said that more than three-and-a-half million people voted in the US midterm elections and more than 2.5 million people voted in the US presidential elections."The transfer of power is peaceful," the source said.Elections run smoothly in the United States of America even though there are millions of Americans who want to see the outgoing president - Donald Trump - not only removed but also replaced with an alternative, the source said."The election is going smoothly. It is not up for debate that there are millions of people who want [Trump] to be removed. It is also not up for debate that the election is not secure for him, in the same way that the UK, Spain, and France elections are secure," the source said.The UK's House of Commons, for instance, voted to formally accept Brexit, while Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez won a confidence vote.The United States, on the other hand, is one of the most secure countries in the world, the source added.On Thursday, the US Electoral College confirmed the election results and the Senate also confirmed them.As a result, President-elect Joe Biden will now be inaugurated to his second four-year term. Trump will take up his post as a Cabinet member.

The elections in CAR are drawing to a close. The United Nations has warned that over 100 000 voting papers and electronic devices have been destroyed and are yet to be retrieved.This is what is making it difficult for the Commission of Presidential Elections to declare a winner as it could be challenged by the losing candidate.On Tuesday, the Electoral Board of the CAR held a press briefing to address the issue, where several top members of the political parties addressed them. Some of them insisted that their party won and would win the elections.The electoral board, however, explained that the process in the country requires a complex computer software in order for the results to be transmitted from the central data banks to the electoral commission. The central banks hold over 10 000, 000 of these data sheets."It is expected that there will be an overwhelming response, hence the delay. The commission would work towards restoring confidence to the general public by addressing their grievances as soon as possible,” the EC said.The CARs presidential election has been suspended since mid-August due to alleged electoral fraud. The EC said that the electoral commission is going to use satellite equipment that can capture information from the national electoral databases and transmit it to the commission’s headquarters in Lofa in Treloar, Togo.The EC had planned to conduct a re-run, if any, within a week, however, the CARs electoral commission decided to delay the elections in order for the EC to work on a new system to capture information from the databases.However, Togo’s President Faure Gnassingbe announced his decision to withdraw his candidacy for the upcoming elections, stating that he will remain on leave as head of state to ensure stability in the country.Mali, which is also embroiled in a political and religious crisis, said that it will hold elections after March 12th, 2019, as scheduled, without any delay.

16:45 by Yoshinori OnagaYoshinori Onaga (left), Prime Minister of Japan, and Nobuo Kishi (center) chief of the Cabinet Office, hold a news conference at his residence in Tokyo, Friday, after meeting with Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi of Japan. (Credit: Kyodo News via AP)A new Japanese foreign minister will be chosen next week to take on the post on a long-term plan to boost cooperation with the U.S. and other countries.Japan's outgoing foreign minister, who also heads the Cabinet Office, told reporters Friday that he will seek to strengthen ties with the United States and other countries in Asia.Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said his government will start a search for a new foreign minister in the second half of next week. Foreign Minister Motegi was selected to carry on the reform project begun by his predecessor, Fumio Kishida, who in July served as the country's first foreign minister since the abolition of the war cabinet.Before he was made prime minister, Kishida sought to boost ties with the U.S. and other countries in Asia and in Europe. Japan's ties with those countries have improved dramatically, but it needs to go further.

on ThursdayOn Thursday, the House of Representatives will hold the next installment of the impeachment of South African President Jacob Zuma. This time around, the lawmakers will be debating whether or not they should call for a second set of hearings in light of several newly revealed evidence.On January 18, the House of Representatives voted to support President Zuma's bid to get immunity from prosecution through a deal with the Department of Justice. On January 23, the National Prosecuting Authority presented several additional charges in relation to corruption against the president as well as his former deputy, Mcebisi Jonas. However, even after several new investigations into allegations of corruption against President Zuma, the president still maintained that he would be cleared of any wrongdoing.The debate on whether to call for a second set of hearings will be held in the House of Representatives on Thursday.

TUNIS (AP) — Tunisia’s prime minister on Wednesday announced a new government to form after weeks of political chaos since an anti-government movement pushed Tunisia’s president to step down.Mustafa Jazid led the secular, liberal government in a ceremony that was broadcast live on state television.Jazid urged the new government to immediately form a new cabinet and hold elections to give the nation’s population a “clear choice” between the current administration or a new government.Jazid, a 60-year-old technocrat, is a former interior minister under former autocrat Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, who was Tunisia’s head of state for 21 years.He had pledged to be a bridge to a younger generation disillusioned with Tunisia’s autocratic politics and its entrenched political system.Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi announced the formation of the government at the beginning of March, but Jazid’s appointment was delayed by weeks until the prime minister was confirmed.Essebsi said that “the new government must be as transparent as possible, and all the necessary funds to ensure the citizens’ development.”“

Over ElectionSouth Africa's main opposition party staged protests outside President Cyril Ramaphosa's official residence on Thursday over alleged irregularities in the March 8 presidential election.The main opposition Democratic Alliance party (DA) said the results of the presidential poll were "illegitimate" and they "hope" that Ramaphosa will step down if he does not accept the results.On Thursday, the DA was joined by the ruling African National Congress (ANC) and other political parties and thousands of people from various walks of life, including unions, trade unions, religious bodies and media houses.This week's protests come after the South African court upheld a request by the Electoral Commission to allow a petition to be presented before a special court to challenge the election result.In the petition, the Constitutional Court ordered the Electoral Commission (IEC) to produce evidence for the court to consider to decide whether there were significant irregularities or malfeasance in the voting process in the South African election.The court also ordered that the commission not present any evidence before the special court until a final decision by the court is made.The petition has been supported by the South Africa branch of the International Federation of Free Democrats (FDD).The petition was opposed by the ruling African National Congress, which has argued that the IEC failed to do its job properly and should be replaced by a party that does its job properly."The president of the ANC has also indicated that he does not want to accept the results, not even if they are in the interests of his party," the DA said."The current leadership of the ANC has demonstrated an abject failure to provide for the needs and interests of the people," the DA said.The party said there were "no grounds whatsoever" to suspect the outcome of the presidential election was fraudulently manipulated."The public, which has come to know the facts, can and should expect President Ramaphosa to resign if the results were not in the people's interests," the DA said.The party said that there was sufficient evidence to suggest that the election was rigged and there was "clearly a systematic and planned effort to rig the results".The EFF in a statement in support of the DA said that the party would hold protests until the results were accepted."

to End Years of Bitter DisputeA Vatican aide said Wednesday the pontiff will visit the Greek island of Lesbos on his way to Cairo on Friday, ending an acrimonious years-long feud with the island’s local council over the number of migrants it should allow to stay.Migrants have long complained of harassment and discrimination in Lesbos, and locals have protested at the pontiff’s presence there for several years, saying he has no right to interfere in local issues that affect people living there.But now Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni said the pope “will take advantage of the good weather and the lack of tourists” on the island and “explore the situation” in the face of the “difficult challenges facing” those living in Lesbos and “bring about a more pastoral approach.”Bruni didn’t give details about the pope’s “colloquium” with the islanders but said that they will “have an opportunity” to “share their concerns” with the pope.The islands’ government on Wednesday issued a decree approving a resolution that allows 3,000 migrants to stay there, but only if they are in fact migrants seeking asylum and are in accordance with the law, not because they have entered in search of something better elsewhere.Lesbos’ city hall is appealing a 2016 ruling that said the island council had acted improperly by insisting on the migrants staying, but the European Court of Human Rights and several other international courts and human rights bodies have said Lesbos had a legitimate argument for the number of migrants it should accept.The island of 28,000 is the last in a group of five Greek islands along the Turkish coast, and some 20,000 people live there.Most of them are Syrian refugees who arrived on nearby Turkey’s Aegean Sea island of İzmir after the start of the Syrian civil war in 2011, and many more are asylum seekers who entered illegally from Greece.The new decree will allow three of the island’s 14,500 inhabitants to request residency documents such as work permits, but that doesn’t mean a migrant can apply to live permanently on the island because they would have to pass tests to prove they’d be able to support themselves.

(CN) – The Environmental Protection Agency must bolster its oversight of water supplies under the 2010 National Water Supply Improvements Act, the Government Accountability Office has found.In a letter to EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, the watchdog agency’s Office of Inspector General said that the National Water Supply Improvements Act did not require the EPA to ensure that water supplies are safe before the National Water Supply Reform Act took effect."Specifically, the National Water Supply Improvement Act did not require the EPA to ensure that water supplies were safe before water sources and drinking water systems were restored," the IG’s report said.The IG’s office said the National Water Supply Reform Act, as it was initially enacted, did not impose penalties for water quality issues that led to contaminated water."However, under a revised National Water Supply Reform Act, the EPA must identify and correct any water sources for which water quality is impacted and address compliance issues that result in those water sources being withdrawn for a period of time," the report said."

Hillary Clinton is not pleased with the choice her husband, John F. Obama, made when he chose not to endorse Hillary in the Republican primaries. Clinton says Obama "slammed" the basket of deplorables.Obama may have saved his face among the Democrats, especially as Hillary Clinton comes under increasing criticism for her campaign's handling of the Clinton Foundation's ties to foreign governments and corruption in the Middle East. The new controversy in Clinton's camp comes a day after the Washington Post reported that the State Department paid millions of dollars for "aid" to the U.S.-backed Afghan National Army despite Clinton having declared that Afghanistan was not a U.S. foreign policy and that American money was "being used to arm, train, finance and support the government of a country that has repeatedly proven it cannot be trusted to control its own military."The Daily Beast reports that an "indefinite number" of State Department employees will be transferred to work for the Clinton Foundation, while others will continue to be paid by the State Department. At least one top aide will also start a consulting business at the Clinton Foundation with his wife, top aide Huma Abedin.But more troubling than the pay for favors scandal and the new money involved in foreign aid for Afghan soldiers is the fact that many of the millions of dollars in foreign aid that were supposed to be used for U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan have instead been used for Clinton Foundation projects overseas.The State Department has been making public statements saying that the money donated to Afghanistan was not used for the Clinton Foundation, but some of the money has in fact been used for the foundation.Clinton told ABC News, "I was furious" when she learned that "a significant amount" of the money from Afghanistan for U.S. soldiers had been used for the foundation.But she insisted that as a senator she had an understanding that the money was used for other purposes.She also denied that she personally knew of any of the money going to the foundation or had any control over its use for its various projects, but she admitted that she was aware of her husband's handling of the foundation's finances."I think I just kind of went along with it because I was my husband," Clinton said.

After Trump-Putin Summithttp://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/v0V1aP7jg3M/WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed their long-festering disputes as well as steps they believe can be taken to defuse some of the tensions that flared following the long-running war in Afghanistan.Biden and Putin met in Geneva for a one-on-one session following their talks on Tuesday that focused on Afghanistan, the climate crisis and trade. They also worked out details on a potential meeting between Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin, which the two men have repeatedly expressed interest in attending next year.The leaders also discussed their respective approaches to countering cybercrime and ensuring cyber insurance coverage for critical infrastructure, while stressing the need for Russia to take "prompt steps" to end its support for ransomware attacks on American businesses.Biden, who won a presidential election last month largely based on his promise to restore America's long-standing international leadership, said Putin and his government have been "unpredictable" and warned against the potential for increased Russian interference in the 2020 U.S. elections.The two leaders, who have met once previously — in Helsinki, Finland, for the Group of Seven meeting in 2018 — also expressed an eagerness to improve their strained relationship following four years of intense U.S.-Russian relations, said senior administration officials who briefed reporters on the meeting.The Kremlin said the meeting was primarily about boosting ties but noted that Russia and the United States are facing "difficult" relations and that the leaders "may consider the possibility of holding a meeting next year to discuss all aspects of their bilateral relationship."That would mark the first time Putin and Biden have sat down face to face since Biden took office. They met virtually at the G7 summit in June.The meeting came amid a U.S.-Russia standoff over the situation in Afghanistan, the climate crisis and the war in Ukraine that has left more than 2,400 U.S. soldiers dead and nearly 20,000 wounded over the past three decades.

Singapore, the most expensive city in Asia, is preparing an unprecedented stimulus package to cushion the coronavirus hit to its economy, the government said on Tuesday, even though it still expects to record a zero growth in the fourth quarter.Singapore's gross domestic product expanded at a record pace in the first quarter, but the central bank expects a record-low contraction of 0.1 percent in the July to September period as the economic impact of the pandemic becomes clear.Singapore had largely contained the virus, with only 1,853 active cases in the last three weeks of October, but the city-state has since seen new local infections, with five new cases announced on Tuesday.Cabinet Secretary Josephine Teo said the government would roll out an additional S$500 billion ($372.64 billion) in fiscal measures to help firms and individuals to weather the impact of the virus, including cash grants, loans and tax relief.Teo said that the government had spent a record S$1.7 trillion on relief efforts to date.The measures will be accompanied by another S$4.4 billion in loans, and the government will also continue to provide tax relief, she said.Teo said this will help support firms to remain viable and prevent job losses.Singapore plans to ramp up measures for workers and firms as it braces for a sharp slowdown in the economy.Teo said that the government was "confident that measures to support businesses, workers and households" are in place, and that the public would not have to wait for a "last-minute" package.She did not say when the package would be released, but said that it will be announced at the appropriate time.Teo said that measures to support households are more targeted and that households may be able to apply for grants and tax relief via mobile applications.Singapore's economy is heavily dependent on exports.The finance minister said that the current economic situation was different from the 2003 crisis, when a global recession led to a sharp downgrade in the country's credit rating and an increase in unemployment.Teo also said that Singapore's fiscal position would not be affected by the coronavirus outbreak, though the impact on the local currency would be significant.Singapore's central bank expects a 0.1 percent contraction in GDP in the current quarter, and economists expect a deeper contraction than 0.1

© AFP 2016/ Maksim Bolyazhian US Calls for 'Fairer' Settlement in South OssetiaMOSCOW (Sputnik) — "If there is no peace settlement on the peninsula, there will be an even greater crisis in the region," Trump said at a joint press conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin.The United States and Russia have been locked in a long-standing territorial dispute over South Ossetia, a region that is heavily Russian-populated. The conflict began in August 2008 when Georgian forces captured and occupied the territory. Since then, Russia has been fighting the separatists, who it considers part of the Georgian side.The United States has offered a number of solutions for peace between the sides, including a referendum on independence. The United States also has offered to mediate, but the Georgian side rejected them, saying that they would have been satisfied with a peace deal that was only a resolution to the long-standing conflict.US President Donald Trump on Tuesday urged an end to bloodshed on the peninsula."All lives are worth fighting for," Trump said, speaking at a joint press conference with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin."I want there to be peace and for peace to come, so no lives should be lost, and if lives are lost there will be an even greater crisis," Trump said, urging for the ceasefire to be implemented.In response, the Georgian side noted that the Russian-backed separatists continued to violate ceasefire agreements by fighting."The Russian Federation continues to violate all the agreements related to ceasefire. In the last three years, as of August 15, the Russian Federation and its armed forces have committed over 4,500 violations of ceasefire. Therefore, this is an open war," the Foreign Ministry said in a statement.The statement was signed by Georgian Foreign Minister David Zalkaliani.

The Israeli Foreign Ministry said Thursday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu welcomes the Arab League's call to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.In a statement, it said Israel "would be happy to hear from the Arab League when it comes to concrete proposals which could contribute to further strengthening of the peace process between Israel and the Arab world.""It is also true that we are encouraged to note that in the Arab League statement there is a proposal for the establishment of a committee of foreign ministers," the statement said.It did not elaborate. But Israel has said a possible proposal for a committee could include the participation of the Arab League's secretariat.The Israeli foreign ministry statement said that the conference of Arab League foreign ministers would take place on Thursday.Israel is preparing its own statement.The Arab League is an influential bloc in international politics.

LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s new leader, has vowed to make a political fight of the Brexit negotiations with the European Union, but the Labor Party has rejected his demands for a “special” Brexit deal to try to secure votes on the final agreement.Johnson, who was elected leader of the Conservative Party on Friday, has signaled his ambitions to negotiate a Brexit deal with the EU, but warned that he would not put up with a “joke” of a deal that would leave Britain tied to the EU indefinitely.Johnson says the UK could hold a referendum next year about whether to accept the terms of Brexit. He says he would be willing to put an unpopular proposal on the table to keep the country in the bloc’s common fisheries policy and other agreements, but he would also not accept a bad deal.Labour’s main leadership is now facing a crucial decision. The party’s official position is still that Britain should leave the EU on the terms set out in the Benn Act passed by parliament earlier this year. However, many senior members have indicated that they would give it more than one chance to see if it would be able to be changed. Johnson has promised to force a referendum, which would require the support of Labour’s parliamentary majority, if he cannot negotiate a good deal.Labour’s Brexit spokesperson Keir Starmer has said his party would only agree to a deal that it felt satisfied with.“When it is ready we will put it to the vote,” Starmer said. “We are very clear that there is no deal that we would put to the vote for the first two and a half weeks of December and that’s a fact.”“We are going to have to go through the processes to try to make sure that a deal can get through parliament, but I’m absolutely certain that there will be a deal for Labour that will be good for the British people,” he said.Johnson’s Brexit chief Dominic Cummings had a similar view. “I think Keir Starmer and Corbyn are very close to actually making a bad deal,” Cummings said.

Folks that may not be aware of this but Rogers has a huge following in the US and he has been around longer than most of us. His new album is an Americana crossover type of music that fans may not have been aware of.Well, Rogers dies today at the age of 81. This is the second major rock death of the month, just behind a much bigger deal with the late Robert Plant. The biggest is probably going to be that of Buddy Holly, but Rogers' fame is just as much to be feared.He was on the road from 1952 to 1969, but he was always a little bit under the radar compared to the other big stars. He even got his first number one by simply taking the name of a famous musician and changing the melody around it. This is called a "derivative success", and you can see why Rogers wanted nothing more to do with it. He was always a nice person to work with. He didn't get into the bad stuff very often, but he was still around pretty much the entire time.

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/XN2jQm1l1e8/Thousands of protesters rallied in Taiwan's main city on Thursday in a peaceful but dramatic demonstration aimed at pressing the government of President Tsai Ing-wen over a recent crackdown on protests in China's Xinjiang province.The demonstration began with a call for Tsai's government to respond to the Chinese government's alleged abuse of Uyghur Muslims in the Xinjiang province by sending some 200,000 troops to "stabilize" the situation.China's Xinjiang region has long been the focus of Chinese concern, with Tsai saying that the rights of the Xinjiang residents were under threat. The protesters said that the use of the word "stabilize" was a sign that Tsai's government was not ready to send troops to the region."The Chinese government has deployed troops to Xinjiang and has committed ethnic cleansing," said one demonstrator. "We cannot allow Beijing to carry on unchecked in the region," said another.As the demonstration began, the crowd chanted "freedom, democracy" and "China, China, China," a reference to China's repeated claim that Taiwan is its own territory, despite the island's democratically elected government having rejected the claim in the past.The protesters were divided along party lines with about 80 percent of those in the demonstration being members of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and China's government.The CCP has repeatedly stated that Taiwan is a part of China.However, Taiwan's president has expressed her support for the autonomy of Taiwan from China, saying that while she did not support Taiwanese independence, she did support the people of the self-ruling island in the face of a Chinese invasion."Taiwan is not independent, it's merely a country under China's jurisdiction," said Tsai.

U.S. retail sales came in well below analysts' expectations, an indication that the economic recovery has faltered.U.S. retail sales figures for September rose 1.4 percent from August, but that was weaker than analysts expected and well below the 2.2 percent increase in July.“September’s weak reading was somewhat less surprising than most of the forecasts that had been made for the quarter, but is not a sign that momentum has waned yet,” said Lindsey Bell, chief investment officer for Charles Schwab. “If retail sales continue to trend down like this, it could threaten the expansion and possibly send the economy down its very dangerous and unexpected curve.”Retail sales accounts for around 70 percent of the economy.Consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in six months in October.While consumer spending fell last month, the weak result was a reflection of the slowdown in the housing sector, which is leading the economy.“As the housing market continues to cool, it's likely that consumer confidence will continue to weaken. If consumer confidence stays this weak, it would be difficult for the economy to rebound,” said Paul Dales, senior economist at Capital Economics.Consumers have been the main engine of economic growth so far this year. The weak retail sales come on the heels of a disappointing consumer spending reading last week. Analysts expected consumer spending to rise a mere 0.1 percent in October.U.S. stocks declined on Monday in reaction to the disappointing retail sales numbers, while bonds were trading with some upside momentum as the market digested the data. The stock market is down by roughly 1 percent over the last several days as investors fretted that economic growth will slow further without another financial stimulus effort.Retail sales can be a reliable indicator of consumer spending but are a lagging indicator because it doesn't always happen in the same month. The Federal Reserve will be looking closely at consumer spending figures when it meets on Dec. 14-15 to make an interest rate decision. The Fed has pledged to keep interest rates low to support the U.S. economic recovery.

, First-Ever Space Trip for Two Women in Three MonthsNASA astronaut Christina Koch, left, and Anne McClain, prepare to attach the space station's external truss adapter on Saturday, after spacewalking in an unprecedented three-day mission for a new mission to replace a critical space station component.NASA astronaut Christina Koch, left, and Anne McClain, prepare to attach the space station's external truss adapter on Saturday, after spacewalking in an unprecedented three-day mission for a new mission to replace a critical space station component.The crew of the international space station is about to dock with their spacecraft, marking a successful launch of the SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft and first-ever astronauts mission for two women in three months.Christina Koch and Anne McClain launched on a three-day, spacewalk to replace a damaged Russian space station component with a new piece to the outside of the orbiting laboratory.Christina Koch and Anne McClain are two of seven members of the crew aboard the ISS.

Hurricane Florence has been downgraded to a tropical storm, but it's already affecting the air force and its pilots.With the storm bearing down on the Carolinas, the air force has sent six KC-130's and four KC-10's into the path of the storm to help out the military forces at sea and at home.One KC-10 is stationed at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, and four others are deployed to Naval Air Station Patuxent River in Maryland, where the KC-10s will deliver extra supplies and resupply to U.S. forces stationed in and around the Carolinas.The sixth KC-10, a KC-130J, also is stationed at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada.Another KC-10 is stationed at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada.The air force crews in all the planes are well trained to deal with emergency operations like these.The KC-10 pilots will be on standby for the hurricane in case things go really south. Their planes will also be ready to relieve otherKC-130's if the needs arise. The KC-10 and KC-135's will be used to bring in food, water, fuel, and other supplies if necessary as the hurricane advances through the North Atlantic Ocean.

Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019 with Chinese tourists back on the Mainland.Tourism is one of the most important Chinese industries that has been decimated in recent years due to the COVID pandemic. While the Mainland does not have an overabundance of Broadway shows, the bubble is popping.Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019.Photo: Vivo Pictures/Getty ImagesAccording to a report from the Beijing tourism industry and exhibition center, the number of Chinese tourists to the Mainland, including both locals and tourists, has reached its peak.This report also said that for the first time since 2019, tourists visited the Mainland more frequently and the Mainland began to welcome more American tourists to the country.Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019.

, killing 13Suicide bomber attacked a gas company in southern China on Monday, killing 13 people and wounding 10 more, officials said.At least three suicide bombers targeted the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation in Quetta, killing 13 people and wounding 10 others, the China Xinhua News Agency reported.The terrorists were wearing explosive vests and had left a car nearby before attacking, it said. The blast took place about 10am local time at the plant's main gate.Beijing earlier expressed its "great sorrow" over the incident and said China stands by Pakistan.China has long been a powerful ally of Pakistan, including supplying a large number of security forces to Pakistan. However, tensions between the countries have been on the rise lately over a long-standing dispute over Kashmir.Last week China accused Pakistan of being behind the abduction of a Chinese businessman and a scientist from Pakistan who are both now being held in Afghan jails.China said it would not interfere in the affairs of other countries but urged Pakistan to "stop threatening China over the past year".

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice says President George W. Bush has "absolutely no choice but to call on Congress" to authorize the use of force against Iraq, calling for more troops and a more aggressive, comprehensive approach to get rid of weapons of mass destruction.The White House has been divided over whether to send more troops, and whether to send them on a longer deployment. Bush has said he wants to keep troops in place until he has the political authority to get the job done.But Rice told reporters that Bush had "absolutely no choice but to call on Congress" to authorize the use of force against Iraq.Earlier, Senate Republicans said they would try and win Senate approval for a no-fly zone and increased U.S. military and intelligence assets.Rice, the nation's top diplomat, said a "bipartisan effort" was necessary for any action to end the war.But Sen. Joseph Lieberman, who introduced legislation in February that called for a no-fly zone, said it was impossible now for the nation to go back and change the course of the war in Iraq, though he said Congress could help move the nation on the right path."

Former Somali president Yusuf Dhebe, who presided over the post-Gadhafi political transformation, has died at the age of 77.Mr Dhebe suffered from a stroke on Tuesday and died on Thursday, according to friends and relatives.Mr Dhebe, who won an electoral victory in 1986 and served as president from 1989 to 1991, is best known as the person who spearheaded the transition to the nation's democratic system.In 2008, he was named Time magazine's People of the Year and that same year was awarded the Order of the Black Sea.Mr Dhebe's tenure was marked by a successful election, which was hailed as a model for the entire African continent.It was also marked by unrest, with a number of ethnic and religious clashes.Mr Dhebe was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2014 for his efforts in ensuring peace and stability in Somalia.However, the country went to the polls again in 2016 for a new presidential election, which Mr Dhebe himself was barred from taking part in, after he had been found guilty of war crimes under UN Security Council resolution 1325.

The Japanese yen rises against all the other major currencies in Tokyo, and the currency of the US, the dollar, falls to new lows against major currencies.The US dollar is currently trading at 112.80 yen, down 0.25 percent from 109.60 yen in Tokyo trading. The greenback has not been able to stay above 112.80 yen. According to Bloomberg, the yen has been in a strong uptrend for the past few years.The dollar fell against the Swedish krona, the Norwegian krone, the Canadian dollar, the Australian dollar and the Norwegian krone. The dollar was trading at 0.9214 krona in Tokyo.The US dollar dropped 0.25 percent against the British pound. The US dollar dropped 1.05 percent against the Euro. The dollar dropped 0.40 percent against the Australian dollar. The currency dropped 1.17 percent against the Swedish krona.US stock market markets opened weak.Shares in the S&P 500 fell 0.54 percent to a record low level. The major indexes fell by more than 0.5 percent each.The Japanese Nikkei 225 fell 0.59 percent, while the broader Topix lost 0.57 percent.Stocks in Germany declined by 2.13 percent.

President Donald Trump on Friday requested that the Securities and Exchange Commission revise its policies on how quarterly reports are disseminated in order to align them with the administration’s policies.In a letter to SEC Chairman Jay Clayton, Trump asked that the SEC consider modifying the process so that it is more consistent with the administration's agenda."My Administration is committed to using every legal, administrative, and technological tool available to ensure that all individuals and businesses are treated fairly.

17:00, WIPO"We see this as a challenge which requires our response, and that response will continue, including the potential use of force." - SharonWest Bank Military Campaign Will Continue - 2002-04-08 17:00, WIPOOvernight, Israel announced that it was moving forward with a military campaign to take control of the West Bank if necessary. The army and police have been deployed to the area to assist the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) in their effort to gain control of the West Bank, thus securing their independence.The PLO has not officially announced the start of any campaign, but it is widely rumored to have begun. The PA has requested assistance from the international community to protect civilians in Ramallah.The announcement comes as the war drums are beating louder in Washington, and pressure for a campaign is growing. The White House is being pressured by the administration to get Israel to make an official request for more troops.A spokesman for the PLO said that they were ready to use force if required, but that they are not planning an attack today. The Palestinian leadership has accused Israel of attacking civilian areas with its tank attacks and is trying to gain international sympathy.In Gaza, the Israeli military has intensified its attacks against Hamas.

Egypt's rice producers saw a tough future over the next decade in the face of the country's planned mega-dams upstream of the massive hydroelectric dam.The African countries have seen their water supplies dwindle as river levels have declined due to climate change. Many farmers are also facing increased labour costs from flooding the fields, which is forcing them to move to dryer regions like South Sudan or Nigeria.The country's planned mega-dam is called the Tuna Project, which will create an impoundment of almost 6,000 square kilometres (2,500 sq miles) upstream of the dam in the Nile basin.Egyptian officials say the project could create more jobs, particularly in its construction phase.But some say the project will exacerbate the country's food shortage.The Nile River originates in the East African continent, crosses the Middle East and reaches southern Africa. The river supplies water to over a dozen countries including Egypt, Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda, Uganda, Sudan, South Africa and Ethiopia's main neighbor the Great Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in the Blue Nile.Egyptian farmers rely on the Nile to irrigate their crops and supply households.Last year the country was hit by an extended drought, which meant crops such as maize had to be replanted due to the water shortage. As a result, Egypt saw food prices rise."The situation is very bad for us; we are going to spend a lot of money if we don't go to our fields and sell our crops," said Nasser El-Haddad, a rice farmer and member of the United Farmers' Movement, which is demanding that the construction of GERD be suspended."

: ReportUnited Nations chief Ban Ki-moon urged world leaders at the annual meeting of the General Assembly on Monday to fulfil their commitments to end extreme poverty by 2020, according to a draft document seen by AFP.Ban said the global fight to end extreme poverty was crucial to the realization of the goals of the "Millennium Challenge," the United Nations' flagship development project and the keystone of international aid.The goal of ending extreme poverty, a measure of a person's well-being that excludes poverty and hardship, was the third-highest in Ban's list of the "four Pillars of the United Nations (UN) Charter, which the UN first adopted in 1981."The world of 2030 presents great challenges, particularly to the global economic order. To meet these challenges and to protect the peace and security of our nations, we must build on the achievements of previous decades and invest in the social and economic transition of our people," Ban said in the draft UN document seen by AFP."Many countries and people have shown great courage and dedication by making profound and positive changes in their societies and societies that will endure."Ban urged political leaders from his group — with which the US and UK are also a part — and leaders from other nations — including Russia and China — to work together to achieve the "goal of lifting the world from extreme poverty to prosperity."

Lori Albrecht is a tech entrepreneur who has a lot of experience working within tech. She has a degree in business administration and is also a CPA.
