: World Bank Assessed $5.4 Bln Emergency COVID-19 FundThe World Bank has said that it has set up an emergency response facility to address the worsening economic and socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis. The Facility, which will be used to support the World Bank's work to stop the spread of the virus, can help mitigate the effects of the pandemic in a number of ways.The Emergency Response facility is a part of the multilateral development bank's $5.4 billion, 20-year COVID-19 Response and Recovery Plan, announced by the World Bank's president David Malpass in April 2020. The facility will be used by the UN Economic Commission for Western Asia (UNECWA), under its emergency response framework that will help to address the economic and socio-economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the region.The Emergency Response will support member countries' responses, such as building health services and providing basic livelihoods to combat the impact of the crisis. In addition, it will facilitate the acceleration of climate adaptation and mitigation efforts across the region.The Facility includes $5.4 billion, $1.8 billion and $2.9 billion. This will be used in a host of ways, including supporting Member States' response to the coronavirus pandemic and their transition to low-carbon and resilient development. In addition, the Facility will support Member States' capacity to adapt to climate impacts, including through their preparedness to respond to extreme weather and natural disasters in both the long-term and short term.The Facility will help mitigate the effects of the pandemic in the region, while ensuring that Member States' economies and livelihoods are not adversely affected, the World Bank said in a statement.The announcement by the World Bank was made in a letter to the UN Economic Commission for Western Asia from World Bank Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva, in which she said that "the COVID-19 pandemic and its impacts have posed serious threats to development, particularly on women and girls. While the number of deaths and severe cases continues to increase, the recovery is largely limited to countries and regions where there is a well-established social safety net, including public health systems, affordable access to healthcare, and effective social programs.""

The Occupy movement has been looking to the people for support, but with the political gridlock at the state and federal level, they may need to find ways to reach more people and make a physical presence more effective. But the only way to make it happen in the short term is to recruit more organizers.On Monday, August 17, the group held its first convention to vote on how to best move forward. According to a post at Occupy Nation, the group decided that a more centralized leadership team would be better than the decentralized approach they have tried.An article in the Daily Kos reports that the OWS group is aiming to build “an organization on the basis of shared principles rather than a group of volunteers with different agendas and different levels of influence.” They’ll try to attract “a core of dedicated organizers who are passionate about our message and willing to devote time to getting things done.”An anonymous post at the site is saying that the group is trying to set up a network of local unions and other supporters who will be working with the group on things like voter registration, training, and education.And there was one more announcement. For the first time, there are also plans to have a physical presence in the nation’s capitol.“

Three Indonesian sailors went missing and feared dead off the southern Philippine coast in MarchA third Indonesian sailor has disappeared after being taken hostage in the southern Philippines, officials said on Friday, as the country's military intensified searches to find missing sailors.The crewmen – three Indonesians and one Filipino – were abducted in late March, two months after they disappeared in waters near the Maluku Islands, a Philippine archipelago.The military's naval commander said his men had "rescued" the hostages in waters near the Philippine capital, Manila, and were "trying to rescue" them.The soldiers were "searching for the people missing and there are possibilities that they might be dead," he said.The naval commander did not say how long the search operation will continue.A fisherman named Fadil Suhari – who has been seen in pictures with the men – claimed he saw one of the crewmen on a ship in the Gulf of Tonkin on Feb. 25, but he could not be contacted after that."

sBurundian political parties are required to register voters as citizens of the country, but if the government were to allow a “free press,” it could allow foreign journalists."The government is saying that they are preparing for elections, but at the moment the media cannot enter the country,” said Burundi Commissioner for Freedom of Press, Robert Mugisha.Mugisha was addressing the press on Tuesday, after a session of the ruling National Patriotic Front party’s Standing Council, which was held at a school in the north Burundian town of Kayanza.“The government will not allow foreign journalists to enter the country because it means that they would not be able to report as citizens as they say,” he added.On February 5, Burundi Foreign Affairs minister, Oly Ilunga, declared on Twitter that the country’s authorities would “allow international journalists, but the restrictions include the limitation of access to the capital city [Kigali]” and its environs.Burundi is due to hold elections in 2020, with the President of the African Union’s (AU) member states to head a 15-member electoral commission.There are already three parties already in place, and four others have expressed an intention to run. However, another five will be allowed to field candidates.

Islamabad: After days of heavy fighting with militants in the volatile region of Swat valley, Pakistani forces killed all remaining militants, including senior Taliban commanders, in the area, the army said on Wednesday.Pakistan's army carried out "precision strikes" against militants who had holed up in the city of Mianwali, the main city of the region in the southwestern Swat Valley province."Pakistan Armed Forces (PAF) has successfully targeted militants" in Mianwali area, a statement said.Earlier in the day, the Pakistani military said militants had trapped around 15,000 people inside their valley stronghold, a region where militants have a free hand to carry out suicide attacks.In January 2020, militants including some senior commanders from the Taliban had entered Swat valley, taking over Swati tribes' lands and capturing swathes of territory.(

: NASAWashington, Jan 26 (PTI) NASA has warned that a US satellite that had recently fallen to Earth might have been hit by a "dangerous fuel" after it had burned up, and there was no cause for alarm after the US space agency said the satellite had returned to Earth safely on Monday.The US space agency has launched a satellite into space on Sunday, and just before midnight on Monday, it had returned to Earth, following a trajectory that kept it from falling into the ocean."We can confirm that our S-II X-Band global positioning satellite, with its payload attached, is in the Earth's atmosphere. The satellite is healthy," said NASA in a statement Monday."I want to be clear that while there is no reason to be alarmed at this time, we will continue to monitor the situation. The satellite was in our orbit and is in a healthy orbit," it said.US space agency is concerned about the loss of one of the two remaining US S-band satellites which are crucial for communication with ships, aircraft and other vehicles in the Asia-Pacific region.The loss of the satellites has happened to at least two countries in the world, including the US, that had launched them.After a lengthy effort, the satellite launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida, got into an elliptical orbit, and was in a stable position with a period of one month."The S-I (or "Kestrel" in the US military) tracking network, which has been providing global communications to the Navy for years, had been down since November 28 following a mishap with a failed satellite. That happened when the system was being updated from old equipment, which is a common event with spacecraft," NASA said in its statement.The US space agency said it would not be able to provide specific details of the status of the satellite, because it was not being commanded or controlled, but it was in a "stable orbit in deep Earth-orbit, within the global communications network".

: ReportChina will start building a U.S. assembly plant in 2019, reports CNBC. The news comes amid the ongoing trade war between the two nations.CNBC reports that China will start building a U.S. assembly plant in 2019, a move that could help bring the two nations closer to an end to the tariff battle that has strained commerce relations for over a year.This would help the economy as both nations work to end the trade war with a less bitter feeling.Currently, neither China nor the U.S. have a car factory in operation to produce vehicles for American consumers.China already manufactures cars in the world's two largest economies, so having the U.S. take a look into doing the same would make economic sense as both countries look to bolster their economies.But how long it would take for the U.S. market to be flooded with vehicles from China remains to be seen, and the CNBC report cites no timetable.There were some hopes that the U.S. would agree to purchase Chinese-made electric cars from the company BYD when the two nations signed a memorandum of understanding in 2018.Still, no official word or official announcement has been made since 2018. A BYD electric car was recently unveiled in the Chinese market.One of the biggest reasons for the Trump administration wanting to cut a deal with China on trade is that the president claims that the U.S. has "little to gain" from a trade deal with the Chinese and that the trade war is bad for the U.S. business community.U.S. President Donald Trump is currently in a trade war with China, which is also in the process of putting a tariff on another U.S. product: steel.Read the original article on CNBC. Copyright 2018. Follow CNBC on Twitter.

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/zfXkG4r_V_Y/Director of National Intelligence John Bolton predicted Tuesday that U.S.-Russia ties would improve after President Joe Biden’s meetings with Russian President Vladimir Putin and that Biden would agree to meet next month in Paris with Putin.When asked about a meeting between the two leaders in Paris to discuss the coronavirus and other issues, Bolton said “certainly I see that we’ll have an agreement to meet.”“And then in Paris I believe we’re going to have a summit,” the former ambassador to the United Nations said.Bolton told NBC’s Today show that he had heard the idea from Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov.“There’s been a number of meetings between our foreign ministers over the last six months, some of them in Paris,” Bolton said. “And I think we’re on track to have a meeting.”He said Biden and Putin had agreed to resume the strategic dialogue between the United States and Russia that was cut off by former President Donald Trump.He said the two presidents would consider working together to “address serious issues facing our world.”

In A World Of LiesThe “hurry-up-and-wait” approach in Delhi, where it will take up to 2 months for the government to get a new cabinet, is a typical example of Indian democracy’s inability to function effectively. But Shailja Patel is changing this, with her candid video messages in which she openly discusses about her experience, and that of her sister, who are both suffering from mental illness.Shailja Patel’s videos are a welcome change from the monotonous and insensitive narration that many videos on social media share about mental health. She has spoken at length about her experiences as a child who is afflicted with Asperger’s, and the challenges that it poses for someone with a learning deficit to hold a job.I wish every Indian would become as unphased by the phrase “Asperger’s”, and “dyslexia”, as Shailja Patel has become by the term “mental illness” in our society.As a child, Shailja, and her sister, Shruti, were subjected to a very different set of experiences in their home. Shailja had a normal upbringing and a happy childhood. However, at an early age, the family realised that Shailja suffered from mental illness that manifested itself as an inability to process social events. Shruti could not do the same, as her brain, unlike that of Shailja’s, had a very high processing speed. Shruti was a gifted child, and went on to win the IAS exam and be the director of a prestigious government school. And Shailja, by her own admission, was the opposite.It has been a long process of acceptance in which Shruti and Shailja have learnt to live with their illnesses, with a higher degree of consciousness and a higher degree of comfort. Shruti’s battle with Asperger’s has helped Shailja accept, and to live with, the label of being mentally unwell.At the same time, Shruti has been taking advantage of the social acceptance, and the chance for her to work in the private sector. While Shailja is struggling with the mental illness, Shruti’s career is steadily rising.

ATHENS – Greece’s government on Friday defended a court decision that held back extradition to Turkey of soldiers suspected of involvement in deadly 2010 events, saying it must be respected and there is no need for a fresh court procedure.Greece’s ruling coalition and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras have been accused of seeking to have their allies acquitted in the case in order to ensure they remain in office come the next election in 2019.Greece’s chief prosecutor said on Thursday the court would not back a request by the government to send the soldiers to Turkey for trial, despite a court’s verdict last week that ruled against them.Tsipras and his government have called for new court proceedings on the basis that the men’s trial would be fair and would not be politicized ahead of a fresh general election.Tsipras said during an interview with the Kathimerini daily that any attempt to circumvent the original decision by the court would be an “adversarial procedure” and would not be accepted.He also rejected allegations that Greece was seeking to be granted legal immunity for members of his government, saying that this was “an imaginary interpretation.”The issue of whether Tsipras and his government should be tried for war crimes for allegedly ordering attacks on the Kurdish minority during the fighting against the Islamic State militant group in Syria has also plagued their governing coalition in recent months.The military actions of Greece’s foreign policy since the country’s 2011 crisis have come under fire from Turkey, an ally of the government of Greek premier Alexis Tsipras, over the alleged violations of the Geneva convention.The prosecutor has previously said that there was no “legal reason” to send the men back for prosecution.

Addis Ababa, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 19th Jun, 2021 ) :US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Wednesday that Washington was committed to supporting Ethiopia's "fragile" reforms and urged the ruling military to take a "new approach".Addressing reporters at the end of his first visit to Ethiopia as the US leader, Blinken also called for the release of an American journalist held for two years at an undisclosed location."We welcome the progress in the reforms that are taking place there," he said. "But we want to see a new approach, especially now that the democratic process is really starting to unfold and to be fully implemented."We want to see this change go smoothly," he added.Blinken had visited Addis Ababa at the start of an international visit intended to shore up support for its military intervention in Tigray, as the conflict rages on in the largely agricultural country.Addis Ababa has faced increased pressure to open dialogue with its former foe as the United Nations Security Council is scheduled to hold a meeting on the situation on Thursday.Ethiopian troops backed by fighters from neighbouring Eritrea have taken control of Tigray's former regional capital after holding off an offensive by local forces.Ethiopia's government says the army won victory over Tigray's local rulers.But Tigray's leaders claim the army is now attacking civilians.The United Nations says it is "conflicted" over the conflict, which is also spreading into Sudan, Eritrea and Sudan.Ethiopia's government is accused of human rights abuses, but human rights groups say government troops committed atrocities.Blinken said he met leaders of the TPLF -- the Tigray People's Liberation Front -- during his two-day visit.The TPLF leader, Abiy Ahmed, had ruled the Tigray region for nearly three decades until last November.As Tigrayans began their resistance against Prime Minister Abiy, they were attacked and some officials were killed.Tigrayans rebelled.

as One of Their Own, Report SaysIn an attempt to explain the growing popularity of Rwanda on the continent, the U.S. has been holding a series of events in the country. For example, a bipartisan group of politicians met with Kagame when they visited Rwanda in April 2015 and asked him to explain his government's policies and programs."In every country, there are people who take their place," Kagame told the gathering, referring to himself and his Rwanda National Assembly members. "We need to understand the role of government and where it has a particular responsibility, such as the role of education, or to promote economic development in a country; we need to understand the role of agriculture."While they were on the ground, politicians were repeatedly told to "understand that the government is not a single organization."In a recent Washington Post editorial, the newspaper's editorial director described the recent meetings as "a good idea" and "a way for Kagame to explain why he's popular to American audiences."The editorial suggested that Kagame was looking to "understand his own place" as the leader of a country whose people were "being oppressed and massacred," and that Kagame was doing so "to prove that he could be trusted."The editorial also argued that the U.S. should not be quick to judge Kagame's policies and "should be patient" and that such a close working relationship with his country was not a "strategic necessity," but a "good and necessary thing."In the Post story, however, journalists noted that this relationship did not exist previously. And they also noted that the State Department's policy on Rwanda has changed dramatically in recent years.In 2014, State was so frustrated with the government's human rights abuses that it imposed economic sanctions. Then, in 2017, President Trump signed a waiver that eased some of those sanctions."There are no words to describe the American disappointment with Kagame's government," said one former U.S. official at the time. "They have done nothing but kill their own people."During that meeting in April of that year, some U.S. lawmakers also criticized Kagame's human rights policies. However, Kagame has faced few international challenges since taking power in 1994, and his government has never had serious trouble in accessing foreign investment."

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/fQp-5xu8P3w/Former President Reagan is making the rounds as a hologram in an effort to help secure the GOP ticket against President Joe Biden in the election.According to The Christian Science Monitor, the hologram is a three-dimensional, digitally-generated image produced and projected onto a screen, usually by a virtual artist, to help a person in need."The video does not provide a direct image of the person," the report continues, "but can offer a real-time perspective that helps to highlight the person, whether it's someone who is in imminent danger or someone who is suffering from some other malady."According to a source close to the former president, Reagan is "absolutely thrilled to be able to assist" in a way, particularly to help the GOP candidate, his son, the Christian Science Monitor reported.The publication shared a clip from the former president's appearances and interviews with ABC and Fox News, including a rare video interview with former First Lady Nancy Reagan.Despite the campaign's apparent success with using holograms and other virtual technologies to help with in-person and virtual events, the former president still wants people to see him and be inspired."I know that every once in a while, we can find a way to be able to connect through technology," a source told the Christian Science Monitor.At least one of the recent videos of the former president, according to the report, was recorded before he became seriously ill in August.As his health deteriorated, the former president continued to appear and speak online.On Thursday, President Donald Trump visited a church and addressed the crowd from his helicopter, as he did last month, the Christian Science Monitor reported."That's a big crowd, folks, I love it, because we're back to work, we're back to our lives," President Trump said.In recent weeks, former President Barack Obama was also filmed delivering campaign speeches from his helicopter and appearing as a hologram, as the former Democratic president faced the prospect of facing a serious challenger in the upcoming election.Former President George W. Bush, and his wife Laura, also took to the skies to assist the former president with his re-election campaign in 2020.

| Ndagana MutabaziRwandan surgeons have performed a surgery on six patients from different countries, including the Democratic Republic of Congo.The surgery was performed at the international surgical hospital located in Bukavu in the Rwandese capital of Kigali.The international surgical hospital, which is supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, was established in 2008 by a group of Rwandan doctors to cater to Rwandese surgeons' requirement to operate abroad.Rwandan surgeons have recently operated on nine patients who were brought to the hospital by international surgeons.Some of the patients, who needed a surgery to repair a facial or dental problem, include one patient from the Democratic Republic of Congo, four patients from South Africa, one patient each from the United Kingdom, the United States, and South Africa."They had a case of chronic facial pain, facial cancer, and we performed the surgery with the help of medical team from various countries," said Dr. Patrick Nzalimana, a surgeon from South Africa.One of the patients from the Democratic Republic of Congo, Dr. Fidace, said that he had a very painful operation that he underwent at the International Surgical hospital in Bukavu."I didn't have a pain because I was brought to the hospital with a broken nose and when I was brought to the operation room a doctor took me aside, I saw the doctor and then he gave me a lot of painkillers," he told Nyabagha.Ndagana Mutabazi, who is a surgeon from South Africa said that it was a huge benefit for Rwanda that a lot of Rwandan patients are brought to the country by the international surgeons."We don't have any hospitals here. I think it's a wonderful thing that some people from all over the world came and operated for us. It is very valuable," he told Nyabagha."We are making an effort to make them aware of the importance of getting the best surgeons as early as possible to bring the best service to our patients," the surgeon said.Dr. Tereza, an orthopaedic surgeon from South Africa, said that she was very happy to see Rwanda's surgeons operating overseas and bringing reconstructive surgery to the citizens of the nation."

WASHINGTON (Sputnik) — US Speaker of the House Paul Ryan vowed tax reform by the end of 2017 and a bipartisan panel is set to launch an investigation into the White House’s financial policies.The Washington Post reported on Wednesday that the Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee told colleagues the party’s tax reform plan would be unveiled in early August. It is possible that the panel could hold an announcement as early as August 9.On Thursday morning, Ryan told reporters that lawmakers were focused on the party’s tax policy, but were making progress on tax reform. He mentioned tax reform as a campaign goal.“We’re not just talking about it right now, we’re going to get there,” Ryan said during his weekly press conference.Trump made similar comments during his trip to Europe last week.Trump vowed to push for tax reform during his campaign. On Tuesday, Trump unveiled his tax reform plan. The plan does not include a tax cut for all Americans.The proposal does however eliminate the tax deduction for the mortgage interest paid on homes acquired from financial institutions, and proposes to replace that deduction with a tax credit.

- WNKY.com | Louisville News, Weather and SportsA Nigerian militant group has released nearly 900 kidnapped children as part of a massive amnesty program.Islamic Republic of Nigeria Boko Haram has released most of the 900 schoolchildren it has seized, an aid group says.The children were freed in the largest amnesty granted to hostages held by the group.The release comes in the face of growing criticism of Boko Haram's activities.In a statement on Wednesday, the group said it had released nearly 900 of the children it had kept in captivity over the past 18 months.The children were released "in order to serve the betterment and the education of the whole human family," the militants' Amadou Bakassi faction said.In exchange, the group said it would release several hundred hostages it has kept since last year."We call on the military and the authorities to end this brutal conflict so that all the people of this great and magnificent nation will be safe," the militants' statement said.No date was given for when the mass release will take place.The release comes at a time when Nigeria's army has been battling rebels in the north, while neighboring countries are concerned that the country's security is not improving.Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

across Iran's southeastern provinces of East Azarbaijan, Kerman, Khuzestan and Qom have been affected by heavy rains over the past 24 hours.Also in this area was the governor of Kerman province, Ali Bagherini, and the deputy governor of East Azarbaijan, Mohammad Sadeghi, who died while fleeing from their homes, Rabiei added.Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has expressed his condolences over the WASHINGTON: Former European Trade Commissioner Pierre Moscovici and the United States, an opponent of China in the trade dispute, on Friday said former Swiss government minister Dominique de Vries would be the World Trade Organization´s next director general.The Washington-based WTO said Moscovici, 55, would become director general, followed by de Vries, 53, who served as the WTO´s top trade official in 2013-14."I am very pleased to learn my appointment by the WTO Executive Board has been approved," Moscovici said in a statement."I look forward to working closely with the new leadership and look forward to building on the progress made under the leadership of Glynis Breakwell and Michael Rammell."Breakwell succeeded Tom Kremmer as director general on Aug. 7 and Rammell succeeded Thomas Nilsen, who retired from the WTO in July last year.In his statement, de Vries said the appointment is "an important first step towards fulfilling the mission that the WTO is expected to perform: to resolve disputes by fair and equitable means through multilateral negotiations".The WTO is under scrutiny by the Trump administration. The Trump administration has been working to strengthen its trading relationships with other countries, including traditional trading partners. It has criticized multilateral trade agreements, including the World Trade Organization.

The leader of a Toronto mosque has resigned over the weekend after saying an imam's comment about genital mutilation was an example of "real Islam."Imam Mohamed F. M. Farha — who ran the Toronto Islamic Community Centre — has resigned after saying that he could see "genital mutilation done in the community" due to "real Islam" and "real men" he has seen "hurt" after attending a Muslim funeral.Farha said that he had been talking with a woman "who is the granddaughter of a female family member of a young Muslim man who was killed in the 9/11 attacks" who described how her family member was attacked. Farha added that while the woman was "dealing with the tragedy" in that attack, she had to witness the attack in order to understand what it is to be Muslim in the modern world."[The woman] had said that there was no way for her to have felt safe when she was young, because the Muslim community where she was from does not have female leaders who are trained to talk about those types of issues," Farha said. "I have been talking to her since I was asked to resign by the community on Saturday."Fara told the Canadian Press that he plans to attend a training session on the issue of genital mutilation "as soon as possible."Fara said the decision came about after the Muslim community in the community reached out to him to express their support for him.

BEIJING - China has celebrated the completion of a new bridge linking two major cities that had been gridlocked for decades.The two new bridges, the new Hong Kong-Macau Bridge linking Hong Kong’s Kowloon peninsula to Macau’s neighboring Hong Kong Island, and the new Beijing-Shenyang-Beijing Bridge linking the two capitals, were opened on Monday.Chinese Premier Li Keqiang led the opening ceremony for the bridge projects in Hong Kong and Macau with a ceremony to mark the start of construction work for the first three phases of the Kowloon-Macau bridge.The two new bridges connect Hong Kong with Kowloon, linking the capital cities of the two Asian financial hubs, China’s largest international financial and trade center.The bridge is a critical part of a multi-city, integrated transport system in Hong Kong, an important global city which is also an important hub for trade with mainland China.The main tunnel connecting the two cities will run alongside the current Kowloon-Macao bridge, allowing people to travel between the two cities in half the time, allowing a greater degree of connectivity across the city.It is also the only one-stop bridge connecting both cities.The first three phases of the Hong Kong-Macau bridge will have a total capacity of 4,000 people per hour.The three-phase bridge, which is expected to open by the end of 2017, will cost HK$17 billion ($2.05 billion) and will serve 1.8 million vehicles per day.The second leg of the two-city bridge, which is scheduled to be completed in 2022, will increase capacity to 1.8 million vehicles.

Pakistan's President Asif Ali Zardari said on Tuesday that Pakistan will not stop fighting the Afghan Taliban and other militants until they are eliminated from the region.Speaking in a visit to Islamabad, the Pakistani leader said that his country will give its "full might" to the struggle against Taliban and other militants in Pakistan."Pakistan is committed to bringing peace in Afghanistan and is committed to fighting against terrorism," said the president."We will give our full might to this fight," he said adding that "the world is with Pakistan in this fight and it is Pakistan's fight. We will not stop fighting until we have eradicated Taliban and other militants," he vowed.Talking to Pakistani students, the president said that they will become leaders of the world and are destined to become the most powerful world powers of the 21st century."These youths should learn from their mistakes of the past and work on improving the society," he said.The president said that education would lead to the development of Pakistan, adding that Pakistan had already done well in improving the standard of the youth.

China's Communist Party has celebrated 60 years of achieving the great goal of achieving socialism with Chinese characteristics in practice.In commemoration of the party's anniversary, Xi Jinping, the general secretary of the party, proclaimed that the communist party is committed to realizing the great dream of the party and country.Xi made the remarks on the last day of the celebrations in Beijing.The Chinese Communist Party was founded in 1949 as a result of the failure to unite the military and civilian sectors in the aftermath of World War II.After Mao Zedong's death in 1976, Deng Xiaoping took the reins, and launched an economic reform and liberalization campaign in 1978 to bring a measure of market economy to China.Deng introduced several reforms and liberalized many aspects of China's economy.Mao Zedong was largely regarded as the father of modern China, who introduced a mix of socialism and capitalism and opened China up for the international community.Rival leaders of the Chinese Communist Party like Deng, Hu Yaobang, and Zhu Rongji also played a vital role in the founding of the party.But Xi Jinping is regarded as the most dominant figure of the Chinese Communist Party, the central figure of the whole communist process.This fact of Xi Jinping's success in leading the Communist Party may lead to more development in China, which is a world leader in trade and manufacturing.This report was first published by Global Research.

Police have released the suspected terrorist who inspired the Brussels attacks, to avoid the need of his trial having to be postponed due to a lack of evidence.Mouaaoum Belkacem, an Algerian, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder over the November 19, 2016 attacks in Brussels, Belgium, for which he has always denied having any involvement.Belkacem, who had fled Belgium due to his Algerian status and his alleged past links to a terrorist group, was arrested at the Brussels Zaventem Airport, on his way back to Belgium from Turkey.He is now free from the Belgian judicial system and has been given an alibis, which the police will seek to verify. The government will not prosecute Belkacem since his lack of guilt makes the prosecution inadmissible, because the trial would have to be delayed due to the need for additional evidence to be obtained.Belkacem’s detention was a political decision, according to the Interior Ministry, as the case had been dismissed after prosecutors failed to establish that Belkacem was involved in the attacks which occurred in Brussels, on November 19th, 2016.At the end of October, the Belgian parliament had suspended the trial of the suspect who had inspired the Brussels attacks. However, a week after the suspension of the trial of the Brussels attacker, the same Parliament, had decided to lift the suspension and hold another trial of the suspect who had inspired the Brussels attacks. The same decision was then made by the Belgian judiciary, the same people who suspended the Brussels terror trial and who were in control of the Brussels terrorism trial, without any explanation.Belkacem had reportedly been in contact with the Islamic State group (IS) but not directly with his group which did not take responsibility for the attacks which were planned to be carried out in Brussels but whose ultimate goal was to kill as many people as possible.Following the Belgian terror trial in July, 2016, which was suspended when the Belgian Parliament did not have enough evidence to justify the arrest of the Brussels suspect, the case against him was also dismissed as a result.

in NigeriaThe UN has said that a robust Ebola recovery strategy is needed in Nigeria to help protect citizens from new waves of the virus.A recovery plan in Nigeria is needed now more than ever as a second wave of Ebola is taking hold, according to a new report published by UN officials.The report titled, "Seconding the World to the Fight against Ebola", notes that Nigeria has had an "excellent response" to the first wave of Ebola, as it was able to contain the virus within its borders, but that the country has seen a rapid resurgence of new cases in some regions, particularly in West Africa.In the West African region, the outbreak has taken a particularly deadly toll because it's also the region that has had the most access to vaccines.The UN officials say that in the absence of robust national recovery strategies, and effective vaccine delivery system, the threat of a new wave of the Ebola virus in Nigeria remains considerable.The report says that it would not be sufficient to contain Ebola."Without the right recovery strategy and vaccine distribution systems, it is difficult to imagine a path to containment of the virus for the near future," it says.The new outbreak is especially concerning because of the fact that it has affected communities that had little exposure in the first round, and that the vaccines have not been as robustly rolled out in the region as they have in more established and developed countries.Some African countries, including Nigeria, have a lower immunization rate than other parts of the world.The report says that a vaccination strategy with a strong focus on protecting and protecting communities and communities, and a strategy to prevent the spread of the disease, is necessary if the world is to "turn a corner and reduce the threat of the virus."

On May 6, 2018, Ukraine opened its Eurovision Song Contest with an entry by the Ukrainian rapper "Kerfuffle" and the country's national anthem.Then, the stagehands were unable to use a sound system to play the song properly, and they had to stop the music halfway through. Kerfuffle and the crowd were left frustrated, and the Ukrainian artists were forced to cut off some songs before the competition could begin.Kerfuffle, whose full name is Sergey Khorvakov, is the owner of the Ukrainian club "Dynamika" (Kerfuffle and the Dynamika club) and is a well-known Ukrainian internet activist.On May 7, 2018, Kerfuffle started a petition on Change.org.The petition was signed by more than 10,000 people at the time of this writing.The petition claimed that:the Kyiv stage was not "ready".Kerfuffle was "trying to do his best"Ukraine's Ukrainian artists were denied their right of free expression due to political tensions and political pressure.Kerfuffle had been the only artist in Ukraine to use the stage.Kerfuffle demanded to be released from his contract and allow the Ukrainians to participate in the contest.Kerfuffle demanded a fair trial and was allowed to return.Russia, being the only party from the contest that did not send a participant, refused to participate in the contest.Then, on May 8, 2018, the European Broadcasting Union announced that it had canceled the Ukraine's entry.BBC quoted the Ukrainian broadcaster Rada as saying that:Kerfuffle's participation in the contest was conditional. We could not offer him any alternative.Kerfuffle's team had the right to submit an alternative, and it was refused.The Ukraine's government and the Eurovision organizers were trying to resolve the issue.The parties were unable to agree on what to do. The Ukraine's government refused to release the Kyiv's artist from the contract and the Eurovision organizers refused to grant the Ukraine a waiver of the "compulsory participation requirement" for Kerfuffle's participation in the contest.The Kyiv's stage was not "ready".

WASHINGTON -- The United States has issued what could be a tough warning to Palestinians who may see Israel's move toward full membership in the Jewish state as a green light to push for a more violent Palestinian uprising.U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the administration was concerned that recent developments in Israel's peace process could lead to a Palestinian uprising.In recent days, Israel has signed the agreements to give up much of its pre-1967 borders and give Palestinians some self-rule over the territory of the new state. U.S. officials have cautioned that Hamas, a radical Islamist organization that has ruled Gaza since 2006, could use the deal to cement control over the territory. They say such a move could escalate the situation by empowering Hamas, which currently controls Gaza, as a major player in the Palestinian peace process."Any movement along that line could be dangerous," a U.S. official said, calling the situation a "serious" one.The Israeli government has expressed satisfaction with the agreement, but has said it still wants full membership in the United Nations, and a Palestinian state at peace with Israel.A U.S. official said the U.S. government will be willing to provide economic assistance to Israel and its Jewish neighbors in the absence of a Palestinian state, and would do so to help both Jewish Israelis and Jewish Palestinians who support Israel.

| News | The NationalThe terrorist threat is still very real as is evident in the United States with the recent terrorist attacks in Boston, New York City, and elsewhere. International Security has been a real issue for all countries in the world. Many governments and countries have been struggling to combat the terrorism threat both within their borders and internationally. The terrorism and proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, chemical and biological weapons, are of growing concern to many people of all nations. There is also a concern of terrorist attacks that would cause serious damage to the World Financial Systems. In 2002 there were reports of numerous attacks, especially in the Middle East, Africa and Pakistan that the United Nations believes were the work of terrorist groups. These attacks have been in order to create fear and create unrest within the populations of the affected countries. They also cause political unrest in the countries affected by these attacks. The terrorist attacks do not deter any nation from continuing to fight and keep the world safe. In this paper we will focus on the current terrorist threat and the possible consequences to the countries and governments in relation to it.A terrorist attack, in the form of a bomb, car bomb or other type of improvised explosive device (IED) was used against a diplomatic facility or military installation in a large city in an attempt to kill or injure an official or military personnel. The terrorists want to incite fear and confusion. They want the public to believe that there is a significant risk that officials and military personnel may be killed. The terrorism that targets the world’s financial systems are to make governments and the public fearful and to cause a financial panic. Terrorists do not care that the terrorist attacks are done for the sake of terrorism, they are trying to create fear and confusion that they believe will help bring about change in the nations that were targeted. In the United States a group of terrorist organizations carried out several attacks in the past. The most notable was the Oklahoma City bombing on April 17, 1995 and the 9/11 attacks in New York City on September 11, 2001. In the past year, there have been more than 30 bombings in cities throughout the United States.In the U.S. government, there have been several cases of FBI agents killed by a radical group known as the Black Liberation Army. This radical group is believed to be the group that launched the attacks on the U.S. embassies and other targets in Africa and the Middle East.

Attempt in YemenA wanted wanted poster posted by Interpol has been released in a bid to locate and bring him to justice.The Egyptian-based organisation posted the poster on social media on Thursday, asking the public to seek him out in an attempt to capture and bring him to justice.The poster reads: "On Tuesday, a terrorist group named Islamic State (IS) attempted to kill some foreigners, including Egyptian Copts and Jews. For more information, please contact Interpol's Arabic Service or send a report to our website (info@interpol.com)."The group also urged the media to "cover the incident" and posted the picture of the wanted poster.It's not the first time that Hamas have attempted to send operatives across the world to carry out attacks, with some succumbing to the terrorist group's brutal tactics on their behalf.In 2010, Hamas operatives captured and killed Osama Abu Khattab, a Palestinian leader, in a joint raid with the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, the Islamic Movement in Judea and Samaria (Ismailiya) or the Palestinian Islamic Resistance Movement.Khattab, an al-Qaeda-linked leader, had been accused of being the mastermind of the terrorist attacks carried out against Israel last year.At the time, Ismailiya claimed that Khattab had taken over the responsibility of carrying out attacks against Jews after the assassination of Hamas' top commander Sami al-Hajaj, the group's deputy-secretary.Khattab's murder came after the assassination of Hamas spokesperson Osama Abu-Jihad al-Khatib, another al-Qaeda-affiliated militant, who also had close connections to Al-Qaeda.Hamas' efforts to send assassins across the world have been met with little success.

Less than 100 Days Before East Timor's Statehood Declared — 2002-02-13MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — A day after the Netherlands ended its 30-year military role in East Timor, the prime minister said that his country would seek to ratify a United Nations Security Council resolution establishing a transitional government of the new country.East Timor gained independence from Indonesia in 1975 after a bloody battle against the Indonesian military that took 2,500 lives.The UN Security Council approved the resolution establishing a government in East Timor in December.Speaking to reporters on the front lawn of the Dutch parliament building in the eastern city of Leiden, Prime Minister Erika ten Dole said the resolution had been approved without much drama by the council's five permanent members."We are now the legal owners of East Timor and there is a need to ratify the resolution of the Security Council," she said.Ten Dole said the Netherlands was planning to propose a resolution under Chapter VII of the UN charter that would allow the formation of a new government in East Timor.East Timor will be held by the African Union because a UN mandate remains in force in Timor-Leste, a former Dutch colony. That mandate is due to expire at the end of 2014.The UN has said it needs at least three years of peace and stability to permit a broader, free and fair general election for East Timor to determine the next political entity. The UN has said that a referendum would be held within four to six years, after which a new political entity will be established.Copyright 2002 Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

BEIJING (Sputnik) – The United States and Taiwan are working together to strengthen economic and security relations, said the top U.S. envoy to China, who voiced concern about the situation in the Chinese-claimed island.On Friday, United States Secretary of State Mike Pompeo paid a one-day visit to Taiwan, which has long sought support from Washington."The United States and the people of Taiwan are united to increase economic and security ties between the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan," US Ambassador to China Terry Branstetter said in Taipei after visiting the newly-created National Museum of China, which focuses on the country's civil war and war-era military history.READ MORE: US-Taiwan Relations May 'Worsen' Ahead of 2026 World Cup — China© AP Photo / Kin Cheung U.S. Navy Completes Taiwan Travel Mission for 20th Time in YearThe United States and Taiwan have maintained a long-standing military relationship in a bid to defend themselves against Chinese aggression.In 2013, the former US-Japan Defense Treaty was re-instated following a long-lost period of the two countries' ties.On September 20, 2016, President Obama met with Taiwanese leader Tsai Ing-wen on the sidelines of a BRICS summit in Antalya, where the Chinese president said Washington will support the democratic island. In November 2017, Taiwan's President Tsai held a historic summit with U.S. President Donald Trump, which paved the way for the restoration of the U.S.-Japan Defense Treaty.Earlier on Friday, Pompeo said the US and Taiwan were "tied by a shared destiny," and that China should abide by its commitments under the 1997 Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and the Four Parties to the Taiwan Relations Agreement (FTA)."The United States and Taiwan share a commitment to ensuring peace and prosperity across the Asia-Pacific, which includes Taiwan," the envoy said in a press conference.China regards Taiwan as its own as opposed to democratic countries in the Asia-Pacific, including the United States and Britain. China has repeatedly warned the United States of military action against Taiwan if Beijing were to make unilateral moves towards independence.

in Iowa×  in IowaDES MOINES, Iowa (AP) — A federal judge in Texas blocked U.S. officials from erecting a fence that would separate a swath of Iowa from its largest city.The ruling, issued Tuesday, temporarily bars work on a section of wall in southeast Texas planned under a new law that President Donald Trump is calling his “toughest” at the southern border.Trump’s action was seen as part of a broader effort to shift more of the billions in federal funds available for construction of a wall along the Mexican border to the states, an action that Trump has used to build some of his signature projects since he took office.The ruling from U.S. District Judge Sam Moulton in Corpus Christi is the second temporary nationwide injunction handed down by the judge in the case. On Tuesday, he issued a temporary nationwide stay on work on the Rio Grande Valley of Texas after a similar ruling in Arizona.Texas and Arizona argued that they needed the wall to protect against crime and drug smuggling.The judge said in his ruling that he did not think his order would result in the border being “virtually empty,” a conclusion that was contested by Texas officials.Moulton said he had to weigh whether he could keep the wall in place for the time being while the government appeals the case. It’s possible that the next hearing in the case will not be held in his courtroom.Moulton said he was concerned that parts of the wall would be built to look more like posts and less like the concrete sections of fencing that have been in place in places along the Mexican border.In April, Moulton ordered that parts of a border fence in eastern New Mexico must be taken down and that a new type of mesh barrier — one made of steel — be used. In his ruling Tuesday, Moulton stopped short of ordering the entire fence, but he noted that it could include some parts of it.Trump has pledged to construct 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) of wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and to build new sections where existing walls fall short. Moulton’s decision makes it possible that some of the construction will be done in Texas, where new barriers are not permitted.

Former Haitian dictator Jovenel Moïse is reportedly looking to stand in the next presidential election, said the son of the ex-president who's now living in Florida.The son, Laurent Duvernay-Tardif, made the comments in an interview with NBC Miami radio's "The Dave Campbell Show" posted to the website The Miami Herald."I think he is thinking about it," said Laurent."I think the question is whether he knows it and is ready to take the steps necessary to become an elected leader."Laurent said that he thinks he has a "lot of respect" for Moïse and a "good working relationship" with his ex-president father.In a follow-up interview with the Miami Herald on the same day, Laurent said that he thinks Moïse is "a good person, he's a good man. I think his father made a mistake when he gave away that power. The people were upset, that's what led to the change."But he noted that "he was a bad man and it's not the same man that I'm used to."And he admitted to the Herald that he thinks Moïse's power could be used to "help the people" even if he doesn't win a fifth term.He said that he's been keeping an eye on Moïse's health and that "everything I know about my dad is positive."Asked about allegations that Moïse sought to get himself elected president in the 2016 election, Laurent said: "I think there was some electioneering but I don't believe there was a real election."He noted that Moïse had said that he wanted to be president of Haiti, not of Haiti."If Moïse had done that, the people would have been in favor of his candidacy," said Laurent. "The people were not behind Moïse during his term and the Haitian people were not behind him during his second term."Laurent said he thinks the former dictator has "a lot of things he'd like to do.""

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson arrives to meet with Cuban President Raul Castro at a government facility in Havana, Cuba, Thursday, July 27, 2017. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)HAVANA (AP) — The Latest on developments in Cuba (all times local):11:50 a.m.U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has signaled that tough new measures against Cuba’s communist government will come from the Trump administration.Addressing an American delegation in Havana, Tillerson said the Obama administration has taken a “relatively easy line” with Havana. He said a new government is taking office and the U.S. wants a new approach that “has not been given at all.”Tillerson’s remarks Tuesday before an estimated 500 Cuban business leaders were intended to signal his policy shift from the Obama administration. It also comes on the same day as the president is holding a joint U.S.-Russia summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin.___11:20 a.m.U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says that President Donald Trump’s tough approach to Cuba will be an example for the future, not just for his administration.Tillerson said Tuesday after meeting with Cuban business leaders in Havana that Trump would continue his predecessor’s policy of “maintaining patience” and building up support for new reforms.Tillerson said he had invited top Cuban officials to visit Washington soon to see how the country can be improved.He says that under Obama, the U.S. gave “relatively easy lines of communication” to Cuba and tried to encourage dialogue.Tillerson did not elaborate on what steps Trump’s administration could take to promote reform.___11:10 a.m.The White House is backing the Cuba plan promoted by U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson for developing economic ties with the communist government.The White House tweeted on Tuesday that “both @senateflorida & @repmarcobama have made it clear that Cuba must not get away with this and we will stand by our friends.”

Marlene Kitzhaber: We’re on the cusp of another big-picture housing policy policyOn the cusp of a housing policy.The president and his wife have not missed a chance to announce a policy — often a big one — during his tenure in office.In May 2016, at the urging of the White House and its think tank, we launched a national housing policy survey for households to make recommendations for the president on how to improve housing for everyone in our country.We included housing as a "big issue" in the survey, along with education, the state of our infrastructure, the environment, and the state of the economy.

In the early days of Donald Trump's business life, he was mostly a real estate developer, with his real estate projects operating mostly in countries like Canada and Switzerland. But then he decided to use his connections as a real estate developer to help him get into politics with a "Trump Organization" and to build a presidential campaign that is currently embroiled in controversy.There are, of course, some caveats to this whole situation. Trump may not be as wealthy as he claims, and he has been accused of conflicts of interest with his business empire. But it's hard to deny that he's successfully built his brand around the idea of a Trump in the White House and a Trump presidency.Ivanka Trump has always been the president's daughter-in-law, but she has found her place in the White House not merely through serving as a political pawn, but by building the Trump brand and creating the political and financial benefits her family and business has found.While Trump is no longer in the public eye, the Trump family's business has remained in business and continues to grow.While the Trump family's business is still doing well, it has managed to avoid scandals like those involving her father, who was accused of mistreating women, or her brother, who was accused of taking money from foreign governments without their permission. This is largely thanks to the Trump brand, which is being built on the success and goodwill her family has managed to create with a loyal following."I know people think the Trump family is corrupt," Ivanka Trump said recently during a discussion about women and leadership with the Women's Business Council of New York City. "I hope they believe that because the fact is the Trump family's businesses are doing really well. They are growing, and not just in the fashion industry."The New York Times reported in November 2017 that the Trump Organization, through Ivanka Trump's brand, was making a profit of $80 million in the first four quarters of 2017. Ivanka's father Donald Trump is still in office, but his son Eric and daughter Ivanka still manage the Trump brand. Donald Trump's sister, Mary Trump, is an administrator of the Trump Foundation.But it's unlikely that the Trump family's business will ever be as profitable as the Trump brand.

Zimbabwe President Emmerson Mnangagwa. Photo: Daily NewsThe government has indicated it will meet President Emmerson Mnangagwa to discuss the political, security and economic situation in Zimbabwe.“I have instructed my security commanders to make plans to attend a meeting with President Mnangagwa to talk about the political, security and economic situation of Zimbabwe,” Vice President Constantino Chiwenga said on Monday.On Tuesday, the Zimbabwe Defence Forces said it would discuss with Chiwenga the security situation in the country.Zimbabwe Defence Forces Chief of Staff General Philip Jappie told a newspaper in Harare that ZDF soldiers were deployed at major points of the country including some camps and strategic points and had taken over.“They are in positions that they will not let any other country deploy their troops,” he said, adding that they would be withdrawn once peace has restored in the country.The statement came as the government has been trying to placate the political leaders. The army announced it had opened talks with the country’s political leaders to end the situation.The political leadership has however disputed the statement.Mnangagwa will be expected to provide a solution to the political deadlock, particularly the issues on leadership, security and political stability in the country.The political crisis, which has seen several people killed over the last two weeks, has resulted in a power struggle in the country as several political actors have been left out of the talks with the military leaders.

Mariya Tymoshenko is not in the Ukrainian government, nor is she at the current meeting between the leaders of Ukraine, the United States, and Russia in Minsk. That doesn’t make her any less important to Ukraine, however.The fact that Tymoshenko is not there has a lot to do with how this week's talks are playing out. If the leaders of Ukraine and the United States don't get along, what good are the talks they have?The talks between Ukraine and the United States have been going on since the beginning of January. And for two weeks now, the United States has been holding talks with Russian counterparts as well.Both sides have been looking for solutions to the crisis. But the talks have been held behind closed doors, and there are rumors that the United States has given up on its demand to get a peace deal by the end of April.So far there has been a lot of positive talk. But all of that is all about how the talks will be conducted.On Monday, a statement was issued by the Foreign Ministers of the four countries—Ukraine, the United States, Russia, and Britain. They called for an immediate ceasefire and talks to begin immediately.If peace talks can't be held in the next few days, if they cannot be arranged in time before the end of the month, then what chance do the talks have now? And this does not mean that the talks won't work. But there's no real point in announcing that.There is no indication what those talks might entail. It's not clear what kind of peace plan the United States might be willing to accept. And there is no sign the United States has any real plan of its own.This week's talks have been taking place behind closed doors and behind the scenes. If they succeed, then everything should be fine. But at this point, the question is, what hope do the talks have?This is a story that's been playing out for weeks. And in the past two weeks there has been a lot of hope, especially when the talks were taking place behind closed doors.But then the talks were halted, and this was followed by another delay. And so on.

Post After AttacksIslam Times - Qatar pulled all its troops from its Djibouti-Eritrea border post after attacks on the soldiers.The troops were withdrawn from the Djibouti-Eritrea border post in Al Fula region after a wave of attacks. On Tuesday, three soldiers were killed and five others were injured in an attack by suspected militants. The Qatar-Eritrea border post is located in Al Fula village.Al Fula is also the headquarters of the Qatari border guards and it is the only frontier crossing between the two countries. Qatar is also the only country that allows Qatari troops to transit through its borders.Qatar’s foreign affairs minister, Mohammed Mohammed Al-Thani, is on a two-day visit to Djibouti. Mohammed said in an interview with Djiboutian radio that Qatar and Djibouti are working to improve security and stability in their common region.

in Time for School ClosingBlack Lives Matter flags have returned to a Vermont school flagpole.At the end of September, some signs with the black flag of Black Lives Matter (BLM) started showing up at schools all over the state.

as Taliban Stalemate In AfghanistanTaliban fighters fire mortar rounds at the general population during a government airstrike in Kandahar, Afghanistan August 9, 2019. REUTERS/Danish SiddiquiISLAMABAD (Reuters) - At least 45 people were killed in suicide bombings across Pakistan on Wednesday, as the Taliban held the same ground as they had during a 10-day offensive in Afghanistan last month.Police said the casualties in the suicide bombings in the eastern city of Lahore were mainly civilians but that the military was investigating a suicide attack in the northern city of Quetta, which killed four soldiers.The military was still struggling to dislodge fighters hiding inside a hospital in the Pakistani city of Peshawar on Wednesday, after the Taliban stormed a hospital and killed eight people on Tuesday, in what is seen as another sign of the growing strength of the Taliban on the battlefield.Wednesday's attacks were in addition to three in a single day that hit Lahore the previous day, in which a suicide bomber killed five people.One senior military official and one security official said the military had captured scores of Taliban fighters from areas that had fallen to the insurgents, although it was unclear if they were among the 45 killed.The senior military official said the military had also captured Taliban fighters from areas in North Waziristan, in the country's remote northwestern border region, adding that the military had also detained two Taliban fighters from South Waziristan.In a separate incident in the same border area on Wednesday, a Taliban suicide bomber targeted a government vehicle, which killed six members of government security forces. Two Taliban fighters also died in the attack, a senior security official said.In a statement, the Taliban said it had killed at least 27 security forces in the attack in Waziristan.Two people were killed and 40 injured in attacks carried out by the Taliban in South Waziristan, police said.The Taliban claimed responsibility for at least five attacks that targeted police across South Waziristan province in the past few days, but it was not clear if any of the militants involved was from the group.

WASHINGTON — President Obama was sworn in as the 39th president of the United States Wednesday evening at the U.S. Capitol.Obama was sworn in at 7:27 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time (10:27 P.M. Central) via the Internet.Obama, the son of a former Illinois state senator, won a historic upset victory against Mitt Romney in the presidential election, claiming a majority of the popular vote.The president delivered a brief speech that was streamed live on the Internet.“We are a nation divided, a nation that is bitterly divided on matters of race, a nation that seems to be sliding toward a second civil war,” Obama said.“We are a nation that believes that every single person in America, regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, economic background, religion — every single one of us — should be treated as if they had nothing else to lose but their lives, their dignity, and everything they have to win,” he said.Obama took over as president in January 2009 after he had won the election by less than two points of President George W. Bush.Obama’s four years have seen a steady recovery in the U.S. economy and the decline of terrorism.A report released today by the Federal Reserve says the U.S. has regained its manufacturing-driven growth following a recession that started in December 2007 and was only officially declared over in June 2009.The report notes that the nation had added 2.7 million private sector jobs since 2007 and a further 1.6 million in 2012.The economy is now experiencing a second period of recovery.“All indications are that this recovery continues to be strong and that it will become a virtuous circle,” President Obama said.President Obama also signed eight executive orders during his first 100 days in office. Among them:“We will continue to invest in science, in infrastructure. We will make sure that every child in America gets a decent education, and that every single child can succeed in this country.”“We’ll make sure that every American has access to affordable health insurance, and that every American can afford the prescription drugs they need, and that every American has access to quality, affordable college education.”“

, Security in AfghanistanThe United Nations on Monday warned that human rights are essential to peace and security in Afghanistan, despite the ongoing violence.The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said that "despite the ongoing conflict, the human rights of the civilian population are a priority" for the country, and that the international community's continued engagement is needed to help."Despite the continued conflict, the human rights of the civilian population are a priority for Afghanistan. The protection and protection of civilians is especially important in light of the continuing conflict, ongoing human rights violations, and the threat of further violence," the OCHA added."Human rights are also essential in facilitating the safe, voluntary and dignified repatriation of Afghan nationals and other foreigners stranded in the country. The safe, voluntary, dignified, return of Afghan nationals and other foreigners, including women and children, is one of the key tasks to be done," the UN added.Despite the ongoing conflict and threats from further violence, the humanitarian community has made great strides in providing humanitarian assistance to the country, UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore told the annual G7 summit."Human rights are the basis of our global stability. They are essential to international security. And we can never give up these values, whether it is the right to a decent education, safe and affordable water supply, or the right to life," she stressed in her opening remarks, according to a UN News Service report.Fore also stressed that "all efforts to strengthen national institutions to tackle root causes of conflict and to enable a lasting reduction of violence" are absolutely essential."This means prioritising peace and reconciliation, development, development finance, education, human rights and gender equality, climate change, and sustainable development," Fore said."As a result, Afghanistan is now among the countries where the greatest growth in the last 15 years has come from," said Fore.The latest UN figures show that in 2015, the United Nations distributed $9.8 billion in humanitarian assistance and delivered $6.3 billion of it, and another $8.2 billion were collected.The UN also said that in the same year, it delivered $1 billion in emergency medical supplies and delivered more than 4 million tons of relief material, including 2.4 million tons of rice, 8.4 million blankets, 2 million masks and 2 million vaccines.

Photo Credit: Wikimedia, CC-BY 4.0New York (PIX11) — American lawmakers Tuesday called for stiffer sanctions against Russia, following a slew of recent events that have shaken the U.S.-Russia relationship, especially over Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.Advertisement“To be sure, the United States has been the world leader in defense of its democratic ideals,” U.S. Rep. Eliot Engel told Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, during a closed meeting Monday on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly, as reported by Fox News.Engel, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, has been leading calls in the U.S. House of Representatives for tougher sanctions against Russia, and said that the U.S. and Russia should step up the rhetoric during their upcoming meetings in New York.“It is time for the United States and Russia to step up their rhetoric and threats in regard to international security,” he said, according to the AP.President Donald Trump has yet to comment on the matter, though he has previously been outspoken about the need for a tougher response to Russia.The meeting between Putin and Engel came amid a slew of other high-level meetings between U.S. and Russian officials. In a separate meeting, Trump announced his intention to hold a meeting with Putin and other leaders during the annual gathering of the General Assembly in New York.Trump made the announcement after meeting other world leaders Monday in New York, where he reaffirmed his commitment to U.S.-led international organizations, including NATO, and urged them to work on countering North Korea.The North Korea summit has been put on hold, and the summit scheduled for November 9 in Singapore between Trump and Kim Jong Un will now take place next month, Trump said.“We’ll see if we can get that done,” he said, according to AP. “It’s a big one. It’s a big deal. It’s a big challenge.”

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina — Argentine authorities carried out raids at the homes of fugitive businessman Carlos Alberto Fernandez, his former secretary of his ruling party, on Thursday.Fernandez, who also served as head of state during the country's 1980-1984 armed confrontation with leftist rebels, has been on the run since he fled his home in Buenos Aires in January 2019."Argentine police executed a warrant issued by a magistrate, and seized property in Boca Junctions," the official Twitter account of Interior Minister Ricardo Alarcon said. "The authorities are looking for weapons."Alarcon later posted a photo of himself on Twitter with Fernandez.Fernandez's former secretary of state, Julio De Vido, said in a tweet that the "arrest warrant was served for his arrest."Fernandez is the architect of the social program that was the political cornerstone of President Alberto Fernández's government during the 1980s — but which has become a bone of contention between the two men.Fernandez was forced from power in 1986 after the military coup that ended Argentina's 27-year rule.The economy is now doing better under Fernández than it did when he took office, but the political system is divided on his "Fernandezism," and he now faces another test as he faces opposition from the same groups who drove him out of power during the civil war.

on MondayA meeting between the Palestinian leadership and the Middle East Quartet on Monday in Lisbon will highlight an important issue for Israel – the Palestinian Authority’s refusal to halt its policies toward the Jewish people.The visit is coming at a critical juncture for Israel’s security in light of the violent riots that broke out in Jerusalem in recent days over the contested al-Aqsa Mosque, and clashes and riots throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip that followed. The Palestinian Authority (PA) maintains full control of al-Aqsa and other holy places on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, and has declared that it is the sole custodian of the al-Aqsa compound and all other al-Aqsa sites in East Jerusalem. That includes al-Aqsa itself.

Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine on March 16, 2014; this is the third time that Russia has annexed eastern Ukraine from a country (and only second time from Russia).Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine on March 16, 2014; this is the third time that Russia has annexed eastern Ukraine from a country (and only second time from Russia).This video from Novaya Gazeta, Ukraine's state-run news agency, shows the convoy of trucks heading out to the Russian border:This video from Novaya Gazeta, Ukraine's state-run news agency, shows the convoy of trucks heading out to the Russian border:As Russian security forces continued to clear land, the separatists drove in with the aid of Ukrainian military vehicles:Russia's military and military-technical aid has been an important part of the war that has raged in Eastern Ukraine between government forces and pro-Russia separatist forces.The war is far from over. The ongoing fighting has forced nearly 1.5 million people to leave their homes, and Russia has pledged a military presence in the region that is likely to escalate. Ukraine, however, has been largely unaffected by Russian military hardware; the vast majority of Ukraine's population lives in the southern region of the country, far from areas affected by the war, and Russia's military presence has largely been limited to bases and bases near eastern Ukraine.For the rebels who control eastern Ukraine, Russia's military aid has been an important part of the war that has raged in Eastern Ukraine between government forces and pro-Russia separatist forces. The rebels have relied on the support of Russian-backed, Ukrainian army fighters, whose numbers and weaponry vary widely from place to place. Ukraine's military and military-technical aid has been an important part of the war that has raged in Eastern Ukraine between government forces and pro-Russia separatist forces. The war is far from over. The ongoing fighting has forced nearly 1.5 million people to leave their homes, and Russia has pledged a military presence in the region that is likely to escalate.

An investigative journalist in the central Mexican state of Veracruz was shot dead and a suspect is now in custody, local media reported on Monday.Molvi Manuel Gaviria was killed in a shooting incident in the town of Coimbatore in the state's central highlands, according to reports from local media.Gaviria was investigating alleged drug dealers in his neighborhood.Video from the scene showed an old man lying on the ground with a gunshot wound to his abdomen. A male suspect was later arrested. The video also showed a group of residents in the street, who were not involved in the investigation but were watching from the windows.Several other people have already been detained, including two government officials.The crime took place while one of the Mexican president's son was being transported for medical treatment in another part of the state.President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who is running for a second term in elections scheduled for July 1, called for a calm in the country, a place where there is no violence "as a deterrent."

The same survey shows many Venezuelans are also opposed to the constitution. They argue the document has been the cause of the political conflict in the country.According to a new poll, about 85 percent of Venezuelans want the Venezuelan Constitution Revision Committee to make changes to the document.The survey, conducted between November 9 and November 14, polled 4,000 people through an interactive digital tool that enables a voter to rank issues in a list.The document, which was written in 1983, is the fourth to the eighth in the country's 27-year constitution. However, it was ratified in 1994 and has been amended several times since.In 2011, a court ordered that some laws should not have been ratified, including a law on the country's Constitution.Some 70,000 protesters in Caracas in 2012 called for the government to remove certain articles of the constitution, which they argued were unconstitutional because they did not follow certain rules.Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, whose father was the president for 15 years before leaving in 1981, is seeking to replace the Constitution. He has repeatedly called for a referendum.But the country's Supreme Court has dismissed calls for a new referendum in the past, citing the nation's political crisis.Many Venezuelans feel that the constitution, which was ratified in 1974, has not been implemented well.Many blame the country's crisis, which includes high inflation, food shortages and rampant crime, on the document.Most also believe the country is heading for a civil war.This is not the first time an online poll has revealed Venezuelans' attitudes on the constitution.An online poll conducted by the government in November 2013 found that about 75 percent of Venezuelans believe the constitution is "unbalanced," while another 21 percent said it is "balanced."

(Image: AFP/Getty)The new populist, illiberal Europe is beginning to resemble the US and Western Europe of the 1930s, but without the economic and political stability. Europe’s leaders may finally be listening.The rise of “populist movements” – far-right parties, nationalists, nationalists, and some liberal conservatives – across Europe in recent years has been alarming to European leaders. Some of them fear they are moving toward illiberalism and may become more difficult to control.The new populist, illiberal Europe is beginning to resemble the US and Western Europe of the 1930s, but without the economic and political stability. Europe’s leaders may finally be listening.One of the key elements of illiberalism is the use of the legal system to prevent people from exercising democracy. It may be seen as the new tyranny of the masses. In the United States during the 1920s, popular movements like the League of Labor forced the government to provide better civil rights, and helped turn the nation from a conservative to a progressive nation. It is often thought that the Great Depression was caused by the excesses of the New Deal.
