In Europe, illiberal governments were able to take advantage of the economic dislocation of the Great Depression to prevent political debate on important issues.In the last three years, Europe’s populist and illiberal movements have moved beyond the traditional boundaries of traditional political alliances. Now they are challenging not only the traditional parties but also the political institutions of the European Union.For example, European leaders reacted furiously to a recent report from French President Emmanuel Macron, who made a speech to an audience of the European Parliament denouncing racism and anti-Semitism in Europe. Macron, a former investment banker, is making an attempt to rebrand the movement’s aims by portraying himself as a champion of liberal values. He is right: his report found that many of Europe’s anti-immigrant parties were led by individuals with questionable or even dubious backgrounds and many of them shared little if any of Europe’s liberal values.

, Not the Evidence.Liberian politician and senator-elect Sirleaf J. Taylor II recently expressed that the government should consider making some exceptions on criminal charges against her for actions that occurred prior to the date of the presidential election.The senator-elect said President George Manneh Weah, who was officially inaugurated as Liberia's 14th president on Tuesday, "remains in place" and "is not going anywhere soon," meaning that he continues to hold the post even after Taylor leaves the country.Weah had also asked President Donald Trump to pardon former Liberian leader Charles Taylor.But in what has been perceived as a direct challenge to President Weah, Taylor's daughter and the attorney for the former Liberian rebel leader told CNN Thursday that the Taylor family is not expecting President Trump to pardon her father anytime soon.The younger Taylor had accused the US president of being "unfit to lead" and "unprepared" when he asked him, citing "all sorts of nonsense" to be considered for a presidential pardon.The elder Taylor was shot and killed in 2006 by rebels who had infiltrated the country as an international peacekeeping force for the international community's backing of the long-stalled peace process.In October 2016, his daughter Taylor J. called President Trump, then-candidate Trump, a "disastrous leader" in an interview with "60 Minutes."Taylor family lawyer and attorney-at-law Joseph Taylor told CNN in an exclusive interview that the decision to pursue criminal charges against her client will not deter him from pursuing justice.In an interview with CNN on Thursday, Joseph Taylor described President Weah as "a good man" but "a very, very, very bad leader."Taylor said that President Weah was "unprepared" and was "not equipped" for the challenges of running Liberia, including corruption.In 2016, George Manneh Weah became Liberia's 14th president, replacing former Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, who died last February after more than six years in office.Sirleaf, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, was elected president of Liberia in 2011 on the third place in the country's multi-party system, after two-term presidential winner Charles Taylor.Taylor fled Liberia to the United States in 1999 and was arrested in 2011 at the request of Liberia, the International Criminal Court, and the UN Security Council.

A new study by the Armed Conflict Project has revealed a key role played by traditional systems for conflict resolution in the troubled Middle East: the 'tribal system.'The study, published in The Lancet, reports that it is tribes in the Middle East who are best able to engage in conflict resolution. The study explains that the tribes are often more engaged, and more committed, to finding a resolution than are government officials.The analysis, based on interviews with local tribes, also found that in some instances, individuals were willing to kill each other to make a peace agreement, with tribal elders able to be relied upon to assist this work.In a recent speech to the American Institute for International Studies in Washington, D.C., U.S. President Barack Obama said,"A lot of things that have happened in the United States over the last couple decades, particularly in the post-Cold War era, can be traced back to a failure to recognize and honor a tradition of cooperation among our people—a tradition of the collective defense in times of conflict. And as a nation, we're not even really doing that today, and it's not just in places where we've engaged in civil wars; our policies toward the Iraqi people are a good example."There are four possible forms of the tribal system. They range from traditional tribal leadership to an elaborate form of central government with a military, police, and police agencies and courts.In Yemen's conflict, tribal leaders are often in control of the military and security sectors, and have power through the ability to exert influence through their influence within central authorities.In Afghanistan, there is a tradition of tribalism associated with political authority among men of one tribe that has a different form in other areas. For example, Afghan tribes are mostly tribal leaders, with the exception of a few prominent women.Another tradition in Arab countries that is common in the Middle East is the "tribal system," which encompasses the leadership of the political class and military. According to the report, the leader of the most influential tribe in Yemen, Abu Israil, is also a tribal leader, and tribal leaders are also involved in political decision-making, as the leaders and the political system tend to dole out power based on tribal lines.The research team notes that the 'tribal system' can be effective in a conflict. It can allow people to avoid killing each other, and thus avoid major humanitarian suffering.

Britain's chief counterterror officer released his version of the London Bridge terror attack on Tuesday."What we do know is that a number of the individuals who are currently being interviewed by counterterrorism officers were part of an extended, ongoing plan to execute terror attacks in the country," Chief Constable Bernard Hogan-Howe said.Hogan-Howe has said the UK Security Service received information indicating the attack was "planned and supported by individuals with previous convictions, convicted of terror-related offenses and with a history of extremism in the past."That's a reference to the fact that one of the suspects, Usman Khan, was a failed extremist who had been convicted of preparing to aid terrorists but was allowed to join the Army Reserve.There are other suspects who are being interrogated, such as one who is being questioned under the names of Khalid Masood, Khurram Butt, Yacqub Khan, and Khurram Raza Rizvi.Butt and Khan were not yet arrested, but had been identified on social media as among those being investigated by counterterrorism officers.Butt and Rizvi were among those who were being questioned, and the identity of the other man arrested, Shahid Amjad Shah, remains unknown."The man arrested at the scene [at London Bridge] is one of 11 people we're still trying to identify, which is something I can't talk about," Hogan-Howe said. "When I do, I'll explain how we can't identify anyone, but I can tell you we've been able to identify some more suspects, with some of whom we've been in touch and through whom we've been able to get more information."Khurram Raza RizviA second police officer said the other arrests were carried out by security forces.It's not yet known if they are the same two men from the first video released by the Government. The same people were identified using facial recognition software, and authorities believe they were in the same location at the time the attack occurred.The second video released by the Government, taken 30 minutes after the attacks, shows men who appear to be part of the "lone wolf" element of the attacks.

At least 100 people were arrested in Indonesia's Papua province on Sunday amid a day of demonstrations against the government's planned deployment of military personnel.Thousands of students, mostly students of public university in the central city of Jayapura, protested the deployment on Sunday.Police fired tear gas at the protesters and the demonstrators threw stones at police, triggering clashes in the capital Jayapura.One woman was reported dead and several people, including seven police officers, were injured in the protests.Protests have flared up repeatedly in West Papua, the easternmost region of the country, since early June after West Papuan students and activists called for an independence vote.The Indonesian government has rejected the request for independence and said it was only interested in improving the situation in the region, including addressing complaints from West Papuan people that the Indonesian government has ignored them.The United Nations has expressed concern over the violence, with Secretary General Antonio Guterres calling it "unacceptable."

byThe leaders of Britain, France and Germany say they are putting aside political differences and agree to find common ground when it comes to economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.European Union leaders called in a video conference to discuss cooperation and recovery from the crisis, but didn't provide details on what they will agree on next.Britain and France agreed last week to offer support to the EU in exchange for more access to markets."We have overcome the greatest crisis in our history and I can tell you that today we stand on the brink of a better future for Europe," said French President Emmanuel Macron at the start of the meeting.Macron was followed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel who also praised "our solidarity" and urged leaders "to strengthen it more" in the face of the economic crisis.Merkel also urged a "bold but fair" plan that would be "in keeping" with European values of democratic values, free markets and free societies.A joint communique from the leaders will be issued later Monday.The leaders praised the "solidarity" and "solidarity in action" that has been displayed throughout the crisis in the bloc. They also spoke about the "responsibility" to strengthen cohesion through measures like joint recovery plans for the EU's 27 member states."We can and should take up the task of ensuring a swift and successful vaccination, that we must take together," Merkel said.Macron told his European counterparts he wanted a "Europe of hope" after the crisis."We know that the next steps are going to be in our hands and we will have to fight the next battle on the same footing," he said.The leaders also discussed the digital transition in the "ever-changing and interconnected world.""

China sent a second vessel Sunday to conduct maritime exercises with the Philippines, as Beijing and the Southeast Asian nation fight for control over an international seas near the disputed South China Sea.Two Chinese vessels arrived from nearby Zhanjiang province aboard three fishing boats at about 8:30 p.m., the Philippines Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana announced on Twitter. He said the vessels had conducted drills with the Philippine Coast Guard.Tensions between the two neighbors rose with several skirmishes this year, including the arrest of a Chinese sailor, a Filipino crew member of the Chinese fishing vessel, and a Filipino navy officer who was on his way back to the Philippines when the incident occurred.China denied the allegations, saying it was taking a necessary action in response to a provocation. China did not respond to questions from a Philippine foreign ministry official after the drills.The maneuvers came on a holiday in the Philippines when Chinese fishing boats normally have no trouble operating in the contested waters. The Philippines has been trying to push back more than a dozen Chinese fishing boats that repeatedly enter its waters for search-and-rescue operations.The U.S. government has accused China of deploying at least five vessels near the Philippine naval base in the Spratly Islands, and at least one of them fired warning shots at a Philippine vessel in international waters last month.China responded that it fired only warning shots to prevent a collision, and denied it sent any boats into Filipino waters.China claims almost all the South China Sea, though Manila claims nearly all the waters.

BRUTAL Bangladesh killings raise concerns about secular traditions, but few Bangladeshis have openly talked about their experiences on such a scale.More than 40 people were killed in a series of attacks in Dhaka on Friday, and hundreds more wounded, amid fears over a looming Islamic State insurgency in a country the U.S. says could be its next target.Police have arrested a leader of the suspected attack, identified as Mohammed Kamal Chowdhury. Dhaka residents say his father, also named as Chowdhury, was one of those killed.While many Bangladeshis have openly talked about losing relatives to religious violence – such as the 1982 massacre that drove hundreds of thousands from India’s eastern border – few have shared experiences in the same way.“I know many people who have lost people, but I think they keep it inside and don’t talk about it,” said Zareed Rahman, a Dhaka resident and a former politician.In a recent interview on Bangladesh’s TV, he said that his uncle was killed in 1990. “He was a priest, but he was also killed. I remember his face. You can see his face and hair,” Rahman said, recounting his uncle’s fate as the priest.“I always keep the incident inside and keep it away from my family,” he told the anchor on Friday, and then asked “when are we going to face Islamic extremism and terrorism?”The interview prompted a flood of questions on how Bangladeshis could protect themselves, and on the country’s “soft” image and how such killings could harm the country.“No one should be afraid of Bangladesh,” said the anchor. “Let’s bring out the best in each other.”The anchor also expressed optimism about Bangladesh’s chances of becoming a leader in the regional peace dialogue, something Rahman hoped would happen as soon as possible.But while the anchors’ hope appears to be tempered by the reality, many Bangladeshis – including ordinary, law-abiding citizens – are now openly talking about their experience of violence from religion and extremism, despite the country’s strong tradition of tolerance, respect for civil liberties and an independent judiciary.“

, as FTSE 100 Futures Jump on Back of NewsGreece’s deal to slash its debt by more than a third was hailed as a major breakthrough, as a stock market futures spike on news of a potential deal.There was immediate celebration among markets, with Asian shares falling on profit-taking in recent days following gains in the US.Bonds yields surged in Spain after Moody’s revised the country’s rating outlook to positive from negative.A spokesman for Greece’s Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said his country would not return to a fiscal “halting” programme but would implement the austerity programme and reforms demanded of the lenders.He also dismissed the idea that the new Greek government could be formed without the help of the country’s bailout creditors as “far-fetched”.

NominationThe Senate will begin its second day of debate on the nomination of Judge Sonia Sotomayor to become the next Supreme Court justice, after a long day of questions in which the Republicans took advantage of the Democrats' poor performances in the first full day of hearings. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) questioned the nominee on the definition of judicial activism, and asked whether she had spoken to the Boston Tea Party, and whether her father had worked as a barber in a public housing project. Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) asked about the "prejudice" of President Obama, his wife Michelle, and his daughters Malia, 13, and Sasha, 11, referring to the former president's family vacation to Martha's Vineyard in 2012. Sotomayor's answers to his questions will likely be read as the first indications of how her supporters and detractors will interpret her. In response to a question from Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), Sotomayor responded that the Obama administration has violated the Constitution's pledge to be a "charity" in the form of the government's welfare programs, and that "it is shameful and wrong to reward political cronies by expanding their welfare rolls." Asked by Paul if he would vote for Sotomayor for the Supreme Court, the nominee said that she would. Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), who is considered the most likely Republican to vote against Sotomayor, was absent in the hearing.

, Likely to Make LandfallA weak tropical storm called Arlene is expected to hit the northern Caribbean islands of Belize, Guatemala and Honduras on Monday before moving onto Central America late on Monday.Arlene was downgraded to a tropical storm on Sunday but was still expected to bring strong winds, heavy rainfall and gusts of up to 75 mph (120 kph) to some areas.The U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Sunday that the storm was a "modest disturbance in the Eastern Caribbean Sea that has a 20 percent chance of becoming a tropical depression in the next five days."It warned of "potential for life-threatening flash flooding and landslides throughout the region. Significant damage is possible to agricultural and residential sites."

When the President took office, he quickly approved a plan that would create a new option for students to have a small refundable tax credit, a first-time homebuyer loan, and a student-related refinancing option called "direct loan" which makes a student loan more affordable to the borrower.The move seemed to have the desired effect. Some college-bound students chose to attend a "better" school because they could get a better education.But now that some schools have taken steps to ease the path for paying off student loans, things are getting a little strange.According to CNBC, now that a law has been passed to allow students to "refinance" their student loans, schools are starting to take an increasingly hands-on approach in making sure that all students are paying their loans every day, even if they fail to complete classes. That includes offering students a "free" college education from the schools in their home states.But as the law is changing, schools are starting to create more complicated programs for the families of college-bound students. These kids are being forced out of their home states so that their families can attend institutions of higher education, even if they don't really need to attend because the schools in their states are so much better than the ones they'd have to attend to attend to them.The latest controversy arose in Utah, where one of the schools is offering this type of tuition-reduction package to parents of students who don't make it into the schools they want:Under the program, if a student does not graduate from at least one of the schools that meet the criteria, their parents are automatically enrolled in the program and receive tuition remission, but they will still need to work to cover the costs of attending the schools."I don't want to go to Utah now, I really don't, but they've got a program that they think it might be best for our daughter," said Laura Wilson, the mother of a high school student."

US Army personnel from Forward Operating Base Fingah in Afghanistan's Kunduz province take cover after a drone attack, on October 20, 2001. / AFP / Rahmatullah SayeedUS troops have shifted from a military focus on "winning" against the Taliban and al-Qaeda to a more limited approach involving strikes on al-Qaeda figures in Afghanistan, former generals say.Advertising Read moreThe strategy shift is part of a gradual shift that has begun in recent years as US troops' main goal has been ending the insurgency in Afghanistan and helping stabilize the country as a US military base comes up for renewal, they said.The shift is not as abrupt as in 2007 or 2008, when US forces were in a "search and destroy" mode, as Gen. David Petraeus put it in his 2013 memoir.During the early years, Petraeus said, the war was often "a grind," with combatant commanders trying to control the environment and maintain momentum with limited supplies.A senior US official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the US is no longer trying to win every day, but instead is trying to destroy al-Qaeda's leadership and prevent its ability to operate in the region.The shift of focus away from victory in the war and toward destroying al-Qaeda leaders began in 2018, when President Donald Trump was elected, the official said.Al-Qaeda, the former Al-Qaeda in Afghanistan (AQA) leader and the world's top al-Qaeda terrorist organization in 2011, has been struggling in Afghanistan in recent years. The Taliban, the hardline Islamist group that rules Afghanistan, has been on the defensive against the US-backed Afghan government since 2015.

Despite EU Criticisms of DealCYPRUS, May 30 (Sputnik) — The Cyprus government on Friday vowed to "remain" in the European Union even though EU critics of the agreement signed with the country announced that the country was withdrawing from the bloc, Cyprus Prime Minister Alexis Tseretches told reporters."The prime minister [Tseretches] expressed his commitment that Cyprus is committed to staying in the Eurozone," Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras told reporters.Cyprus has been struggling with a bailout since last November to keep the island afloat, and several EU leaders have voiced concerns about the country's commitment to maintaining its membership within the bloc.The country had earlier voted for the so-called "Grexit" and announced that the country would begin a gradual exit from the bloc starting in 2020.Cyprus is reportedly expected to receive up to €10 billion ($11.3 billion) in EU loans and financial assistance under the deal.

,MARKET STOCK: Sotheby's to Sell French Antiques: 2003-08-13, by Robert J. O'Rourke; in the New York Times, from July 10, 2003;NEW YORK — French antiques dealer Claude Louis-Cantat was convicted today on the charge of conspiracy to commit wire fraud in a multimillion-dollar securities fraud case. The conviction comes after Mr. Louis-Cantat, 59, lost a civil suit seeking more than $2 million in damages he was seeking against Sotheby's, one of the companies involved in the fraud, reports the New York Times.Sotheby's said today that it will sell a collection of French antiques that belonged to Mr. Louis-Cantat at auction. Sotheby's has also offered the collection to a collector.The company had previously said it would not be selling the items and Mr.

by Alabama News Network StaffA Democratic primary in Pennsylvania’s 14th District would alter the balance in Congress at a crucial moment, potentially sending Republicans a message that their grip on power is being tested.Democratic Rep. Susan Wild, in a district where President Donald Trump won just 52 percent of the vote in 2016, faces two opponents in a race that could be a referendum on her tenure after a tumultuous 2018. Wild has been in a public feud with the Philadelphia district attorney and a Philadelphia police union. Both men are expected to run against her in 2020, and neither is currently favored to win.The contest is considered one of the most important in the state. The winner will join Republican Rep. Ryan Bizzack, the current House minority whip, as one of the only Democratic House members representing Pennsylvania in 2019 — but Bizzack is unlikely to hold the seat.In the case of Wild, she would need only to beat the two candidates from the other party to avoid a general election, which would not be easy, given the unpopularity of the two men she is competing against.Bizzack and Wild did not respond to requests for comment ahead of the party’s Tuesday deadline to submit qualifying paperwork for the election.

British Prime Minister Theresa May has been fighting back tears after President Donald Trump said she was "not quite right" and that he'd "probably give me a card" after his first meeting with May in the Oval Office.After Trump praised May for her negotiating skills and said that May had earned "very high ratings," he then hit her on everything from trade to the NHS.He talked about how the US is the UK's largest trading partner, but that that would change after Brexit."I don't want to make too many changes, we've got great trade deals but I think we've got to go into negotiations a little bit differently, but you understand," Trump said in the Oval Office."She was not happy with the deal, she wasn't happy with what happened, but she wasn't happy with what was going on before, either," Trump continued.Trump said that he would have "probably given her a card" but that he had "no interest" in becoming Prime Minister.The British leader immediately tried to respond by saying: "I can only say I'm very happy to have been able to make a positive and very substantial deal with the United States.""That's what this about. It's not about me," Trump replied. "She was very upset with me, and I understand."The president, however, admitted that he wouldn't be "happy" to make any peace agreement with the UK, even if it was good for both sides."I'm gonna get along with everybody, but I really don't care about the UK."The Prime Minister was already being praised by the president, and received a hero's welcome from her own cabinet, but the meeting caused another rift in her party, The Times of London reported.

Thousands of bodies have been discovered in mass graves close to the battlefront against Islamic State, according to local activists and residents.Bodies of both women and men were discovered in separate mass graves close to one of the towns liberated by government forces in July of 2016 from the militant group, a resident in Idlib province told RFE/RL.Idlib province, as well as other parts of Syria and the Russian-Turkish de-escalation zone in the country's south, are home to multiple Islamic State (IS) sleeper cells.Syrian state media said that "at least 600" people have died in the Idlib province, but the resident of Idlib province denied that figure."We've learned from our security forces that thousands of bodies have been found there," said Hayat Al-Sham, a local militia group which was also active in the battle against IS.In July 2016, IS fighters set about burning villages close to the Turkish border in Idlib province."

in 'Sci-fi-Reality'In a future where humans have become the primary explorers on a planet millions of miles away, scientists and space enthusiasts are working to create a realistic world with enough data to help shape the future of humanity.The world's space community is also trying to come up with a realistic and realistic scenario that would allow humans to leave Earth.For years, the science community has been working to develop instruments and methods for future missions to Mars and, someday, even beyond.For example, the Mars Exploration Rover (MER) mission aims to gather a "snapshot" of the Martian atmosphere every day for two and a half years before launching, in a plan called "the Martian Inoxidator." That mission is expected to begin in the summer of 2014.A second mission, known as "Mars Hand Lens Interferometer," or MHLI, will collect data from the Mars surface once the MER mission concludes in August 2018."That was the first step to establishing the ability to actually have a sample sent from Mars," said Thomas Zurbuchen, a senior science adviser at NASA. [In Pictures: Images of Mars' Red Planet]"We think that we could do it tomorrow, but we need to get samples, and we need to bring them back," he said.The MER mission will carry eight sample tubes that would be mounted on the rover. Once the samples are collected by MER, they will travel to Mars' surface, where they would be deposited on Earth's surface.In addition, the Curiosity rover mission will examine Mars' atmosphere and analyze the chemical compositions of rocks. That work is expected to be completed by late 2016.Both the Curiosity and MHLI missions are being managed by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, with funding from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). The European Space Agency, or ESA, manages the ExoMars rover mission on behalf of the European Union.The MHLI mission will be led by a team of scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). Other teams of scientists are working on a variety of other missions to Mars, including the Mars Odyssey orbiter, which is orbiting the Red Planet. NASA and ESA are developing the next generation of robotic spacecraft that will explore the planets in the asteroid belt, known as the Oort Cloud."

, Withdraws Troops From Asian NationWASHINGTON — The United States on Thursday suspended all economic sanctions against Burma, the junta leader."I signed an executive order to suspend certain economic and financial sanctions in Burma against the military junta in response to Burma's military coup," Trump tweeted.In another statement, the US Treasury Department said that "it is critical that Burma's military leader, Min Aung Hlaing, be removed from power.""The military government in Burma has been engaged in human rights abuses and should immediately address all restrictions on the people," it added.According to the Treasury Department, the suspension means that "the United States will not use any U.S. resources or military support to aid the Burmese military's efforts to take control of the civilian government in Burma."In a sign of the US' shift, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Thursday that the US is "going to get out of that type of commitment," Bloomberg reported.As many as 13,000 US troops remain in the Asian country, but "that number is expected to go down," Biden said, without specifying how.The Biden administration also announced that in a "positive step," the two governments signed an agreement for the United States to remove its remaining troops from South Korea, the first step in a formal diplomatic process that could lead to more American military withdrawal.While the Pentagon had no immediate comment on Austin's comments, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Thursday that the US is "going to get out of that type of commitment," Bloomberg reported.According to Politico, sources familiar with US-North Korea policy said the administration is now actively exploring ways to ensure continued security support for the regime as the Kim Jong-un regime increasingly looks weak.US envoy for denuclearization, Ambassador Matthew Ward, told reporters, "If the North Koreans aren't going to play along, you have to find another way."The US also plans to remove remaining troops from South Korea, two senior Biden administration officials said on Thursday, without providing details.

, 2The death of the Guatemalan girl, 2, who died after being left in a hot van in Southern California was expected to be a Christmas Day funeral, the Guatemalan consulate said Friday.The consulate in Los Angeles said in a news release that the family would be buried Tuesday morning.A Guatemalan consul in the United States said he had spoken to the parents who fled to Mexico after fleeing violence in their homeland. The parents told him that their daughter was in a cooler, in a trunk, on the floor of a vehicle that the two drove to L.A.The mother told them that her daughter was crying to get out, but they refused to release her.A crowd of about 200 people gathered near the trunk to show solidarity with the two little Guatemalan children who were found dead Monday afternoon after they were left in a hot car in a parking lot in suburban Los Angeles.A vigil was held late Tuesday night, with many in the crowd throwing fruit and other gifts into the air in memory of the children who died. The vigil continued early the following morning, and protesters marched down a Los Angeles freeway, urging people to vote for Democrat presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in California's presidential election that takes place Tuesday.

Washington (AFP) – Violent crime fell last year in the first six months of 2017, with almost one in four cases being reduced to a charge of domestic violence.The FBI reported Wednesday that there were a total of 39,979 victims of violent crime last year, a slight reduction from the 41,981 victims the agency recorded in 2016.The decrease was driven by falls in some major crimes, like homicide — which fell from 3,926 cases to 3,076 — and sexual assault, which dropped to 5,332 from 6,143.Still, the figures represented the sharpest year-to-year decline in the number of violent crime cases ever recorded by the FBI, which started tracking violent crime in 1980.In addition to the decline in cases recorded by the FBI, the number of violent crimes being prosecuted by local prosecutors also dropped.Between January and December 2017, when the number of murders reported by local law enforcement agencies began being tracked by the FBI, there were 4,079 cases of violent crime — a 10 percent decrease from the same period in 2016.

A Jewish woman sits on the sidewalk outside a mosque in New York that has been closed to men after a similar incident in a different U.S. city on Wednesday.TOM BORGES, Associated PressThe Jewish woman is taking an unusual step in New York City for a second day, to make a public statement to the police after an incident in which a Jewish man was refused entry at a New York mosque.The woman is taking an unusual step in New York City for a second day, to make a public statement to the police after an incident in which a Jewish man was refused entry at a New York mosque.The man who was refused entry at the mosque in lower Manhattan spoke to The Associated Press on Friday evening.On Thursday, he said he wanted to attend the mosque service on Friday, but had to turn away when he was turned away. He said it was because Muslims are not allowed to enter during prayers.The incident came a day after police officers escorted a Jewish man into a synagogue and allowed him inside.There have been multiple incidents in recent weeks where Muslim-majority mosques have barred men from attending services.The New York police department said Friday that the man who was refused entry at the mosque has a complaint pending with it. The police department declined to provide further information.The incident is not a national problem. There are no major mosques in the United States that have barred men from attendance in recent years, and there is no report of incidents in which men have been turned away because they are Jewish.But there have been several incidents in which groups of Muslims have attacked and defaced Jewish symbols in response to such incidents.There have been multiple incidents in recent weeks where Muslim-majority mosques have barred men from attending services.

March 16, 2011According to the latest Pew Research Center survey, more than 70% of Americans favor treating drug users with mental health treatment rather than jail, a stance shared by more than 60% of Republicans and about 65% of Democrats.The Pew study also suggests that attitudes about drugs and crime in the United States have become far more partisan over the past several decades.On the question of whether the United States should incarcerate more people, the national majority is opposed. At about 90%, the percentage of Republicans (and around 25% of Democrats) who say that we should incarcerate more people for offenses relating to drugs is far greater than that of Democrats or independents (at around 10%).For some commentators the findings suggest that these results are due to a growing partisan bias, and that this result may be due to the political preferences of certain political organizations.Other commentators say that these results are due in part to the fact that the American public has become more familiar with the arguments for, and against, drug laws during this period.These findings may be a bit premature.

Using Your Cell PhoneWhen you try to make a call from an international pay phone, you get an "out of service" message. That could be due to poor cellular connections across the globe or even to a technical problem.But a new technology called F-Draim can be used to bypass that problem.The app from South Korea's KT Corp. lets you make a call using your own handset, or with the F-Draim phone of your choice. You then tell the app to transfer the call into the handsets of other users on the same Wi-Fi network -- including those of your friend who might be across the world.F-Draim has a number of limitations, including only transferring calls for calls you've made in the previous hour, and a lack of data transfer. But that won't stop users from jumping online and connecting to existing Wi-Fi networks to make calls in their own countries."It's a major breakthrough," says Lee Soo-hyun, a researcher at Ewha Womans University in Seoul, South Korea, and the lead developer of the technology.He says F-Draim will be the basis for a cheaper and more convenient way to connect to mobile broadband-based web services around the world.Kenya's move isn't just about saving money -- it also wants to boost the use of the Internet in the country, says Kenyatta."If this technology becomes the way people use the Internet it will really increase the use of the Internet," he said during a visit to South Korea earlier this month."

A newly released video by a U.S. Army major-general that aims to provide Islamabad with a military strategy for stabilization of Afghanistan shows how the American strategy for Afghanistan has evolved. For the past several years, the U.S. strategy for Afghanistan was primarily centered around counter-terrorism and military presence. But since the withdrawal of U.S. troops in April, U.S. military strategy has changed. It has shifted toward countering the Taliban, especially in the south.In a video released last week by Army Maj. Gen. Chris Donahue, deputy director of the U.S. military's Center for International Communication, he lays out some of the issues and challenges that American forces will face during their operations in Pakistan.Among these, Donahue lays out the need for U.S. forces to train Afghan forces to fight off the Taliban insurgency and to provide a military solution that includes economic development as an option for the Afghan people. In his views, the Taliban is not a nation. Instead, he believes that what Pakistan needs is the creation of a stable, democratic, and prosperous nation."We will use the same strategy we have used in South Africa. [It is] to promote stability, to assist the people in Afghanistan, and to have a stable and peaceful region. It will not be about 'taking out' the Taliban, but it will be about'making Pakistan work, make Pakistan a better nation and a safer nation.' And that's what we will be doing," Donahue says in the video.It will not be about "taking out" the Taliban, but it will be about "making Pakistan work, make Pakistan a better nation and a safer nation," he added.Earlier in his speech, Donahue said that Pakistan's security and economic problems stem from its foreign policy of supporting Islamist groups who don't believe in democracy and are hostile to the United States and NATO."

General Electric has announced that CEO Jeff Immelt is resigning and that his successor will be Denny Lynch.This is certainly not the kind of message GE needs going into the holiday season. With so much uncertainty regarding the fiscal year 2017 results and with the market being so sensitive about the potential for a rate hike next month, the move by Lynch will likely be welcomed by many.This was a long time coming as Immelt had been under tremendous scrutiny from the shareholders regarding GE’s financial condition and its ability to return value to its shareholders. In his letter of resignation, he did say that he would leave the Board in good standing at the end of the day, which was certainly a sign that he was stepping down.This move comes on the heels of a major restructuring that will lead to the sale of GE’s entire industrial business. This restructuring was the company’s first step towards its goal of selling all of its industrial units.

in Abu DhabiAbu Dhabi police have arrested a suspect in the fatal stabbing of an American woman in the southern United Arab Emirates, police and media reports said Monday.The man was arrested in the capital, Abu Dhabi, around noon, the official WAM news agency reported. The case involves a 26-year-old American woman identified as Heather Barr. The victim was stabbed several times in the abdomen and chest.Police are not naming the alleged assailant but a U.S.-based newspaper identified him as Matthew Barr, an American national. The newspaper, the Washington Post, said he ran a security firm called Global Protection Services and said his brother was his co-defendant in a 2012 case in the United States and was recently released from prison.No motive has been disclosed for the killing.Authorities in Abu Dhabi on Sunday said they were searching for a man who they said stabbed an American woman in an "incident," NBC News reported.

; 3 Missing, 1,400 Damaged; 3 Missing, 1,400 DamagedLONDON -- A magnitude 6.3 earthquake that struck central Ukraine on Sunday killed at least 16 people, injured hundreds more and damaged or destroyed some 1,400 homes and infrastructure in one of the most dangerous times of the year, the UN nuclear agency said.A man is shown after a mine exploded under a car in the village of Zhivyn in the Donetsk region, Ukraine, Aug. 4, 2015."

Share via EmailShare Via TextShare Via TextShare Via EmailThe U.S. government has launched a major campaign to slash its reliance on salt-laden foods.In recent years, U.S. regulators have been increasingly concerned about the excess of salt added to the U.S. diet.Now, the government is issuing new guidelines that food processors will have to meet, or else face civil penalty, over their use of sodium.The Food and Drug Administration recently sent a letter to more than 30,000 food processors, asking them to take extra care in using sodium in their products.While more than half of the foods sold in the U.S. contain some form of salt, the FDA is worried that excessive salt levels can lead to heart disease and kidney failure, which are both extremely costly and life-threatening diseases.The move by the FDA is seen as an effort to reduce the number of American foods that contain too much salt.It also comes amid a debate over the growing influence of processed foods and the fact that many products in their stores contain more than just sodium.The FDA said last year that more than 1.5 billion sodium-containing foods were purchased in the U.S. each year. The agency estimates that more than 200 million Americans take medications that come with sodium.“It is our hope that these voluntary standards will provide the flexibility for manufacturers and producers to determine a consistent approach in meeting the requirements of the voluntary standards,” says FDA Commissioner David Kessler. “And our hope is that these standards will be used to help create a healthier food environment.”

Position in the Party[Taiwan News] – A senior aide of President Tsai Ing-wen and former Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida is believed to be preparing to take over the leadership role in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), according to various media reports.Both Fumio Kishida and Tsai have been rumored to be considering running for the leadership in the DPP as of late.Fumio Kishida was known to be among a group of former DPP vice presidents that Tsai chose to head the party’s new internal affairs committee.Kishida later decided not to go through with it, according to people close to the administration.“The next chairman will need to be someone who will have the most support from other DPP members in the coming election,” said Kishida’s close friend, who requested anonymity.“Kishida had his friends among DPP members who were in favor of him as the chairman.”Tsai’s camp has expressed an interest in Fumio Kishida’s name to take over.Tsai has said he will be stepping down as president sometime after July 28.

Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Vienna on Saturday to protest against Austria's new far-right government.Protesters have gathered outside the Austrian parliament and in the main square of the city after Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz declared himself to be the "man of the people".

The Argentine pope Francis has been outspoken about the plight of migrants during his visit to Bulgaria on Monday, April 26.The visit is an "opportunity to reflect on some problems that may exist, and to create solutions, for which we need to be much more open to the possibility of an effective and effective immigration policy that involves solidarity and solidarity in favor of all the population of Europe," he said.Pope Francis also made clear that he is not going to endorse or support the policy of non-importation of refugees and migrants.He said that he is not seeking to endorse any particular migration policy. He reiterated his statement regarding migrants and asylum seekers in an interview that was aired on Monday's program of Bulgaria's Channel 1."I am not trying to be on the same page as the Greek, Italian or Bulgarian policy, or any of the other policies that are in favour of those arriving, and those fleeing," he said.He continued, "I am calling to be open-minded. I am calling for our European citizenship to allow us to receive the migrants, asylum seekers, without the risk of the expulsion of people, of which we have some in our country. These migrants are living in extreme conditions. They are being held in detention in Greece. Some people say that it is a human right to take them. There is not a human right to force people to come to Europe."The Pope emphasized the need for solidarity between migrants and asylum seekers because he noted that countries have a responsibility to protect and care for those who enter their country.According to the Vatican, the Pope emphasized the importance of the right to a dignified stay of asylum-seekers in the European Union.As he did in his interviews with the Greek bishops, the Pope told the Bulgarian people that he considers the protection of refugees and migrants to be of "impeccable ethical value," and that "it is imperative that the European Union be a force for global peace and social justice."According to the Bulgarian government, Pope Francis visited Bulgaria, where he met with the country's president, Rumen Radev, and a number of other officials, including Prime Minister Boyko Borissov, a government official, and bishops.Earlier on Monday, during a visit to the Greek Orthodox church in Nicomedia, the Pope visited the church of St.

The UN has appealed to the international community for $25 million in order to help Palestinian refugees who face poverty, disease, and the dangers of being uprooted in the aftermath of violence.The head of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) told a UN Security Council meeting in New York on Monday that the situation of refugees could become a humanitarian catastrophe in the coming weeks and months if the international community did not come to their aid."Unless we act quickly, the world must take note," UNRWA Executive Director Pierre Krahenbuhl said, as quoted by Reuters.He said that $25 million would enable the agency to feed 300,000 of the 3.7 million Palestinians that have been forced to leave their homes since the fighting in the Gaza Strip and the Israeli offensive in southern Israel erupted in mid-July.UNRWA is currently on a shoestring budget. In January it received a US$12 million grant, down $6 million from the previous year.The agency faces stiff competition from other international non-governmental organizations that are operating on more substantial and often more generous funding streams.The number of people who were forcibly displaced during the July violence alone increased by 100 percent, according to UNRWA estimates, and the agency said the number of internally displaced could double if the fighting spreads outside the Gaza Strip.But the UNRWA chief insisted that the agency has been taking steps to expand its efforts to help the displaced."We are now operating in refugee camps and assisting those in need," Krahenbuhl said.But while UNRWA and other UN agencies have received vital contributions from the West and the Arab states, the flow of international donations has been extremely limited so far, a result of the "conflict and instability in the region" and the conflict's "humanitarian implications.""We have been able to secure our own assistance in some cases," Krahenbuhl said, but "there is no guarantee that these donors will be able to sustain this or come back for more."The chief of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, Yasser Arafat, last week suggested that the Palestinian Authority could help pay some of the costs. But the PA insists that it is not financially able to step up and take on additional humanitarian duties.

A powerful earthquake that devastated the Indonesian island of Sulawesi has claimed at least 36 lives and injured at least 200, according to local officials.The deadliest and most destructive incident is yet to come when a tsunami threatens the country’s largest islands, Palu and Ternate, which were devastated by last year’s 11.1-magnitude earthquake and tsunami, said Indonesia’s disaster agency chief Sutopo Purwo Nugroho.“We have received some additional information,” he said. “The situation is still very rough … it’s still an active situation.”The earthquake destroyed tens of thousands of homes, damaged about 20,000 buildings, and displaced more than 1.4 million people.Palu and its surrounding areas, which were badly affected by last year’s tsunami, are still recovering from devastation. Palu Mayor Muhammad Iqbal said on Friday that more than 250 houses in Palu city have been destroyed.“

The U.S.-led coalition in Afghanistan is running out of troops and has begun sending in air crews and support packages from neighboring countries to bolster local forces.The United Nations is preparing to deploy a small contingent of unarmed peacekeepers to the former Afghan capital of Kabul.The World Health Organization is struggling with an influx of patients and has requested assistance from the U.N. Security Council.The International Criminal Court has also become involved in the cases of suspected war crimes committed in Darfur in Sudan and elsewhere in Africa.While the humanitarian situation in many countries has improved, conflicts have been escalating in some of the world's most vulnerable parts.The United Nations' Humanitarian Coordinator for Syria, Jens Laerke, said more than 6.6 million people needed humanitarian aid. Half of them were in Syria itself, and 2.7 million in neighbouring countries. More than 1 million were in Yemen, where nearly 90 per cent of the population need help.Even if aid money arrives as needed in Somalia, a long and complex political situation, and the prospect of further U.N. peacekeepers in South Sudan, may prevent a full recovery of South Sudan's economy.In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which had been free from war for more than 20 years, a series of political and economic crises has led to an explosion of violence in the Kasai region.In the Central African Republic, rebel groups have taken control of much of the country's capital, Bangui, despite the presence of African Union troops.The world is still trying to learn the lessons of the Iraq War, but now it is also trying to learn lessons from an explosion of conflict in recent years.Copyright 2021 NPR. To see more, visit https://www.npr.org.

There is evidence that being a member of Parliament (MP) is actually the most dangerous profession in Africa and Asia, according to a new report from the British Parliamentary Research Service.AfricaSomaliaAccording to the BPS report, Somalia is still the most dangerous parliamentary environment, followed by Mali, where being a parliamentarian is more dangerous than being the president. The BPS report also shows that members of parliament are murdered far more frequently than in other countries.AsiaThailandBeing a Thai parliamentarian may be the most dangerous profession in Asia, followed by the Cambodian parliament. According to the BPS report, the Asian Parliamentarians Association (APA) is the most dangerous body representing parliamentarians in Asia.Middle EastJordanBeing a Jordanian parliamentarian is the most dangerous occupation in Middle East, followed by India, where a parliamentarian is most dangerous than prime minister. India, Iran and Pakistan are also among the most dangerous countries for MPs.Western EuropeUKAccording to the BPS report, UK is the most dangerous parliamentary environment followed by Switzerland, France, Italy, Germany and Belgium.AmericasLatin AmericaArgentinaArgentina is the most dangerous parliamentary environment in Latin America followed by Colombia, Chile and Ecuador, according to the BPS report.Central AmericaEl SalvadorEl Salvador is the most dangerous parliamentary environment in Central America followed by Guatemala and Honduras.

- But Will That Be Enough To Disprove Occupy Wall Street?Occupy Boston continues to grow as protesters march towards Zuccotti Park, with many calling for a general strike against the current corporate-run government, even though there's a distinct possibility that any such action would only be a symbolic protest against the police. But a quick glance at Occupy Boston's Facebook page reveals dozens of arrests. And even if the numbers of people who are arrested are significantly smaller than some people believe, will that be enough to completely shut down Occupy Wall Street? And what do those people who were arrested do now?We got word that over 100 arrests were made throughout the downtown areas of Boston on Wednesday, including 50 arrests in Zuccotti Park alone. According to Occupy Boston's Facebook page, "police came in with guns in hand" and took several people away in handcuffs for "assault and riot," though those charges have yet to be filed.

PeopleBEIRUT (AP) — Three Syrian activists and two journalists said a deadly blast in the Syrian border town of Hassakeh near the Turkish border killed at least 5 people on Saturday.The activists and journalists spoke on condition of anonymity because they feared government reprisals.In the latest attack on the Syrian opposition-held border town of Hassakeh, a powerful blast went off Saturday morning and killed five people, the activists said.Local officials in Hassakeh said five people were killed in a rocket-propelled grenade explosion.It wasn’t immediately known whether the rocket struck at midday or when the blast took place. It was also unclear who fired the rocket.Syria’s President Bashar Assad’s government has fired thousands of rockets into the country in recent years, mostly targeting areas held by the opposition, including Hassakeh where a truce is held.In 2016, the Syrian military said its planes had killed “terrorists” on the Turkish border in the northern countryside, in one of its biggest successes against rebels in the fight against government forces.Turkey’s president Erdogan has repeatedly promised to send forces into Syrian territory to drive back the extremists.Syria’s civil war has left hundreds of thousands of people dead and tens of thousands injured.Syrian President Bashar Assad has also launched chemical attacks on his own citizens, allegedly killing dozens of people, a claim dismissed as fabrications by the international community.

, Despite Fears of CoronavirusThe United Nations is calling for free and fair elections in Lebanon on Feb. 14 despite the country's rising coronavirus toll and fears over the spread of the global pandemic, the UN Security Council said Thursday.Lebanon is facing its worst economic and health crisis in decades, and the country is facing a possible default on its debt."

Brigitte Bardot is not alone in her support of the #MeToo campaign.At 83, the French actress’ mother, Isabelle Bardot, is in agreement with her daughter.Brigitte Bardot's mother Isabelle Bardot is supportive of the #MeToo movement. "It is good that some women have come forward," she said on Thursday (14 December) during a gala to support the victims of sexual assault in France.In an interview with the French radio station France 2 on Tuesday (11 December), she added that actresses who participated in the movement were "hypocritical".I think it's good and even the feminist movement has been good, but I think it was hypocritical," she said, but explained that she understood why some people felt sorry.I think it's quite natural to say you're sorry because you've been deceived by people who want to make you believe you are a victim," she told France 2. "I am a feminist and I would not allow that and I would do the same thing with a man who was going to have me do something I didn't want to do."Bardot herself has come under fire this week. She was seen giving an interview in which she questioned the role of women in society, according to the BBC.

The United Nations’ Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has released a report on alleged violations in the war-torn Democratic Republic of the Congo’s (DRC) Central African Republic (CAR) which includes allegations that Chadian soldiers were responsible for at least 200 civilian deaths.The report says that Chadian troops were stationed in a town in the northeast of the country, Bambari, as part of Operation Barkhane, which was launched in 2018 to combat the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), which were previously linked to Boko Haram and the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIS).The report is based on witness accounts and video evidence of what happened on October 7, 2020, in the town of Bambari. The Bambari site has been used repeatedly in recent years as a location for ADF activities, and is used as a staging ground for joint operations against the armed group.During the night of 7 October, the witnesses reported hearing bursts from the town, and saw Chadian military vehicles coming to the area. They reported that at around the same time, several people were wounded in the town. The residents told them that the soldiers were from the Chadian 8th Division. Later that morning, at around 9 a.m., they learned that Chadian troops had killed five civilians, including a five-year-old, and also that several people had been seriously wounded.Two sources were also confirmed to have died during the attack.The Chadian soldiers allegedly began shooting into the crowd in an attempt to kill the men. The witnesses also said that their men opened fire after the Chadian soldiers were told by the local Chadian population that the local population had attacked their bases.According to the report, Chadian soldiers were in the town for an assessment. Chadian personnel were not the intended target of Operation Barkhane, and troops were not sent to Bambari specifically to defend it against any ADF action.Chadian authorities have denied allegations of killings in the town, saying that they had taken over four thousand fighters away from the area.

John Paul II is the former Pope who ruled the Catholic Church from 1979 until his resignation in 2005. He was born on September 4, 1933 in Poland and raised in Poland before returning to Rome for academic work.Vatican City is a Roman Catholic cathedral and the center of the Catholic Church worldwide. It is located in Vatican City, the capital city of Vatican City, and is the seat of the Holy See. It was built in 1929, by the order of the Holy See, to commemorate the visit of Pope Pius XII in 1929 to the Holy Land. It is the main building of the Catholic Church, which includes the Vatican Museum, the Roman Catholic Church, and all the dioceses throughout the world.The papacy is considered to be the ultimate authority of the Church, and to have the power to ordain and dismiss Catholic priests around the world. They use this authority to support the spiritual growth and development of the Church.All the Pope's power comes from his papal primacy or authority, which is granted by the Roman Catholic Church after the death of a Pope.It is the duty of every Catholic to act as a witness to the authority and primacy of the pope. This is especially true for Catholics in the diocese. The pope's authority is limited and not all papal actions can be legal.Pope Paul V was the third pope to have the name Pope V in a papal name, after Pope Pius I and Pope Pius XII.

WASHINGTON - US Ambassador to Sudan, John Bass, on Thursday called for a renewed push for peace and stability in Sudan.He addressed the issue during a meeting with Sudanese political leaders in Khartoum on Thursday, in a bid to move forward with a peace process that is currently frozen."In the last week, a significant amount of progress has been made," he told them.The United Nations has expressed support for a peace deal and the United States has taken a series of actions to help ensure the process.US officials say Sudan's leader, Omar al-Bashir, has agreed to address issues of peace.Meanwhile, sources within the ruling army have told AFP that they are ready to negotiate in line with US calls for reconciliation with the opposition.Washington and Khartoum have been bogged down in a protracted civil war since 1989, and there is little hope that they will agree to a deal this year.However, President Donald Trump's administration is keen to see Sudan resume its role as a regional power broker."The US is ready to take further actions to accelerate this process," Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Twitter on Monday.

One of Italy's most innovative researchers is turning to an artificial intelligence (AI) program to help him develop the next step in the evolution of robotic devices.The researchers at the University of Foggia (UCF) have been able to improve the design of a robotic hand from a prototype they had earlier created.In 2017, the Italian researchers were able to develop a robotic arm capable of grasping and handling objects at great heights. They made the robotic arm using "a special 3-D printing technique." That arm can also grasp objects at a distance of eight feet, which was not possible previously.The arm, called the LAMMION, was created using a three-dimensional (3D) printer developed by University of Toronto's School of Engineering.The robotic arm features three degrees of freedom, enabling it to lift a 3-D object weighing about 4 kilograms (9.9 pounds) with a 20-gram (0.8 ounces) weight ratio. To move the arm in the direction desired by its operator, it requires four degrees of freedom.The LAMMION is the first three-dimensional (3D) robot arm to perform a basic movement (i.e. picking up a 2-D object). This is a significant advancement in the engineering world as the first use of a robotic arm without requiring additional hardware such as sensors, motors, actuators, and so on to achieve this task.The project involves developing algorithms to automatically transfer the information from the LAMMION to a remote control system. It also includes the development of a "robot arm extender." This is a small external device, such as a carabiner, designed to be affixed to the robotic arm extension to make it longer and to hold objects at a greater height.The technology and research that is being developed in this project is being applied to other projects and is likely to be used to improve human robot interfaces for various tasks.Researchers and students from the UCF Faculty of Technology are working on various projects.
January 11th, 2016The shootings in the United States have reached more than one million in 2015.

At the age of 27, the undefeated and undisputed WBA lightweight champion defended his title against the previously undefeated and undisputed WBA middleweight champion at the historic Madison Square Garden, in New York City, during the first ever broadcast of an undefeated heavyweight boxing title fight between two fighters who had never been seen competing together prior to this event.A night to remember!

by Michelle MartinOn Sunday evening the UK saw its worst-ever death toll linked to coronavirus, with 548 deaths reported in just one day — an astonishing figure.This was not expected, and this too is not unexpected: this is a pandemic, a global health emergency. But to many people it is also a personal tragedy and a national emergency. It feels like a national tragedy, the likes of which we never even expected.There is no greater illustration than the reaction from people and the government.It has been a huge and overwhelming effort to combat this global threat. While the numbers are staggering and many people, businesses and organisations have fallen on hard times, some people have responded to the crisis with incredible kindness and generosity.From small donations of food and money to the most heartfelt pleas for volunteers, to donations to food banks, to help with medical costs and for personal protective equipment, the reaction has been immense and deeply moving.It also highlights how people are feeling and reacting to all this in different ways. It is almost as if some people are doing it as a social duty to give back, whilst some are just doing it because they want to feel part of the response in some way.The government has also offered a huge response, a huge and overwhelming amount of money to help fight the disease. The vast majority of people have done so incredibly well, donating to food banks and offering financial help, without expecting in return any sort of reward.However, many are still feeling the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, and are looking for something to do, and this is where social media comes in.It is an enormous help for many, and has been a huge help for many people, and also for others too. For some, social media gives them a way to voice their opinions and find their way to people who need them. It lets them reach people on a topic of interest for them.

- ReportsAn increase in attempts to reach the UK via the English Channel, a border policy under threat in Britain as London attempts to get away with the issue in international waters.According to the British government, the latest migrants are mostly from the Arab world in an effort to force British policy changes.More than 3,000 migrants have passed through French ports to reach the UK so far this year, which is already up 25 percent compared to the same period in 2018.The increase is blamed on the growing number of attempts to reach the British coast by crossing the English Channel.While the migrants have the right to enter, the British government's policy of only letting in non-EU nationals in an effort to secure the votes of the "leave" voters is being challenged in court.The French have agreed to allow an additional 200,000 migrants to be permanently resettled in France after their asylum applications are approved.The British government is currently appealing a ruling which requires the UK to take in 400,000 new Syrian refugees.The UK currently rejects all new asylum requests from citizens of the Muslim world and has refused to allow Syrians to settle in the country.Many believe that the increase in arrivals can be blamed on the growing number of Syrian refugee populations in Turkey, which they claim to have been "misled."The British government had already agreed to allow 10,000 Syrian refugees to settle in Britain.The British prime minister, Theresa May, has recently warned that any attempt to "disconnect" her country from the rest of the European Union would be a mistake.

The world's largest AIDS fund says scientists have discovered a new way to prevent the transmission of HIV.The new anti-HIV drug, developed by scientists in Italy, would be the first to have the potential to stop the virus from spreading between blood groups.The lead researcher at the University of Bologna's Laboratory of Virology says his team's findings could lead to a "profound" change in how the AIDS virus is spread.Antiretroviral drugs are already in place for at least some people with AIDS, but it's not clear how effective they are. This drug would be able to block HIV from replicating in blood plasma. If the cells that produce it get infected by the virus, they can't produce the virus anymore and can be treated with existing drugs.The gel would also be able to prevent some strains from infecting blood cells, researchers say."We don't have many options that could prevent transmission between blood groups; HIV is a relatively uncommon disease to have on your blood group," says researcher Dr. Luca Borrelli.The next step will be finding people who can use this gel in clinical trials and making sure it stays stable in the body, says Borrelli, who is also a professor of virology at the University of Rome.The Italian National AIDS Commission (CNAR) is also enthusiastic about the potential."In the worst case, this drug may help 100,000 people. There are huge benefits for the world's poor countries if we could get a vaccine for this," says the commission's HIV director, Giovanni Battista Ammara.

When a couple makes the decision to live together, they know what they’ll have to share. So they get an idea of what they’ll have to share. And then they spend a lot of time together, figuring out exactly what those two things will be.Which brings us to the scene of that infamous episode of The Real World: Home Edition in which a couple decided to live together. And you know how that goes: When they first have to figure out what to eat (or what not to eat, for that matter), then they figure out what to do with each other when they’re together.And so the story of what that might be ends up being a lot of things for just about every roomate involved.But what if it weren’t about food, or other stuff for that matter? What if it wasn’t?Which brings us to Smart Guy and Dumb Girl, who are about to live together in what the show has been calling “whatever works.” It’s a place where everything they need is in one place, and it’s a place where they get a lot of sleep. And apparently they are more than willing to be roommates.So we’re going to find out whether their new roomate is a smart man, or a pretty darn good dumb guy. The most likely scenario here is that he will be the more intelligent, and/or more patient room mate.I can’t really see it that way, because the fact that she is in charge of the kitchen means that she is probably smarter. The way I see it is that the more intelligent/hardworking partner is the one who gets to stay up too late, plays Xbox and reads books to himself, and can do all the dirty work.When you’re watching someone else’s life on television, you want a little insight to what makes them tick. Whether it be a man (as we see in the movie) or a woman, you want to know what makes her tick. And who knows? You might like their character when you find out exactly what she does to make it work.So, what’s Smart Guy’s end goal in the “whatever works” place?It’s not hard to guess.

Pakistan says the U.S. has turned down efforts to secure a peace settlement in Afghanistan, citing recent security problems on its borders, including possible suicide attacks in neighbouring countries.The U.S. Embassy in Islamabad on Saturday acknowledged the "difficulties" the U.S. faces in resolving security problems in Afghanistan, saying it could have taken steps to improve security."The United States has always sought peace in Afghanistan through peaceful means, including through reconciliation and intra-Afghan talks. Pakistan believes that such efforts must succeed, not only in order to create stability in Afghanistan, but also to achieve a lasting and peace-loving peace on the region," the U.S. Embassy said in a statement issued in Islamabad.Pakistan's military leadership, however, blamed the Afghan government and its foreign backers for their military failure, blaming "interference" by foreign forces.Pakistan denies U.S. claims about interference in Afghanistan's internal affairs.The U.S. Embassy said the embassy was continuing to urge Afghan leaders to help to create a secure future for all."However, the United States believes that Afghan leaders, if they are committed, will make such changes," it said."While there are continued concerns, including possible attacks against Pakistan, the United States believes that the current security situation in Afghanistan is not conducive to terrorist violence or to terrorist strikes in the United States," the statement added.It said Washington would continue its efforts in the hope that peace can finally come to Afghanistan.

Washington, Feb 6 (AP) The United States and the IMF on Monday endorsed a major initiative for poorer countries dealing with the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.The White House and Washington's twin allies were moving forward on an initiative that would authorize up to $40 billion in short-term loans to poorer nations to help contain the virus and help them recover.President Joe Biden had told the IMF and World Bank last Friday that the US and its allies would not seek debt relief or austerity measures for poor countries.The White House is moving forward on an initiative to help countries struggling to recover from the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, even as many nations face threats from the virus.Biden on Friday said that the US would provide up to USD 20 billion in aid to combat the virus, though the vast majority of it will come through COVID-19 vaccine diplomacy.But on Monday, the IMF and World Bank, as well as the US Treasury, said the president's remarks were too vague and not enough to commit Washington to taking immediate action."The Fund welcomes the forthcoming action by the United States to support low- and middle-income countries to fight COVID-19," the bank said in a statement.But while the White House and Washington's two allies were moving forward on the initiative, the pandemic still kills hundreds of thousands of people every day and is ravaging the global economy."

, Most Affected by War CrimesThe United Nations humanitarian chief says that most of those currently displaced by Syria's devastating war have been affected by war crimes."More than 2.5 million people are in need of assistance and protection. More than half of them are living in extremely fragile conditions, suffering the worst forms of trauma and suffering," the United Nations Special Adviser on the prevention of war crimes, Lakhdar Brahimi, said in his annual report on humanitarian operations in war-torn Syria."Some of these are actually being perpetrated by the same armed groups that they are trying to protect," he said, calling on the international community to support Syrian authorities and independent humanitarian organisations in their efforts to provide humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable victims.Brahimi noted that the United Nations is assisting some 12 million people in the country. He also called for an independent judicial investigation into allegations that Syrian armed groups are preventing aid access to civilians.The Syrian Arab Army (SAA) is conducting operations against rebel forces in the province of Quneitra, which borders Turkey.The battle for the city of Tamer al-Dah is raging between SAA and armed groups led by Jaish al-Islam, a militant group based in northeastern Syria.Despite a number of offensive operations by the SAA, Jaish al-Islam continues to hold control of areas around Tamer al-Dah.Brahimi said that in the last month alone, approximately 200,000 people have fled their homes of Quneitra.UN experts say they have collected evidence that Syrian and allied forces have committed war crimes and crimes against humanity during the assault on the city of Tabuk.Brahimi said that the United Nations was "deeply disturbed and concerned" by reports that members of Jaish al-Islam have been using excessive force against civilians in the area of Al-Sukhanat as well as using artillery and air strikes at will to attack and bomb areas of Tamer al-Dah."

for UseIt seems like the latest charitable intervention is the offer of a Compassionate Care Award. The first of the year, and the second awarded by HumanKind, compels you to spend some time on this site, then to post an online question “about yourself.” You need to think hard about what you are doing and what you want to achieve before you leave this page. The purpose is to help people get to know you, and to give you some insight into who you are and what you want to accomplish. You may be asked to elaborate, but you can say you already know who you want to be about yourself, that you already have some good ideas about what you want to do. You can give yourself some good advice. You may be asked to explain why you do your current work and what you are trying to do. Perhaps you can tell people what you have learned about yourself, or what you have learned from the people you have come into contact with. I hope, by writing this, I can answer your questions about yourself and make yourself seem more of a “person” than a “gimmick,” and a “pseudoperson.”The second Compassionate Care Award Award for the year, a few days before I was told by HumanKind that I could ask any “organization, charity or organization” to write me about myself, is supposed to be a “test.” What does that mean? I want to see what is really behind what I am doing and what I say. This is to help me see how far my “passive” self has “passive” feelings and a “passive” character that “passive” feelings don’t have. It isn’t necessarily that I am asking you to tell me what is going on in your life, but it does allow me to learn from what you write, and from what I write about you. This kind of “test” doesn’t tell you who you are, because you don’t write about a “you” and tell a “me” of who you want to be.
