in ReportBEIRUT, July 16, 2014 (ENS) – A United Nations report has detailed the situation in Syria – including the use of cluster munitions and barrel bombs – in an unprecedented number of attacks.While Syria appears to have a “relatively low” number of cluster bombs in its arsenal, the report indicates that in the first six months of this year alone, more than 500,000 cluster munitions were used during fighting across Syria’s nine provinces, accounting for more than half of all cluster-weapon use in Syria this year.During this period, an average of four to eight victims were killed per hour, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said in the report, released today.The report noted that for the first time ever, the use of cluster munitions was a cause for concern in Syria because it would put the population in an already dangerous situation and risk further displacement.“Although some progress has been made in Syria regarding the use of cluster munitions, the report demonstrates that this trend may continue in light of the continued use of cluster munitions in Syrian military operations in the first half of this year,” said Valerie Amos, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs, in her introduction to the report.The report – one of more than 10 UN reports issued today concerning Syria’s civil war – includes an extensive survey of what happened in Syria in 2013.The report found a steady uptick in the use of barrel bombs, which are non-explosive explosive launchers packed with a large quantity of chemical materials, including chlorine.“The use of chemical weapons in Syria should be condemned by everyone, including the international community,” Amos said.Barbarium bombs were used throughout Syria this year, and were most often used in the first half of 2014.

; India Govt Fined Over Rs 5 Million For not Rescuing PeopleIndia, a country of 1.25 billion people, is home to more than 300 million cyclone survivors, according to its National Disaster Management and Control Agency.The cyclone that hit India has brought death and destruction, killing at least 3 people with another 5 missing, the government said Thursday, as it imposed an immediate 3 billion rupees ($39 million) fine for not responding to requests from people in need.The storm, which the National Weather Service in India’s eastern district of Sikkim calls Fani, was said to have crossed the east coast of India between Puri in Odisha state and Puri in Andhra Pradesh state.“The cyclone has uprooted several trees across Odisha and Andhra Pradesh’s districts,” an official told AFP.India has been battered by frequent storms and cyclones for decades, and with its vast population, the government tries to build its defences in advance.But the government failed to protect more than 4 million people in the eastern state of Odisha, many of whom have lived in vulnerable and overcrowded homes for years, and who have had to flee from their homes because of cyclones before, said rights activists.The government has also struggled to pay compensation in a disaster that it described as “extremely big”.Odisha authorities had given only a 50-kilometre (30-mile) warning ahead of the storm, a far cry from what the Odisha government was telling cyclone survivors living in low-lying areas, who had had their houses destroyed in previous storms.The Odisha state government has said it will compensate the victims with Rs 20 million ($272,000) and will provide shelter, a hospital and a job for those who cannot find one for themselves.“The government should have been better prepared from the beginning,” said K. Surya, founder of an NGO called ODF, or Odisha Disaster Forum.Many cyclone survivors in Odisha have no access to banking facilities, no land registry, and no government-owned mobile phone network because most areas are cut off by inaccessible mountains, Surya told AFP.“

Despite reform, Native American women still face high rates of crime. A 2010 study from the University of California-Santa Barbara and the National Center for Educational Statistics found that in some Native American communities, the risk of violent crime was 10 times greater than in communities where only 20 percent of residents are Native American.While the criminal justice reform movement has made a dent in reducing violent crime rates overall, Native American women’s safety remains a serious concern. To remedy that, law enforcement agencies and tribal leaders need to address the unique challenges Native American women face and ensure that crime victims receive the protection they deserve.According to the U.S. Department of Justice, Native American women were the victims of crimes at four times the rate of white women. In California, Native American women are 3.5 times as likely to be arrested for crimes as white women, and are 1.7 times as likely to be victims of violence.A 2007 study from the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics found that while violent crime rates decreased in communities where Native American women were the primary victim group, their rates of robbery continued to be higher than in communities where more than half of residents were Native American.

Islamabad [Pakistan], Nov 6 (ANI): Pakistani Taliban, which has been on the verge of capturing the key northwestern district of South Waziristan, has withdrawn from the district, South Waziristan District Police said on Wednesday.Pakistan's Foreign Office in a press statement said that the Pakistani government is committed to the Afghan people and has supported the Afghan government in their peace process.Also Read | India’s COVID-19 Tally Hits 26-Million, Single-Day High, 1,000 Deaths Reported.Earlier in the day, South Waziristan District Police had confirmed that the Pakistani Taliban had withdrawn from the district.According to the provincial police, Pakistani Taliban have withdrawn from the South Waziristan District.Also Read | Pakistan PM Imran Khan to Discuss Situation in Afghanistan With US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan.The announcement came after an earlier Taliban announcement that they were leaving the Pakistani district of Waziristan.The Taliban, which has been on the verge of capturing the key northwestern district of South Waziristan, had announced earlier that they were leaving the district, South Waziristan District Police.At least seven Afghan soldiers had been killed in South Waziristan area earlier, said South Waziristan Police.Pakistani Taliban (Taliban) is a terrorist organisation banned in Pakistan and a designated global terrorist by the United Nations.The Pakistani government and the military have conducted an offensive against the Taliban.

DAVID GREENE, HOST:It's Saturday on Day Six of our series about the Sudanese conflict. I'm joined by Yuma Kibra, the Sudanese Ambassador to the U.S. The violence in Sudan was a big story not too long ago, but Kibra says now youth are making big changes. He's one of several young Sudanese we talked to today, and we'll come back to them for more on that.Thanks for joining us, Yuma. So tell us a little bit about yourself.YUMA KIBRA: (Through interpreter) (Music: "I Feel Like a Woman") It's a very good day. I am here in the USA to attend a conference organized by the Sudan Institute of International Affairs. It is important for us, the generation that was born between the end of the civil war and the beginning of the war in Darfur. Now we are starting, as I mentioned, with a political transition but, of course, there are challenges. In my country, of course, the people are saying that the new president is a man who is in a position to make peace and this is important.I was born between the end of the civil war and the beginning of the war in Darfur. And when I say a generation - (Music: "I Feel Like a Woman") - I mean a generation.I remember the war. I remember the war. I think I remember a certain year. In my country I have lived the war. So I understand how people are feeling. In addition, we need to give a boost to the security forces and to the Sudanese government because we have been fighting for a very long time and we are now starting the transition. I think this is an important day. In addition, I think we should make peace to ensure that Darfur is not repeated to our whole Sudanese people.GREENE: Did you hear about the political transition coming to the end? That was a big thing this past week.KIBRA: Yes, I heard it. Actually, I heard about the political transition, which is a very important step, because I think this transition has already started. As a matter of fact, I believe we are already doing it.

in Sambisa ForestOn 15 December 2017, the Chief Justice of Nigeria, Justice Dikumo, handed a letter requesting the International Criminal Court to consider taking a full investigation of atrocities committed by Boko Haram in the Sambisa Forest. This request was submitted as a statement of Nigeria's intention to take action against atrocities by Boko Haram. Nigeria's actions are in response to a letter of request sent to the ICC by the U.S. State Department in 2014.Amnesty International's request for action against crimes committed by Boko Haram is an important step in the ongoing struggle to end crimes against humanity perpetrated by Boko Haram.Boko Haram is responsible for committing atrocities on a horrific scale against civilians in Nigeria's Sambisa Forest, where over 250,000 people were displaced and some 300,000 people have fled their homes. The Sambisa Forest has been declared as a humanitarian crisis because its nature, scale and magnitude of destruction make it difficult to provide food for all displaced people in need.The Sambisa Forest has been subjected to extensive destruction, including the destruction of more than half a million trees and a significant number of animal farms in order to ensure Boko Haram's operational activities.Amnesty International is concerned that it is now increasingly clear that many of these crimes were committed at the hands of armed groups who use the forest to carry out their operations and have caused serious humanitarian concern for the people living in and near the forest.The situation calls for a full investigation into these crimes, which would enable full accountability and accountability for those responsible. The United States of America also needs to take action to ensure that the crimes committed by these armed groups are fully investigated and properly punished.Boko Haram's brutal persecution of thousands of people for the crime of trying to leave the Sambisa Forest and return to their homes, is an urgent humanitarian issue in need of urgent attention. This attack should serve as a call for an international investigation into the Sambisa Forest crimes committed by Boko Haram and a call to the ICC to prosecute war criminals.In a letter to Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari on 2 December 2017, Nigeria's Justice Minister, and Attorney General of the Federation (AGF), Abubakar Malami, confirmed Nigeria's intention to take action against atrocities committed by Boko Haram.It is now time for the ICC to initiate an investigation and to fully investigate the crimes committed in Sambisa Forest.

ISLAMABAD — The United States has warned that increased violence is "certain" and said any peace deal with the Taliban must focus on Afghanistan's economy and prevent it from becoming a " breeding ground" for militants.The U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, and his Pakistani counterpart, Asad Umar, met for more than 10 hours Saturday in Islamabad.Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said Sunday that the U.S. ambassador and his Pakistani counterpart "discussed the ongoing dialogue process," but said there was no immediate progress."They assured us that they would take this matter into account in future but we are not seeing any serious effort to resume the talks," he said.The U.S. and NATO formally began peace talks with the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, in March last year, with the aim of opening up talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban about the end of the 22-year-old war. The talks have never been seriously progressed.The Afghan government rejected calls by U.S. President Donald Trump for increased U.S. involvement in the talks, arguing that the U.S. military was already committed and that it was not needed. Trump also threatened to remove support if he was not satisfied.Trump also demanded that the Islamic insurgent group halt attacks on U.S. and other foreign troops in Afghanistan.The Taliban has claimed responsibility for several large-scale attacks in Kabul in recent weeks.A spokesman for Taliban leader Haider al-Abd, who attended the meeting in Islamabad on Sunday, denied any progress."We discussed the current situation of the country. No further steps will be taken," Zabihullah told The Associated Press. "The Afghan side is ready for further talks with the U.S. side."Abd said the Taliban would be open to talking with the Afghan government but that the government must also be ready for such talks."For them to agree on a cease-fire in the past, they have to show an action to that," he said. "After that, we will discuss with them about the path for the future."While it is still not clear how the new U.S. strategy and the future of the Afghan peace talks will affect the new policy that President Trump has announced on Afghanistan, the Afghan government did not deny that U.S.

The brutal onslaught on civilians during the current Sri Lanka war on the western shores has been well-documented at the many news outlets, but it seems that human rights violations are not limited to the war zone itself, but include the civilians who survive the violence. On Sunday, the first day after the alleged attacks that killed over 50 people, some civilians were seen returning to their homes. In the aftermath of the attacks, a curfew was declared in several communities in Batticaloa which is the easternmost district of Sri Lanka, but that is still not enough to protect the people who have to flee their homes.While a curfew was announced, an official statement from the Sri Lankan army states that there is currently no fighting in the area. However, it's not known exactly what's been going on in this area where the curfew has been imposed. However, it's clear that a large number of people have left their homes and many civilians have died from being forced to flee their homes and areas."A curfew has been imposed in some areas of Batticaloa in the easternmost district.

in the UK, EU, Afghanistan, and PakistanThe British government’s Foreign and Commonwealth Office recently released data showing a number of foreign spies suspected of having breached UK government surveillance systems may not be the only perpetrators. The Office of Strategic Services (OSS) released data showing that in addition to an already known list of British spies with high-risk intelligence, a total of 12 suspected terrorists have been questioned by British security services with information suggesting that they may have also accessed UK systems that are being monitored by the NSA. These suspects include:• A “person of interest” in a 2007 shooting at the London Stock Exchange that resulted in four fatalities, and one police officer being seriously injured.• The former chief of Pakistan’s national intelligence agency, who reportedly fled to the US in 2009 after being questioned by UK intelligence about his role in the assassination of Benazir Bhutto.• Pakistani-born suspect Abdul Hafiz, who had reportedly traveled to the UK under false pretenses, and was questioned by the OSS in late 2006 in the case of an alleged plot to kill a British soldier.• Abdul Rahman, a suspect in the murder of a police officer that took place the following year, who was questioned by the UK security service (CIS) after being “identified as a possible suspect in the death of Detective Constable David James,” who had been involved in the investigation into the death of two men who were murdered in a suspected murder-for-hire plot.• A suspect in the 2006 murder of a police officer, who was reportedly involved in the investigation into the case and who was questioned by the CIS.In addition, the British government revealed that in an effort to protect UK spy targets, intelligence sources were sent overseas to question suspects. In the UK, for instance, intelligence sources were sent to the US to question suspects linked to the 2007 London Stock Exchange shooting. In the US, the same sources were flown to Pakistan to question suspects associated with a 2006 “plot to murder a British soldier at a NATO base in the country,” though the source of the attack remains a mystery. In some cases, the source of the attack has still not been identified.The information released by the British government to the OSS shows that a number of the suspects were under suspicion but that some have not been arrested.

A lawyer said Tuesday that an independent journalist who works for an online news outlet in Georgia has been kidnapped by unknown parties.Nashville, Tennessee, attorney William McRaven released a statement that said an independent investigative reporter with The Associated Press (AP) was abducted Tuesday, along with his wife, by unknown men.McRaven said the journalist was found unharmed Wednesday morning by an AP reporter.McRaven noted that the AP "applies its highest journalistic standards to all its reporters." He didn't specify how he knew the journalist had been kidnapped.The journalist's colleagues at the AP, including the AP's executive editor, declined to comment on the story."The AP strives to provide quality journalism, and we stand by that commitment," AP spokeswoman Julie Pace said. "We've been closely monitoring the AP newsroom and this story, and are working to provide more details as soon as we have them."McRaven said he had spoken to the journalist and his wife and that they told him they were unharmed. He didn't elaborate on any of their descriptions, but he thanked reporters who provided updates about the kidnapping.McRaven said he didn't know the circumstances of the abduction, but he said "the AP is a trusted news organization that is fully committed to providing its citizens with accurate and useful information."Georgia's WXIA-TV reports that police in Clark County in the Atlanta area searched an apartment complex for the man believed to be behind the abduction. Police say two people are being questioned. No arrests have been made.

Haiduan Liu, an economics student in Beijing, celebrated his 19th birthday on August 12 with the local police after having been detained in a crackdown on the anniversary of Mao Zedong's birthday.His arrest was not officially acknowledged by Beijing's government but local police confirmed that he was detained. Liu was also charged with breaking pandemic control laws, with some sources mentioning coronavirus.The students arrested in Haiduan's case have all been taken for test for COVID-19 after they started reporting at different police stations. They have been charged with incitement of violence and spreading news that violated pandemic control laws.China has a record of detaining academics and activists who hold different views as well as individuals who have openly discussed the issues at which the party, the party's leadership, and the government of Xi Jinping have been blind.The arrest of Liu is likely in retaliation for a speech Liu was set to deliver at the Chinese People's University on August 11. It was a speech by Liu that the police have been unable to verify and which Liu claims has now been removed from the official website for the police force.Liu's speech was to be titled "How to win socialism's moral victory", where he was critical of the Xi government and the Party's policies at large. He had stated, "Today, the country is going through a difficult period, but the road to socialism is clear. We must show that the party and the government are capable of making good decisions and that they will stick to them."The speech was never approved by the government and Liu and the university have filed a lawsuit to have the speech officially cleared.The speech was never approved by the government and Liu and the university have filed a lawsuit to have the speech officially cleared.It was only after the speech came to light that the university expelled Liu from their campus. Liu has said that he plans to return to Haiduan for another year of study.It is unlikely that Liu's speech would have been cleared because even if it was approved, the speech would have dealt with matters that are too politically sensitive for the Chinese regime. Liu believes his speech should have been cleared, but only if there was a higher purpose behind it and it would have dealt with matters that were too politically sensitive for the regime.A speech by Liu is one of the most valuable tools of dissent and critical analysis in China today.

Refugees in Belgium are worried about the backlash they will face after the country’s prime minister said they could “only stay if they accept the conditions.”“There is no question about it: people will be afraid of being the scapegoat for anything that happens,” said Aisha Akef, who was originally from Somalia.Akef and her brother, who is from Eritrea, decided to settle in Belgium in 2016. They were granted asylum in 2017.However, they worry about the backlash that could happen when they speak their minds on social media about how they’re feeling and the challenges they’re having in adapting to their new life in Belgium.“When you say something and you think about it you realize it’s true, but people also have different perspectives and can react differently, so you have to learn to live with the things that are happening around you,” Akef said.The country’s premier, Jan Jambon, made the comments on Twitter in response to the criticism from a Belgian senator that his country would lose some of its multicultural nature if the country’s newcomers cannot adapt to the new way of life.According to reports, some lawmakers warned that their citizens would suffer from an influx of foreigners from Africa.Jambon responded that the country’s culture and history would be “lost” if the country cannot “accept the fact that it is not always like what you hear on the television, on the radio, in the cinema, in the supermarket, in the Internet, and in the movies.”The government promised last week that it will look into how to protect citizens who are “unwelcome” when their fellow citizens criticize the newcomers’ behavior.

Published on 26 February 2017 | Author:Katharine E.The latest tragic incident in China involving a mine at Huangxing in Jilin province is a call to action. In its wake are proposals for mine rescue and an improvement in mine clearance practices in the wake of the recent tragedy.The mine explosion in Huangxing's Huangshi Village killed 26 people. The mine was operated by a local mine contractor and it occurred after the contractor failed to secure the mine. This tragedy occurred at a time when there was a national focus on the safety of mines and the mines industry.

WASHINGTON — A U.S.-backed militia in Syria conceded to journalists on Monday that they could not yet defeat the Islamic State group (IS) in that country despite more than 500 airstrikes by American-led troops."It is difficult for us to achieve security in the region, but it's also important for us to be honest and open with the public and be able to say we have difficulties and that it could take some time before we succeed in our goal of security," Abu Mohammed, a spokesman for the U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), told reporters.SDF is a coalition of local and foreign fighters who have joined the U.S.-led coalition to fight IS in Iraq and Syria. The U.S.-backed alliance has been in the country longer than the Islamic State group has been in its self-proclaimed caliphate."The ISK (IS) are a real challenge, but we are fighting them and they are not in all areas, and we are still working on it," Abu Mohammed said.ISK stands for Islamic State Khorasani, which the group's most recent leadership claimed as its official name.The group's militants have continued to carry out suicide attacks in parts of the country, including attacks in the Syrian cities of Hasakeh and Daraa in the last two weeks.U.S. airstrikes and ground forces in Syria have been largely focused on the fight against ISK.The SDF has reported losing between 50 and 100 U.S. soldiers killed in Iraq since the U.S.-led coalition declared victory in the country last November.

, China SaysThe earthquake that hit China's south-central region on Saturday killed at least 18 people, China said, a magnitude 6.4 quake that jolted some residents of the region in a region that had previously seen three deadly quakes.China said the latest quake had caused at least 18 deaths, but it gave no specific figures, with a toll expected to climb when search and rescue efforts resumed.The quake struck early on Saturday morning, the China Earthquake Administration said.It struck the area around Huaihai City in the Hubei province, with at least some damage to buildings there, according to the local government, which said it was not yet time for rescue.There was no immediate reports of major injuries or major damage in the quake-hit region.China has been hit by a number of deadly quakes over the past couple years.

President Donald Trump is making up for lost time in his State of the Union address.His claim is Trump’s “most important.” But it’s wrong on every level. He’s right, however, that there’s been a new spike in gun violence.He’s not wrong on the importance of border security, but again, he’s wrong on the number of illegal immigrants trying to enter the country. He’s wrong that crime is down in most cities. He’s wrong that the budget deficit is a problem.And most importantly, he’s wrong that there have been fewer shootings and fewer deaths in the inner cities, where much of the crime is done.Here’s the full text of the speech.From the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.:Mr. President,Members of the Congress:Tonight, in the State of the Union address, I'm going to address what I believe is the most important issue facing our nation — our border.And a big and urgent priority for this administration is the security of our southern border. This is what the people of Mexico want and this is what the people of Central America want, too.We've made great progress on the front lines in defeating drug gangs, building new bridges and fences, making real progress on keeping families safe and getting illegal immigrants to the United States in the first place.But this will be the largest and most audacious law enforcement effort ever launched in our country's history, and it will require the collaboration of every man, woman, and child — including our brave law enforcement. It's something that we all want, and we're all in this together.But as soon as I take the oath of office, the most dangerous drug cartels in the history of Mexico will try to cross our southern border. These criminals know that law enforcement is far better equipped than anyone else at the border.So, in addition to the hundreds of billions of dollars we have allocated for our border security and wall — the cost is going to be much lower than anybody previously realized.The people in Central America who are going to be affected by this will be those who have crossed into the United States illegally and come to our schools and work with our kids, our neighborhoods, and our communities.

MoreRicardo VargasRICARDO VARGAZ, the Nepalese National Bureau Chief for his country’s most prestigious television station, told the United Nations in Geneva on Monday that local authorities are cracking down on press freedoms, a charge which has been dismissed by the authorities.In a telephone interview with Al Jazeera, Vargas said local security forces were detaining journalists at the request of the local governor’s office in the main city of Kathmandu, the country’s national capital.On August 31, at least 50 journalists of various local and foreign television stations in Nepal’s capital were detained at their homes in the overnight operation, according to government spokesman and Kathmandu University professor Bhupendra Chandel.Authorities claimed that journalists were involved in a “violent and criminal protest against security forces”, but independent television journalists have said they were arrested in their homes and detained at police stations.Vargas is responsible for a large part of the television output of Kathmandu Television (KTV) which is owned by a Chinese telecommunications company that is headquartered in China’s Guangzhou city.

For 'Attacking' IndiaWashington [US], July 10 (ANI): The United States, on Thursday, called for an end to the boycott of Indian opposition leader Sonia Gandhi for her role in the violence that shook her home.India had requested the United States to end the suspension of assistance to Sri Lanka's Government after a special United Nations (UN) committee recommended that it be suspended. The US had refused to lift the suspension of aid until the Sri Lankan government takes certain actions. The country had also sought the restoration of certain development assistance suspended by the US government for Sri Lanka.The US is suspending assistance to Sri Lanka because it will not commit to action to achieve the outcome of a special committee of the UN human rights body, which recommended that the United States suspend assistance to the government of Sri Lanka in response to violent protests between pro-and-anti forces in that country.Also Read | US to Resume Financial Assistance to S Sri Lanka: Report.The suspension of assistance to Sri Lanka was approved by the US Senate. The suspension will continue until the government of Sri Lanka takes certain steps to prevent further violence, including holding political dialogue and releasing those who are still under house arrest, in accordance with the Special Committee's report.The UN Special Rapporteur for human rights in Sri Lanka, Navi Pillay, had called upon the Security Council to suspend the suspension of financial assistance to Sri Lanka and take other actions to maintain a conducive climate in that country, especially in view of the ongoing violence, the Human Rights Council, after the country had lost the Special Rapporteur's mandate. The special rapporteur also urged the member States of the Human Rights Council to take steps to ensure that the country has an effective framework for addressing the human rights concerns arising out of the violence, in particular including by encouraging the government and security forces to restore the rule of law, take prompt steps to ensure the safety of all communities, including the protection of journalists and ensure an independent, impartial, thorough and independent investigation into all allegations of the use of excessive force and other violations of human rights, ensure appropriate and prompt redress of the rights concerns, prevent further violence and provide assistance to the affected communities to help restore the social, economic, cultural and educational development of Sri Lanka.In April, the US State Department had issued the first travel warning on Sri Lanka, saying that it would be reevaluating travel to the country.

Former French Minister Receives Jail sentence In Angola Arms TrialFORMER French Minister Yannick Jadot was sentenced to four years in jail on Tuesday in an ongoing French arms trial.The sentence was handed down after it was revealed that one of the weapons found in the apartment Yannick Jadot rented in the African country of Angola was designed to be used in a nuclear attack.According to the French government, the new bomb would have been far too unstable to have been successfully detonated.According to the investigation the weapon was made between 1980 and 1990 at the former French secret service laboratory of Sciences Po.On the night of March 8th in the year 2009 Jadot, a former defense minister, was questioned by French anti-terrorism prosecutors.After a 12-hour interrogation the official investigation carried out revealed the possession of a military weapon designed to be used in nuclear attacks.The weapon had been tested in France’s military laboratories.

The United States is seeking diplomatic dialogue with China, including seeking Beijing's consent for an intelligence-sharing alliance with Thailand, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman said on Tuesday in Bangkok, a day after Chinese military announced that it was sending a ballistic missile to the Spratly Islands.Sherman said the U.S. had proposed the dialogue to China. "We think it is important for all countries to come together when they face a threat," she told reporters during a press conference, calling for dialogue to be reciprocal. "We want to be able to share intelligence without any preconditions."The deputy secretary said it was a good time to bring the dispute to the negotiating table. "You can't solve things without having dialogue," she said.The U.S. deputy secretary said the U.S. and China have been conducting naval drills this month and warned the United Kingdom about any Chinese activity in the Indian Ocean. She said she spoke on the phone with British Foreign Secretary William Hague the same day.She expressed the hope that Britain would not take the U.S.'s statement as a threat and could maintain its commitment to a bilateral agreement with Taiwan."The British have been an important partner in our effort, to bring about a peaceful resolution in the Taiwan issue," she said. "We remain hopeful that Britain will remain steadfast on its commitment to Taiwan, just as they have on their commitment to the international system."Sherman had earlier visited China's embassy in Thailand. She has also met Thai PM Yingluck Shinawatra during her visit to the U.S.

A senior member of the EU's peacekeeping mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina said Thursday that the EU was ready to deploy troops to avert another eruption of violence."I am not going to speculate because we are preparing for all scenarios," EU chief Javier Solana told reporters after meeting the UN special envoy for Bosnia, Jean-Claude Lagardère.Lagardère has called for a new Dayton accord to be implemented by the end of 2012, to avoid a repeat of the violence that followed an election the previous year in which pro-Muslim forces lost out to pro-Christian forces.Lagarderer warned that the UN Security Council would be ready to send troops to Bosnia if necessary.EU members have repeatedly stated that they would intervene if Bosnia's government fails to show proper respect for the UN-mediated agreement that ended three years of bloodshed.Solana said that the EU will continue to support all the measures in the Dayton accord but he also warned that if new clashes were to erupt it would be for a military intervention by the international community.

, UN SaysBy Keba EssebJuba (South Africa), (Sputnik/ANI): The presidential elections in Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) that was scheduled for August 8 but has been postponed due to the security situation in the country is taking place amid chaos and unrest.The Congolese Electoral Commission (CEN) announced on Saturday that the presidential and parliamentary elections would be postponed after violence erupted in the country's eastern Equatorias, a day after it set the deadline for submitting voter registration forms, according to a media report.The United Nations Assistance Mission in the DRC (UNAMID) stated that thousands of people have fled their homes, and some have taken refuge in neighbouring countries in neighboring countries.Speaking at the U.N.

An official at the World Food Programme says nearly a quarter of Africa's population needs emergency food aid to save lives.Nearly 12 million people in southern Africa need emergency food aid.WFP Regional Director Ramesh Swarup says an estimated 8-10 million people are in the most acute need.He says around 8-12 million people are facing food insecurity in southern Africa, with the highest number in Madagascar.He says most of the crisis is driven by acute food shortages, and is a consequence of prolonged dry spells.Swarup says it is an emergency and it is not something that will be resolved without strong leadership from the heads of state.More than 7 million people are chronically or permanently food insecure in southern Africa, with the number expected to reach 11 million by the end of the year.Swarup says a number of agencies are stepping up response, but he says more is needed to address the crisis.He said, "We have been operating in southern Africa for over 50 years and a lot of work has been done, but that is changing and we need to be ready for what's about to come."Swarup says the next two years will be very critical for southern Africa.He says WFP will focus its resources in 2017 in South Africa and Mozambique, and work on the country's long term food security.He says the agency has a mandate to ensure food security of all people, with a vision of creating a "stable, resilient, resilient" agricultural economy that is healthy and productive.Swarup said, "What we're doing at the moment is trying to find new strategies and innovations and looking at things like climate risk and resilience in agriculture.

to Flights From UKMOSCOW (Sputnik) - Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis does not believe that the Balkan route that was used in the past to transport citizens out of the UK will be able to resume its service to the EU from the UK, he said.On Tuesday, the European Union decided not to lift a travel ban on British citizens and non-EU nationals from all non-EU countries and that only citizens of the EU and Britain are allowed to enter the bloc."

By James M. DorseyNEW DELHI — Despite the economy slowing further, India is again raising interest rates to try to rein in inflation.The Reserve Bank of India's Monetary Policy Committee, on Tuesday, unanimously voted to raise the benchmark lending rate by 0.25 percentage point to 7.15 percent for six months, and another 0.05 percentage point to 7.20 percent for nine months.This will be the 12th hike since September, but will be the second since November. It is the first since August, and would mark the first increase in the benchmark interest rate since India began its current rate-hike cycle in November last year.The decision has become increasingly controversial within the government, and some economists say it may signal that there will be no need for further increases this year. Inflation in India has been above the RBI's estimate since September, reaching 7.23 percent last month — an increase from 6.78 percent in August.India's growth rate, now about 6 percent — from 5.5 percent — is expected to decline to 6.1 percent or so by the end of the year.Analysts say there is some possibility of some room for further easing as more recent data, particularly the growth rate of rural areas, have been strong. But the overall direction of policy remains clear: the central bank is determined to try to reverse the recent slump in inflation, a feat it has accomplished only once before: by raising interest rates to a record high of 8.5 percent in July 2011.India has suffered a decade of weak economic growth as a result of an ongoing recession stemming from foreign direct investments, which have left the country's manufacturing sector stagnant and dependent on exports and, by extension, remittances. Even after the RBI cut interest rates in 2012, the economy still suffered from a deficit.Last year, the central bank raised the benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percentage point, but the economy had already weakened significantly. India's economic growth rate of 5.9 percent in 2011 had not been seen since 1984, when the GDP shrank by 1.6 percent.The current slowdown is mostly due to the fall in global demand, which is likely to improve in the near future, and higher interest rates.

Tigrai athletes won 11 titles in the National Taekwondo tournament organized by the Sports Authority of Pakistan.Tia-tia won the gold medal in the women’s 69kg division and Khaqan was awarded silver medal in the 69kg Division. Ayesha took the bronze in the Women’s 81kg division and Mubeen bagged the bronze medal in the Women’s 81kg division. In the Men’s 69kg Division, Mubeen bagged the silver medal.In the Men’s 69kg Division, Tia-tia was awarded the silver medal while Mubeen bagged the bronze medal. Harare, Zimbabwe | UN News |Botswana is providing a $70 million credit line to help Zimbabwe’s struggling economy. The loan, under the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is a part of Botswana’s “Botswana-Zimbabwe Investment Plan.”“This loan demonstrates confidence in the financial system and the economy as a whole, as well as showing our commitment to work with our African partner,” Botswana’s Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Hon. Kazembe Kambwili said in a statement today.“The loan is a complement to the Zimbabwe Investment Authority (ZIA)’s ongoing capacity building project under which several African countries are working toward creating mutually beneficial investment opportunities and markets for each other.”The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with ZIA on the development of a bilateral investment fund to be managed by ZIA which shall be responsible for the implementation of projects with a view to building better regional infrastructure and supporting the implementation of the Agenda 21 Agenda.To date, six countries have already been approved for loans under the MOU. Zimbabwe has received a $30 million loan under the MOU.“The MOU also provides a framework for the identification of areas of convergence in business practices and infrastructure development; and to create a more coordinated institutional structure for financing of Africa’s infrastructure development projects,” said the statement.Botswana’s “Zimbabwe-Botswana Investment Plan” aims to reduce trade barriers between the two countries and boost bilateral economic cooperation.The Botswana-Zimbabwe Economic Co-operation Plan for 2012–2022 is meant to promote economic and political stability in the two countries. It will improve the living standards of the population through: development of agricultural, forestry and animal rearing industries; development of manufacturing; the industrialisation and the promotion of services; agriculture; the promotion of cultural, musical and tourism industries; protection of natural resources; education; and the reduction of unemployment and poverty.“The Plan is expected to produce results which promote peaceful coexistence, economic development and mutual understanding and respect of the human dignity and rights of both people of the two countries,” the statement reads.“

The government of Turkey is once again coming under attack by religious and anti-religious forces. A recent report has revealed that the Education Ministry of the nation is considering plans for an Islamic school in the country. According to reports, the school would be funded from foreign and would cater to the education of the children of the Turkish-Turkish community.A report on the plans for an Islamic school was released by the National Security Committee, which is controlled by Turkey’s Supreme Military Council. The committee was said to be in charge of monitoring the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities, which includes its presence in Turkey.The report states that the plans for the school have been submitted to the Education Ministry and that the ministry has not accepted them.The plans were initially submitted in 2013 by a committee headed by the education minister, but the ministry never approved them. According to the report, the ministry is still considering the plans.The report states that Turkey does not follow Islamic laws and has many cultural laws that are separate from Islam. Therefore, the country follows different rules and laws than it does the religion of Islam.The report also said that a law, which calls for the expulsion of all students from religious schools, was submitted to the education ministry in 2011. The law states that there has to be an increase in the proportion of students from religious backgrounds in private schools.Turkish law states that all religious schools in the country have to comply with the standards of the Turkish education system, which is also an Islamic system. According to the report, the bill was submitted to the Supreme Military Council, and it was not approved.A recent report by the International Crisis Group states that Turkey’s government is being attacked again and this time it is the Education Ministry that is coming under attack.The country is coming under attack once again. This time the secularist education system is under attack. The country’s Education Ministry is coming under fire once again because the ministry is considering plans to fund an Islamic school.In recent years, the country’s Education Ministry is coming under fire for not only not following religious schools but also being the first to take steps to establish Islamic schools in Turkey.According to a report from the International Crisis Group’s Turkey branch, a new bill has been submitted to the Education Ministry. According to the report, the bill has been sent to the Supreme Military Council.

T21:47:01+00:00West Africa is the third most populous region in the world but has the fourth lowest school enrolment in 2004, according to a report by the International Rescue Committee.The report, "West Africa: State of Education 2004" is based on a survey of over 15,000 schools in nine countries in the region.It found that 30 per cent of the schools (or 36.7 million students) have been seriously damaged by conflict or natural disasters, including earthquakes. This is compared to the global figure of 15 per cent.In addition, 60 per cent of West African schools (38.3 million students) were under-resourced with insufficient funding for education and health, compared to the global figure of 20 per cent.The report also found that West African schools had poor environmental conditions and sanitation, as well as poor environmental conditions in schools themselves and in the environments of the surrounding communities.The report concludes that it would be possible to close almost half (47.5 per cent) of the schools in the area, with only 4.1 per cent (8.9 million students) remaining open.This would mean, in theory, that every high school would be closed, and nearly 1.5 million young people would be able to leave the region for good. But it would also mean a huge economic decline and joblessness in a region that has experienced huge growth since the early 2000s.The total cost of the school system was estimated at $2,300 per student, but many schools in the region already have high operating costs.The report suggests that the region would have to raise the $3 billion the report says it needs to properly improve the school systems, rather than just closing them, if the region wants to achieve full economic development.

The latest news from NASA:The space shuttle Atlantis will remain at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida until April, according to the agency. NASA has confirmed that Atlantis remains in the middle of its normal maintenance cycle.The space shuttle will undergo a total of 16 months of work, according to NASA.During the time the work will be focused on the Atlantis wing and vehicle components, the wing’s air tanks, and some of Atlantis’ cargo.The work is being planned to be completed in time for the Atlantis’s scheduled departure.This latest delay of the shuttle, due to the wet conditions in the area, will only increase the cost of flight delays. The space shuttle Atlantis has already experienced two other flight delays this year due to wet weather conditions. The agency plans to add fuel reserves into the shuttle, which will allow the shuttle to stay on course through potential weather risks, according to space analyst James Epps.Atlantis will remain at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida until April, according to the agency.NASA’s next flight will be the Orion spacecraft which will carry astronauts to explore the moon and other celestial bodies.

LOS ANGELES (AP) — Actor Tim Conway, the veteran comic and actor best known for his character of "The Carol Burnett Show," has died after a fall at his home in Southern California. He was 85.His wife, Susan, told the AP that Conway died Wednesday evening.Conway's career as a comic began in the 1950s in the New York area. He appeared in such TV shows as “The Dick Van Dyke Show," “Frasier" and "Seinfeld."He was best known for his iconic role on the Burnett show, which ran from 1955 to 1967.Among his notable film appearances were “Batman,” “Jingle All the Way” and the cult classic “Beverly Hills Cop.”He also had a huge impact on the TV world as a stand-up comic in the 1960s.His first album was released in 1965 and he opened for comic comedians such as Jerry Lewis and Mel Brooks in Las Vegas.In 1970 he became a regular on “The Tonight Show” with Jay Leno and on some subsequent guest spots on the show.He was also active in politics throughout his career, including as an ambassador with the United States at the 1964 Olympics in the Tokyo games and later on as a US ambassador to the European Parliament, according to The Hollywood Reporter.Conway was a Los Angeles native, and his funeral is set for Friday at the Hollywood Palladium, according to his wife.

Over FilmIn a lawsuit filed this week, horror film director Wes Craven and comedian Pauly Shore claim the other used their property unconstitutionally, and the lawsuit seeks unspecified damages.According to court documents obtained by the Hollywood Reporter, the lawsuit was filed against Pauly Shore, the owner and creator of Pauly Shore & the Shore Family Daze, an internet service of jokes posted on the web by Shore.Shore claims in the lawsuit that Craven is seeking the same amount of money he lost in a lawsuit against him when Shore published the original sketches and songs and videos without permission.This is not the first lawsuit between Craven and Pauly Shore, who was Craven's friend.Shore was awarded an injunction in 2014 after Craven sued him for not giving Craven credit.The case is currently on hold because of the coronavirus, but that isn’t to say it can’t be renewed.Wes Craven on the other hand has been hit with a lawsuit by a friend and actor, Pauly Shore, who was Craven's buddy for years and has now filed against the filmmaker.In a recent interview with Sirius XM, Craven revealed he and Shore were arguing about what to do about Pauly Shore."

, Urges Staying CalmU.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is warning North Korea against carrying out a satellite launch.On Tuesday, a North Korean satellite reportedly blasted into the sky over the Sea of Japan.Guterres addressed the issue with his Japanese counterpart Fumio Kishida, calling on both to keep calm, according to a statement published by the U.N."I am concerned by the reports of an ICBM test that was carried out today in North Korea. I urge North Korea to refrain from taking any action that could lead to war," he said."I also urge Japan to ensure that any military action that it might take is proportionate to the threat posed by North Korea," he said, stressing that he and his Japanese counterpart are discussing the matter.Kishida echoed the secretary-general's call for restraint."In response, the United Nations is working with other countries, including Japan, to promote dialogue through diplomatic means, through a peaceful process that will lead to greater international cooperation to resolve the situation and achieve a peaceful settlement for the Korean Peninsula," he said.The United States is also urging North Korea to stop its missile and nuclear development.In a tweet on Tuesday, U.S. President Donald Trump warned China to "get involved" in the crisis as the president also made reference to the planned ICBM test.

: Mexico is a country on fireOctober 27, 2018 |The Zapatistas’ guerrilla army in Mexico has announced the launch of a major tour of the country, with no rest and no pauses.A spokesperson for the group, Zapatista Popular Movement (MXP), told Fox News that while the tour may have begun, the organization’s membership had not been “completely decimated”, a “more or less” unchanged number of members and that “we are not at war” with the government.The MPP’s national tour is the result of more than a year of hard work of the rebels following their victory over the Mexican government in the bloodiest battle against the government of the history of the world.It will bring the group’s popular message directly to the people, in some cases to the doors of politicians and government officials.The tour will start from the capital city of Mexico City on October 30, with a stop at the city of Puebla, the home of Zapatista leader Cecilia Ayala and her son, Manuel Vela.

Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to win a second term and continue a policy of "unwavering" support for regional states amid a steady but flimsy global economic recovery.Abenomics has achieved steady economic growth and has lifted unemployment below 4 percent. But the policy is likely to be extended until the next national election in 2021 because voter discontent still deepens as economic gains fade.Japanese voters have increasingly taken issue with Abe, who is on his third term as prime minister, due to his handling of the economic crisis stemming from the Fukushima nuclear accident.Fears that he might quit at the end of his first term have never materialized, but this year they could take a more decisive turn after a series of political setbacks and poor economic forecasts.Abe last month suffered a second blow after a string of major setbacks including a failed constitutional amendment, a government reshuffle and a lower house election called by the opposition.Abe's ruling bloc is facing a similar situation to that of the opposition during the last three decades, when powerful military and foreign governments sought to block any progress made by the prime minister during a period of relative political stability, forcing Abe to push to quickly solve problems.The ruling bloc is looking to hold on to power next year."We'll do our utmost to secure a stable Japan," said Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga on Wednesday, adding that the government was committed to Abe's second term.Analysts believe that the opposition will refrain from trying to force Abe from office.Abe's top priority in the run-up to the election will be deciding which of the six parties that are represented in the Diet -- including those from the major opposition parties -- will run for the top post.The ruling bloc has a simple majority in the upper house of parliament, but it relies on a support of at least 200 seats in the lower house to secure a majority. The conservative bloc will try to woo support from the major opposition parties by offering new and improved policies to attract the smaller parties to the bloc.Japan's economic fortunes have turned for the better but the political landscape remains shaky.

for UnityBETHLEHEM, Dec 12 (IPS) - The United States reiterated its desire to see Ethiopian political groups reconcile for political unity ahead of the coming general election.In a statement from its Bureau for East Africa Policy (BEAP), the U.S. administration said the parties must show "a commitment to working together towards unity and a shared goal, the return of the people of Ethiopia to the Ethiopian people's democratic choice".The statement came during an intensive visit to Ethiopia by U.S.

Thailand is grappling with the highest debt ratio in Asia, which makes the economy particularly vulnerable when the world's financial markets begin to turn on its country. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned this week that the Asian nation of 66 million people is headed for a "tumultuous period," with the possibility of its economy failing to pay off its debts.In recent weeks, hundreds of people have protested in Bangkok demanding that the government raise the interest rate on the loan it is holding from the IMF and the World Bank."There are people in every part of Thailand who don't pay anything in taxes, yet they are the ones who want this government to raise the interest rate on their debts," said Somphachai Khun, the spokesman for the People's Democratic Party of Thailand (PDPT). "I'm sure that if the government had to pay its debts, they would be very angry and unhappy."The official government debt is currently at 40 percent of GDP, a high ratio which IMF economists say should be seen as an indicator of the state of the economy in an advanced country.According to the latest figures from the government, the government has debt of more than 3 trillion baht - nearly $800 billion at current exchange rates - and the IMF says this is likely to be far higher given the government's continued borrowing and the country's dependence on its neighbors for financial aid.The public debt is considered to be a major factor in curbing credit expansion in Thai businesses. The current debt is more than three times the GDP of Thailand's neighbors - Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam - all of whom are in the same precarious position as the nation of Thailand in that they are highly indebted and are facing severe economic problems.A major political move is expected this month to address Thailand's debt problem, but Somphachai said it would not be an immediate move that might increase the cost of borrowing.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sep 2 (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 2nd Sep, 2019 ) :The crew of a missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may have crashed in the Indian Ocean near the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, US officials and a Malaysian official said on Tuesday.There had been an error in flight data analysis, Malaysian aviation minister Azharuddin Abdul Razak told reporters in Putrajaya after returning from an official visit to the US.A US official said that the US has no direct information that the missing plane "may have been in any distress" beyond its last radar contact with the aircraft, after an analysis was made of satellite data to determine the aircraft's path."That's a conclusion from the US.

A Thai woman has successfully won compensation after being beaten, forced to marry and sexually exploited by an Australian man she thought she was helping.The award of $1.5 million (7 million baht) was one of the largest amounts awarded in a sex-trafficking case in Australia.The victim’s lawyer, Mark Baker, said the man she believed to be her English interpreter was “no angel, a hard-living man … who had been involved in a horrific human trafficking situation” in South Australia.After he allegedly moved back to Thailand in late 2012, the woman filed a suit in Australia, claiming that her client had been sexually assaulted, forced to work in his uncle’s coffee shop, and beaten in the head after resisting his advances.“He’s been an absolute nightmare, but his behaviour at the time we thought that he had helped her was that he seemed extremely affectionate, very much in love with her,” Baker said.“He’d made a great speech at the launch party and she didn’t want to leave him, she didn’t know what to do, she couldn’t live without him.”The woman said she had to pay the man several million in compensation to bring about a reconciliation in the couple, and she was allowed to give birth to their child.The woman told the Australian Press Association (APA) that while she has no recollection of the alleged crime, she does remember “how terrified I felt, how scared I felt that my family were going to be killed and how terrified I was in bed at night … I didn’t want him to get away with the children.”The couple has gone on to marry, but the APA says the case continues to be investigated and it is possible the couple may have been forced to change their legal names.The woman’s lawyer says the couple have been “shaken” since the decision to award the compensation, but are now very happy together.“

Amid TalksKABUL — Violence flared in Afghanistan’s eastern Nimruz province on Monday, as Taliban militants attacked a government checkpoint.The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.The attack followed negotiations that Afghan peace negotiators began with a delegation from the Taliban on Friday. The delegation was headed by Suhail Shaheen, one of the leaders of the Taliban's political office in Doha, Qatar.Nimruz has long been a hotbed for violence between the Taliban and Kabul government.On Thursday, the Afghan government said that a member of the pro-government militia had died fighting Taliban in Nimruz, and the Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.The Taliban also attacked the western province of Farah on Tuesday. The Taliban claimed responsibility for a large-scale attack in the city of Zadran on Monday that killed several Afghan security forces, including a commander of the National Directorate of Security, the interior ministry's top intelligence agency.Shaheen, a former Afghan parliament member, told The Associated Press that he will help the United States and the Taliban resume direct talks if they reach an agreement on a deal on Afghanistan.Afghan officials were initially skeptical that Taliban fighters would withdraw from contested areas and stop trying to take over more territory.Shaheen's delegation would also include members of the Taliban's political office in Doha, which has been accused of giving Taliban leaders inside Afghanistan special treatment to ensure that the group did not re-energize its offensive.Copyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

Canadian geese may be to blame for the fatal crash of a Hudson River plane Wednesday, according to a team of investigators.The team's conclusion is based on the results of an autopsy performed on one of the victims on Thursday, according to National Public Radio.The pilot of the small plane that crashed had just departed the Long Island Airport when he encountered a "heavy amount" of geese flying in the area, officials said. The pilot was able to safely land the plane, but a passenger was not. The victims were rushed to a nearby hospital where they were pronounced dead.The plane crash occurred just south of Islip, N.Y. It is the same spot where an F-5 jet crashed in 1987, killing two people.The Canadian Government was not able to identify the bird involved in the crash or the person it carried. The crash site was also not the usual spot for the type of bird that flew over the Hudson River, though a pilot said they saw them near that area in a video from his aircraft.A pilot who was taking the same flight was also seen by eyewitnesses.The incident caused a large influx of geese to the area, including one that caused the crash of the aircraft, according to investigators.Experts have previously suggested that Canadian geese become aggressive when approached by humans in a similar fashion to their American counterparts.The crash of a small plane in 2015, which killed two people, happened just miles from the crash of a Canadian passenger jet near the same area. The incident is currently being investigated by the Canadian aviation agency, according to officials.The Canadian government is not ruling out the possibility that the birds in that area were to blame for the crash, but they are not certain if it was the same bird. The crash site was also too deep to be identified, so the Canadian government is not able to find the body it is trying to ID, an aviation expert said.The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board are also investigating the incident.The Associated Press contributed to this report.

in OromiaThe Eritrean government has arrested two American embassy staff in the Amhara region who have been providing the government with intelligence about rebel groups and their movements.Eritrean security authorities arrested a 29-year-old man identified as Abuk T. in Amhara and another 22-year-old identified as O. who was found with a pistol at an unknown location, according to a statement sent to the Washington Post by Eritrea's Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Tuesday evening.They said that a team of security officers arrested the two in Amsha and Adi area in southern Ethiopia by following a tip from the American embassy.The two are being held as they are suspected of being informants for the Amhara rebels and are being interrogated and held until further instructions from the government, it said.Tensions between the Ethiopian and Eritrean governments have escalated over the past few weeks with the killing of two prominent ethnic Amhara politicians who were involved in protests against corruption.

HARARE, Zimbabwe — After four days of crippling strikes and protests over low wages, Zimbabwe's president on Saturday again warned his country's doctors against calling another day of work.HARARE, Zimbabwe — After four days of crippling strikes and protests over low wages, Zimbabwe's president on Saturday again warned his country's doctors against calling another day of work.The president's ultimatum came after a day of more than 100 doctors and nurses striking for better pay at one of the country's largest state hospitals. The doctors say their pay is too low.The president's warning followed a government decision to impose a nationwide lockdown that began on Friday to curb the spread of the coronavirus."No one is in a better position to judge your attitude in terms of being able to fight the corona crisis than the president himself," said Robert Mugabe, who heads Zimbabwe's ruling party.The government imposed the lockdown after more than 300 people attended a private funeral — one of several events that have been linked to the coronavirus — at a mosque in Harare's affluent Mvura suburb.The government ordered people attending funerals to wear masks and to be confined to their homes for 14 days following the funeral.On Saturday, more than 100 doctors and nurses who had staged strikes for better pay staged another protest at one of Zimbabwe's largest state hospitals in Harare's capital, demanding better working conditions and their salaries should be increased to $100 ($0.01 per hour), which they say is below the poverty line."The current pay levels at some state hospitals are insufficient to care for our patients," said doctor James Sanyang. "It is in this regard that we would like to express our strong displeasure in the face of the employer."

of SpainSpanish political analyst and former guerrilla who rose from poverty to become a Spanish lawmaker hopes to become the country’s next leader.In a recent speech, former leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), Ivan Marquez said he hoped to be elected the next Spanish leader.The Spanish presidential election was first held in the country in 1975 and Marquez won over one million votes to become Spain’s leader.Spain will hold another presidential election in 2023 but Marquez will again be trying to break the political impasse that has plagued the country.For years, Marquez has been at the forefront of the failed process for Colombian independence from Spain. The Spanish government has ruled out supporting Colombian independence in favor of democratic consolidation.“I will not stand by the side of the Colombian people who suffer for a future without a future, nor that of Spain which needs to stand up against violence against people who live on the streets, the poor, and suffer discrimination because of their religion, race and gender,” said Marquez, according to the BBC.Marquez will run in the second round of the Spanish parliamentary election in April 2020.

The Swiss Red Cross and the people of the Philippines have been in a delicate situation following the discovery of two bodies that were discovered in the Philippines’ southernmost province of Zamboanga on May 27.The two bodies were discovered by the local police. According to reports, the victims appeared to have been decapitated. The bodies are now being held at the Zamboanga City Police Station. The cause of death is still unknown.A man in his mid to late 30s believed to be a Swiss national, reportedly walked out of the mortuary and left the building alive on July 4.The case has prompted many questions as to whether the bodies were actually the victims of a murder-suicide or what was the motive behind the killings. The case has created tensions among residents of Zamboanga who have raised concerns about the presence of tourists in Zamboanga City and its surroundings. The Filipino president also called for a thorough investigation.The Swiss Red Cross and the people of the Philippines have been in a delicate situation following the discovery of two bodies that were discovered in the Philippines’ southernmost province of Zamboanga on May 27.

In UK CourtAn associate of a Russian arms dealer has been sentenced to five years in prison for money laundering after pleading guilty to conspiracy to commit money laundering, according to a statement released by the Ministry of Interior on December 22, 2018.Alexander Alekseevich Bogachev (39) was handed a five-year prison sentence at Woolwich Crown Court, London.The court heard that Bogachev, a Russian national, was associated with the Russian arms dealer Semyon Aleksandrovich Novikov, as well as other Russian and foreign nationals.However, Bogachev admitted his crimes on December 21, 2018 at the same court and told the court that he used to work for Novikov and would give him money.The court heard that Bogachev and Novikov would then have a lot of money in the form of property and investments for a time.He would then use the money to pay off his debts with people connected to him such as politicians.Bogachev admitted he spent most of his criminal income to acquire properties and luxury goods.He also told the court that he and Novikov had an affair, but he did not know that at the time.He has confessed to other crimes including three money laundering offences under UK Companies Act 2006.

, Report SaysTwo pilots were killed in a Marine helicopter crash in Arizona on Saturday, CBS reports.According to a report from the Arizona Republic, the plane went down in a wooded area called Okemo Mountain near the town of Sky Harbor, an airport located in the city of Chandler, some 500 miles south of Flagstaff, which is about the same distance from Phoenix as it is from London. The aircraft, which took off Saturday afternoon, crashed just after 5 p.m., according to local authorities."One pilot was deceased, one was deceased," said Arizona Department of Public Safety Chief Mark Lamb. "The helicopter's engine was also shut off at the scene.""The helicopter's tail ended up in a tree on the ground. We are doing search and rescue on site."The helicopter, named the HH-60W (a type of Chinook helicopter), is said to be a rescue or search and recovery helicopter, designed for rescue missions. It reportedly lost power around four miles from Sky Harbor, the Arizona Republic reported.According to CNN, the cause of the crash is not yet known. The helicopter is reportedly a four-seat, six-engine helicopter with a capacity for 13 passengers.The helicopter reportedly originated from the Naval Air Station in Whidbey Island, Washington.An investigation into the crash is underway, according to Arizona Republic.The helicopter's body reportedly will be transported to the Naval Air Station in Whidbey Island for further testing.A medical crew from Sky Harbor reportedly treated a pilot who was taken to the hospital for minor injuries.It isn't the first time the helicopter has crashed. The plane crashed in September 2015 in the San Francisco Bay Area, killing both pilots on board, and also injured four passengers.At the time of the crash, Chief of Marine Operations Lt.

An Iraqi security official said Tuesday that one senior insurgent was arrested in Baghdad and was being investigated for the attack on a military camp in Anbar province, where seven U.S. soldiers were killed in a raid that also injured 22.The official said the suspect, also an insurgent leader, had been under Iraqi security scrutiny for weeks and was on the radar of counterterrorism officials before the attack on Sunday.The official spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss a sensitive matter.An Associated Press reporter and a witness said that three more suspects were arrested in Baghdad on Tuesday. However, neither the AP nor witness was able to identify them or confirm whether the suspects were military police or security forces.Another Iraqi security official said the government was trying to determine how many insurgents were involved in the attack.

BELGRADE – Three international criminal cases, including the war crimes trial of former Bosnian Serb leader Slobodan Milo, should be transferred to Croatia or Serbia, prosecutors at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) said Wednesday, in a press conference held in The Hague.Speaking from the tribunal’s headquarters in The Hague, Judge Peter M. J. Johnson, ICTY Chief Prosecutor Luis B. Navarro, and other judges were present.Milo was the most senior commander in the Srebrenica massacre in July 1995 that left some 8,000 men and boys dead. In his defense, he claimed he could not have authorized the slaughter himself, and had only “received a verbal order from higher authorities,” but an appeal court judge on Wednesday rejected his defense, and convicted the war crimes chief of genocide.“

in IraqWASHINGTON -- The U.S. and Turkey will try to expand efforts to defeat the Islamic State group in Iraq's Nineveh province as a new military offensive ramps up.Turkey's military announced Sunday it has sent reinforcements into Syria along with other planes in preparation for a new offensive in Nineveh province. The United States will send warplanes, tanks, artillery pieces and other gear.The U.S. has said it has some 700 troops in Iraq to fight the militants, but officials have not disclosed the exact number or what they are doing.Defense Secretary Ash Carter said Friday that the U.S. will bolster its military presence in Syria's south as a new offensive in Mosul is launched.Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he spoke with U.S. President Barack Obama in which they agreed to work together to "turn the page" on the Islamic State.On Tuesday, Turkish drones targeted Islamic State targets in northern Iraq in response to suicide car bombings in Turkey, killing 44 people and wounding more than 160 in the capital Ankara.Turkey, which is a member of the NATO military alliance, has said it will not stand by as the Islamic State group takes advantage of the security vacuum in Iraq and Syria to attack more effectively and with impunity.Turkey launched a military incursion last week to push out Islamic militants that the Obama administration has said are seeking to establish a state ruled by Islamic law.Copyright 2015 Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.Do you have an opinion about this story?

of South Sudan ConflictThe withdrawal of Chad from the Central African Republic is a risk that South Sudan’s warring parties may use to regain control of oil-rich areas in their conflict zone, the United Nations said on Friday.Nations and countries that support South Sudan’s peace effort called for restraint after Chadian forces were withdrawn this week.Chad’s government said it decided to withdraw in response to the South Sudanese government’s move to grant an amnesty for rebels who had captured the northern town of Yomtew and some areas of the capital, Juba.A Sudanese army offensive on Tuesday night had killed at least 11 people in the South Sudanese capital of Juba, according to sources.“There are concerns in the international community over Chadian involvement in South Sudan’s conflict,” said United Nations deputy spokesman Farhan Haq, without elaborating.Chad, which has been a staunch backer of South Sudan’s secession from Sudan in 2011, has about 5,000 troops in the CAR.The Chadian defence ministry says it has “provided military logistical and combat support” to the South Sudanese army and its allied militias.Since South Sudan’s independence in 2011, warring groups in the country have been fighting to claim land they see as theirs for the benefit of ethnic groups.A peace deal signed in September, 2011, and repeated in April last year, aimed to settle the conflict which killed more than one million people.South Sudan’s government says the rebels still have the support of “armed” non-government armed groups.The rebels say the ceasefire has not yet been respected, and accuse the Chadian government of refusing to give them weapons.“

ASEAN leaders will hold a special summit to discuss the current U.S. and international sanctions against the regime in Burma, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) said Friday, in response to an announcement by U.S. President Barack Obama about Washington's intention to review sanctions on Burma. The statement says that at the end of the ASEAN summit, a joint statement will be issued on "a resolution for the situation in Burma".ASEAN chair ASEAN chair ASEAN chair Hing Cholchaing said Obama's statement will not undermine any effort in the region for the ASEAN's own members to ease the sanctions against Burma. Hing said that all parties must continue to "take the necessary steps to provide a just, democratic, free and transparent transition in Burma."Hing, who is also deputy chairman of the ASEAN parliament, said it was important to avoid being caught in an "unprecedented" situation when the United States begins to review the status of Burma's human rights record.U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton also said the U.S. government is willing to review its current economic and human rights sanctions against Burma, but that she would continue to pursue a "non-coercive" approach to the country.ASEAN leaders and other international partners, including European Union foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini, have lobbied the Obama administration to remove economic sanctions against the former Burmese junta government. The government has allowed political reform to unfold slowly in recent years but many activists have said there has been little real progress.The military junta in charge of Burma, which took power in a coup in 1962, is led by Aung San Suu Kyi, whose party, the National League for Democracy, is a leading force in the process of democratic reform.

Iran’s largest carrier Iran Air will buy 30 Boeing 737-800s from the U.S. company, Iran announced Wednesday.The purchase comes a day after Boeing (BA) announced it had signed an agreement with Iran’s largest airline to purchase 30 Boeing 737-800s from the U.S. company.The purchase is one of the biggest orders for U.S. airlines this year and marks the largest single order for the 737-800 family of planes by an airline so far.The Iranian purchase comes a day after Boeing on Wednesday announced it had signed an agreement with Iran’s largest airline to purchase 30 Boeing 737-800s, the 737-900, from the U.S. company.
