The 737-900 is Boeing’s newest version of the best-selling 737.This purchase will help Iran’s flag carrier to replace its aging Boeing 737 fleet, which the airline had in the past used to operate international flights.“

in GombeAt least two people were killed in fighting between troops from the Nigeria Army and Boko Haram insurgents at a wedding in Gombe, according to security sources.According to a Reuters report, two people died in the shooting from a Boko Haram attack on a wedding party in Gombe on Saturday.The wedding party was attacked by Boko Haram insurgents shortly before 4 a.m. on Saturday, when a group of Boko Haram militants entered a large residential complex and started firing indiscriminately, eyewitnesses told Reuters.They were not sure if civilians were targeted by the insurgents, but it is widely believed the militants attacked the wedding party because it was a gathering of Western-educated people.This would be the latest attempt to target a wedding party in the northeast of Nigeria, a decade after Boko Haram insurgents attacked a wedding party in Dapchi, the capital of Yobe state. The Boko Haram insurgency in the northeast had claimed more than 30,000 lives since 2009.

August 12, 2014Jakarta, Indonesia - On August 6, Senegal announced that Mali's Ibrahim Keita had been granted an eight-year "redress" after he accepted to be expelled from Senegal when he was 14.The announcement from the Senegalese presidency, which did not say how the youth would return to their country of origin, came just a day after Mali's head of state, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, declared Keita a national hero after the Senegalese general accepted to return to his homeland of origin.The decision not to expel Keita marked a major victory for the international community after many years of campaigning for him.

Former Malaysian prime minister Mahathir Mohammed has denounced U.S. President George W. Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair after their meeting in New York.Mahathir said in a public statement that while he has no personal hatred towards Bush and Blair, his view on the U.S. military action against Iraq and its possible repercussions was different.The 94-year-old, who has been recovering in a hospital in the southern Malaysian state of Sabah, said the U.S. and British leaders were committing crimes in the Middle East, adding, "There is no justification to attack Iraq and there should not be any justification to go to war."

NEW DELHI (AP) — In the first case confirmed in the Indian subcontinent in more than a year, the World Health Organization declared Friday that Bhutan and the Maldives had eliminated measles.It was Bhutan’s first case of measles since January 2020 when a child was infected in a tourist resort on the Himalayan kingdom’s southwestern coast.WHO said Bhutan’s vaccination rates in the last decade are among the best in the world and it is now ready to host large numbers of visitors.Bhutan, a Buddhist country of around 30 million people, has vaccinated more than 85% of its people, WHO’s head of immunization for the region, Mary Morrey, said during an online briefing Friday.The Maldives declared that it too was free of measles with fewer than 10 confirmed cases as of 2019.With more than 100 million citizens, India is India’s largest single immunization program, with more than 2 million health workers delivering more than a million shots per day.The country has more than 1.3 billion people, more than any other country.Measles is one of three major infectious diseases that can be transmitted through contact.A weakened or inactive virus is still infecting a vulnerable person, but because symptoms only manifest themselves when enough time has passed since the last case of infection, these people don’t have any apparent symptoms.Bhutan’s isolation and rapid response systems allowed it to quickly detect this case and quickly respond, Morrey said. The country did not report any new cases in 2020.“The country has performed extremely well over the last 10 years,” said Dr. Dileep Nangula, WHO’s assistant director-general for immunization.The Maldives, in the Indian Ocean, began vaccinating its people in 2017, but the number of confirmed cases has fallen sharply as a result of a “concerted national immunization campaign.”

Than Previously ThoughtThe effects of climate change can already be seen, but as the world moves to curb emissions, that list will grow. Here are five of the biggest changes in the process."This one is going to be a real challenge because it's been a little bit underestimated. But the impacts of climate change are going to get stronger and bigger and happen more quickly and sooner than previously thought."—Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University, via USA TodayThe United States is already feeling its effects of climate change. For example, hurricanes are more powerful and wetter because global warming is leading to wetter and more volatile seas."The longer the warm-air circulation over the ocean goes on, the more water is going to be evaporated into the air and the more water is going to be absorbed by the atmosphere," said Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University, via USA Today. The increased moisture makes hurricanes more intense and devastating.But there's no turning back the clock to fix climate change. The U.S. is expected to spend as much on green energy in the next two decades as the entire budget of France in the 20th century."It's kind of a no-brainer in my mind, really. We know we're going to have impacts of climate change. We know we're going to have heat waves and we know we're going to have sea level rise. So it is kind of this no-brainer, this is what we're going to do," said Steve Williams, climate analyst at the US National Weather Service. "In terms of the overall impact, I don't think anyone is particularly worried by that."The effects of climate change will be felt even more in the next 100 years, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)."This is a really tough task because this is going to be a very long term impact that's going to come, but that's part of what makes climate change such a big problem. And we don't really have that amount of time to fix it because these problems are going to last and people are going to be impacted," said Williams. "So that's the tough part.

BEIJING - Days ahead of the inauguration of Taiwan's president, Chinese military units staged massive war games across a wide swath of the island, including a base with an estimated 100,000 troops.The military drills were reported by the Taipei Times and the Taiwan Heralds.According to the Taipei Times, the drills involved 20,000 soldiers, 5,000 pieces of artillery, 600 tanks and several ships with more than 200,000 soldiers. China's army chief, who was reported to have arrived on Wednesday in Dalian to supervise the military exercises, arrived in Beijing on Thursday.Taiwan's Defense Ministry confirmed the drills were staged by the Chinese military to make sure there is a ready force on hand at the moment of Taiwan's next president taking office, Kuomintang nominee Tsai Ing-wen. The Defense Ministry said Taiwan's government would respond to any eventuality and that the military drills were to ensure the safety of Taiwan and "prevent any warlike provocation or threat."Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen is being sworn in as Taiwan's president on Monday by the U.S. President Barack Obama at the U.S. State Department.Obama was a guest of Taiwan's president and she handed him a book.Obama has not said whether the U.S. will stand beside Taiwan in any possible conflict.China has been making repeated threats to attack Taiwan in case a Taiwanese candidate becomes president.Beijing has repeatedly denounced any U.S. decision to support the island's independence, such as by offering more than $5 billion to the island's self-defense fund.

MindanaoMANILA (Reuters) - Philippine troops killed three members of a local communist rebel group in South Mindanao on Tuesday, the military said, in a new push by the government to curb a long-running insurgency.Three communist rebels, including a group leader, were killed by troops during a gunbattle near the town of Iriga in southern Mindanao, the military said.The rebels were attempting to cross a mountain pass at Iriga when they were caught by government forces, the military said."

The Philippines and its allies have vowed not to let Chinese ships enter their waters, in a bid to prevent what the Chinese calls their'revenge' for a decades-old territorial dispute in the South China Sea.U.S. President Donald Trump said in August that if China's military "moves in any kind of aggressive way, they are going to get met with tremendous force."Trump told the Philippines to prepare for an "active" military response if the situation "continues to get worse."Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has also vowed to give a robust response to any Chinese aggression.However, some Filipinos are worried that there may be too many bad reactions for a country that is currently dealing with one of its worst political crises in years.The United States and China have been at loggerheads in Asia over territorial disputes in the South China Sea and Taiwan. Both sides claim the waters and islands.The Philippines has also found China constructing artificial islands in its territorial waters.Philippines National Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana said the United States had warned the Philippines of the dire consequences of its actions."The United States made it very clear that China has made it very clear that if it encroached further in the area it will be met with a more forceful response," Lorenzana told CNN."We heard from President Trump himself that if that doesn't happen, if the Philippines moves in that direction, then they are going to have to respond in kind," he said.But Lorenzana admitted that it was difficult to know when Duterte will make a public statement about his intentions."So far, we are going on what the president wants," he said, adding that a decision might not be made until the end of the week.The Philippine navy on Friday warned it will not allow China to build facilities on the disputed South China Sea rocks."Those activities violate our country's sovereign rights as guaranteed by international law," the navy said in a statement, the first public statement by Philippine officials on the maritime conflict."

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky declared victory in the country's presidential election, a day after a second vote was ordered by the Supreme Election Commission.Zelensky took 63 percent of the vote in the first tally, and 74 percent in the second. In the initial count, an opposition candidate, Oleh Sentel, claimed he had won 57.8 percent of the vote.The second count was ordered a day after Zelensky won a majority in the parliament's first vote. The parliament is controlled by the opposition, who were demanding a second ballot.The head of the parliament's election commission said the outcome of the second vote was "in accordance with the rules of parliamentary politics."The election is to be held again on 25 April 2020, with the parliamentary election coming first.Zelensky is expected to win a second term but the results will be disputed.Zelensky says his "personal vision for the country" was met in the first round of the vote.President of Ukraine #VladimirZelensky wins by winning 63% of the popular vote in the 1st round of the presidential election.#IreneDoroshenko of the ruling party comes in a distant 2nd place with 22.3% of the vote and Yulia Tymoshenko, the leader of the opposition, came in 3rd with 17.1%.The presidential election is to be held again on 25 April 2020, with the parliamentary election coming first.President Zelensky is expected to win a second term but the results will be disputed.

The EU reported on Tuesday that it was conducting a "credible investigation" into two Georgia and Russia incursions into the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov during a five-day conflict in March 2019.Georgia is fighting for its sovereignty to be respected, which is why it is demanding a return to Tbilisi's control of the Sea of Azov during the incident. Russia has accused Tbilisi of being behind the Black Sea incidents.The EU, which has a wide network of political and military officers across Europe, said that in 2019 it had "conducted extensive and credible investigations" into five incidents involving Russia, the Black Sea Sea and the Sea of Azov.The European Union on Tuesday called for a "transparent and inclusive" investigation into a five-day Russian-Georgia conflict in March 2019.The conflict involved Russian forces backing Georgia against a pro-Moscow separatist force in Georgia's breakaway South Ossetia region.After the five-day conflict ended, the EU conducted a number of probes into what happened during the incidents.The EU's chief spokesperson, Michael Pintree, said Tuesday the EU conducted a "credible investigation" into the events as they happened in 2019.He called for "a transparent and inclusive" investigation into events after the conflict, after Russia accused the EU of political bias in the matter.He added that the EU would ask Russia to cooperate with it and cooperate with the probe, which was based on "reliable" intelligence, reports AFP.In the March 4-5 incident, the EU also found Russian troops and artillery units entering the Sea of Azov.In another incident, Russia blamed a U.S.-supplied surveillance system for allegedly giving the "green light" for a Russian attack."

Philanthropist Bill Gates sounds a warning on cuts to development aid.As part of a series of interviews with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Gates called on governments and civil societies around the world to help more people in the face of worsening poverty and inequality.Gates said the U.S. is the largest donor to the World Bank and the Gavi vaccine alliance, but that it could "do more." Gates made clear that while the U.S. has a more robust economy, it also has a higher rate of poverty and an increase in inequality. And he made clear that if the U.S. were not the largest donor to such organizations, other countries would be.Gates said the U.S. government, which he described as a "brutally honest" one, had a lot of room to help other countries. But at the same time, the U.S. has more poverty, a higher rate of inequality, and a larger population than many other countries."In my opinion, this is not an easy problem to solve, but I don’t think there is one single solution that would satisfy all parties," he said."I’ve never heard a single person in Washington say we have to cut development aid," he said. "I think a lot of people who are saying that are saying that because they don’t want to say that they don’t have the money."Gates cited his own experience of trying to help get his son and wife out of poverty in Africa. He said that his efforts were often rewarded with praise by Washington. But that only made the problem worse.Gates cited other factors that contributed to the poverty and inequality he sees in his current work."All these problems can be traced back to the fact that most people are concentrated in about a few places, and that those countries have relatively high poverty," he said.

ieaiaaThe father and daughter of a dead New Hampshire man are offering conflicting reasons about the man’s death. Police are also now saying that his death may have been non-consensual.The body of 44-year-old Mark Allen was found on August 1, the same day that his daughter was reportedly found safe at a park in Massachusetts.Allen’s son, Mark Ridenour, found the body of his father and his daughter that day and alerted New Hampshire state police, who contacted the state medical examiner’s office.While Ridenour said his father appeared to be dead, the autopsy did not show that he was dead — it showed that the man had died of blunt force trauma, most likely in the head. The autopsy also found that no criminal evidence supported the Ridenour’s claim.Now that New Hampshire law enforcement is involved, the case has been put on hold while the state medical examiner’s office finishes its investigation and Ridenour’s father and daughter provide a statement to investigators.In an affidavit filed yesterday, Ridenour’s father described how his daughter woke him at 6:30am on August 1, and they drove up to the park in Massachusetts.“

As part of the US-Israel relationship, the Pentagon has made at least $2.2 billion available to the Israel Defense Forces for the continued operation in Gaza, which entered a second ceasefire late Sunday, a two-year extension of its first Gaza truce, signed in December 2018 between Israel and Hamas.The Biden administration is "putting pressure on Israel," according to former officials of the Obama administration.The US Congress has historically refused to provide Israel with the billions of dollars it needs.

President Donald Trump sued the Manhattan district attorney Monday over an subpoena seeking his personal financial records, an action that could allow Democrats to question him in an impeachment trial.Trump’s lawyers said that he would challenge the subpoena issued by District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. and the city’s Comptroller Scott Stringer as well as challenge their jurisdiction over the case.“This case will also allow the president to assert his legal right to remain silent,” Trump’s lawyers said in a statement.The New York Times has reported that Trump directed his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, to attack Vance over the probe. It said that Vance asked for the financial records to “better understand” how Trump invested, and the president’s lawyers called that request a “misuse of process” that they would oppose.“The president’s efforts to obstruct this investigation should be resisted,” the lawyers added. “His efforts to interfere with this investigation are unprecedented and, if left unchecked, threaten to undermine the rule of law.”Trump is embroiled in a legal battle with two women who say he sexually assaulted them. A federal appeals court has refused to overrule a judge’s order that compelled Trump to give his tax returns to prosecutors.Trump, a Republican, has argued that the tax returns have nothing to do with the two women, one of whom says she had an affair with Trump years before the alleged assault.There is no question that Trump’s personal financial dealings are a central topic of the investigation.

Brazilian farmers and rural ranchers are mobilizing to protest government moves to privatize parts of the Brazilian agricultural belt—some of the most productive land on the planet. As the land gets smaller, farmers and ranchers increasingly rely on truckers to transport their products to market, thus driving up food prices throughout the nation. A recent truck strike in the Amazon state of Roraima, the biggest producer of soybeans in Brazil, sparked fears that the agrarian reform—a keystone of President Michel Temer's 2017 election campaign—could spiral out of control. But the union representing truckers has rejected the call for an indefinite strike by workers. The truck drivers are demanding an increase in compensation, as well as increased payments to workers on the country's food network. For them, it is just as much a question of survival as it is an election issue. They are also fighting corruption accusations lodged against the federal government and Temer.For truckers, it is a question of survival as much as it is an election issue.In the face of this threat, President Temer has begun reallocating cash to compensate the truck drivers—a controversial move that infuriates farmers and ranchers. The federal government, meanwhile, has pledged billions in tax incentives aimed at strengthening the local farming industry, such as grants, tax relief and credit for the payment of workers on the food network. The government also plans to increase the number of farmers and food producers on the agricultural labor force, particularly in Roraima state. These measures have largely proven effective to strengthen the agriculture sector, which in recent years has begun to generate a steady revenue stream that will allow the farmers to meet the needs of consumers.

BANGKOK — Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha survived a no-confidence motion.This afternoon the lower house of parliament approved the no-confidence motion presented by the Democrat Party led by Pramon Chartmasri, an independent member of parliament in the lower house who is also an associate justice of Thailand's Constitutional Court.The motion was presented to make sure Prayut's government was able to hold onto power ahead of a referendum due in the second half of next year.The no-confidence motion was rejected in two earlier votes held in the lower house.Pramon Chartmasri said that the vote had not been easy."It is true that there are people who want to support the government and support it. The same people want to oppose it," Pramon said."There are some people who did not believe that this government could last. And there are other people who support this government and want to support it," he said."This motion to save the government was more difficult than the previous two motions to save the government."The vote was supported by 13 out of the 16 parties, including the ruling pro-army Future Forward Party and the opposition pro-democracy party the United Front.

BEIRUT — Former leaders and security chiefs from Lebanon’s long-serving security forces have been questioned by a court investigating the assassination of ex-premier and former President Rafic Hariri.At least five former chiefs and generals, including two senior officers in the feared Al-Mohamad police special units known as the “Murders’ Corps” and five others of different rank were questioned in a courtroom on Saturday in the capital Beirut by the high-profile Court of Investigation.Hariri was killed on Nov. 4 in a bomb planted outside his luxury family home in the city. It was the second assassination in Lebanon in six years, prompting a political and diplomatic showdown between the country’s top security leaders.Those under formal investigation are senior leaders of the country’s elite security forces. The rest are likely to receive summonses in the coming days, according to judicial officials.

: VideosA Syrian boy sits inside a shelter in Turkey's Aksehir camp. (Photo: AP)Turkey's Aksehir refugee camp hosts many people displaced by Syria's civil war, from all walks of life.Most camp residents are women and children from the war's shattered cities.The video below was shot by a Syrian boy inside the refugee camp.Aksehir, in northwestern Syria, is one of the largest refugee camps in the world, with nearly 80,000 people at its disposal. Aksehir was established in 1949.Some 20,000 Syrians fled the country after an attack on two villages by pro-Damascus forces. Many fled to the camp in mid-January, with many more arriving afterward.This child was a Syrian boy who escaped from the violence in his country. Aksehir was established in 1949.

Wednesday, State Department SaysU.S. State Department officials said Wednesday that a joint Sudanese-South Sudanese summit meeting has been scheduled for 3:30 p.m. in Khartoum, but no further details were immediately available.The talks are expected to cover issues such as bilateral cooperation between the two countries, the status of the region's troops, and the upcoming election of new leaders in both nations. The two presidents, both of whom have served as vice presidents, have come under fire from some of the country's military leaders for what they consider inadequate action in pursuing peace agreements with the transitional government in South Sudan and rebels in northern Sudan.State Department officials, who have been in Khartoum in recent days to brief top South Sudanese officials and to facilitate an official South Sudan-South Sudanese summit meeting, said they were still finalizing details and had no additional details to share. They said that no time frame for the meeting had been determined.The State Department officials said that the three-hour meeting would be a first for the United States in the two countries since the creation of South Sudan in July 2011.The officials said that they could not provide further information on the possible purpose of the meeting because that would jeopardize the security of U.S. officials.They said that the leaders of Sudan and South Sudan would meet at a time of greater stability and stability for the region, the three-day Sudan-South Sudan summit meeting being held in Khartoum this week. They said the leaders of South Sudan, President Salva Kiir, President Kiir's successor and former Vice President Riek Machar, and U.S. Special Representative to South Sudan John Sipher were all expected to be present at the summit.The State Department officials said that they wanted the meeting to be a signal to both President Kiir's government and the military leaders that the United States was prepared to do business with them and to help them resolve differences that had been exacerbated by the conflict in South Sudan.They said that they would seek a peaceful solution to the violence in South Sudan -- one of the continent's poorest nations -- and to promote economic development, stability and prosperity in Africa through development partnerships and support for the African Union's peacekeeping mission in Darfur.

Despite the continued presence of U.S. forces in Afghanistan, military planners are still concerned about the growing number of militants attempting to attack U.S. and coalition forces there. In an exclusive interview, Gen. Stanley McChrystal, the general officer commanding U.S. and NATO forces in Afghanistan, discusses the increased possibility of attacks against American or coalition troops.With growing political pressure on President Barack Obama, there are signs that McChrystal may be pressured to move away from the Afghan strategy that has been put in place for the past five years by U.S. President George W. Bush.McChrystal acknowledges that, even with new troop numbers coming into Afghanistan, the pace of attacks against U.S. and coalition forces there has not slowed down."You do realize that every day that goes by with us operating against more and more of this enemy — more of the enemy's ability to operate, to launch attacks — means that that is more of an ever-present threat for the next year or two or three," McChrystal said. "So the military remains concerned about the threat, and they continue to assess what the best strategy of combat remains against a higher degree of threats."In January 2010, McChrystal and Defense Secretary Robert Gates released the report "Sustainability: The United States' Strategy to End the Afghan War," which outlined a strategy for ending the nearly 18-year long war in Afghanistan.Some have criticized McChrystal and the Obama administration for "releasing a report that doesn't reflect the reality on the ground in Afghanistan," and some experts have called for withdrawal from Afghanistan. Some have also questioned the rationale for keeping troops in Afghanistan, which includes preventing a resurgence of al Qaeda.McChrystal insists that there is a "real risk" from what he calls the "new generation" of the Taliban. But he and the other senior commanders have also cautioned against a wholesale withdrawal."We're looking at the broader security threat of the Taliban to do our part [in preventing a resurgence of al Qaeda] by reducing that threat in the larger regional context and giving the political leadership that has to contend with that issue," he said. "We're not going to be the sole provider of that threat. We're going to play that role in a larger regional context of the threat."

On Tuesday, the United States Supreme Court said that when police use GPS tracking technology, they must get a warrant to view the data.Lawyers had challenged a decision from U.S. Magistrate Judge David Nye in Washington, D.C., who had issued a warrant in September 2017 to access a cellphone's location history to determine if it had been used at a crime scene.Police had asked to access the data for a separate, unrelated case, to determine whether the suspect had violated a restraining order issued in January 2017 against the suspect’s boyfriend.The technology used to track cellphones’ location is widely available and inexpensive, and the case was seen as a bellwether for the Fourth Amendment, the right to be searched and held harmless from unreasonable search and seizure.In the majority opinion, Justice Samuel Alito wrote, “As a general matter, warrantless access to the location data of mobile phones does not violate the Fourth Amendment.”He was joined by Justices Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh, and Clarence Thomas.

- ReportNASA's InSight lander has touched down on the red planet, with the first-ever US probe to touch down on another world.The lander and rover were initially meant to land on the Mars' Elysium Planitia, which is a slightly more advanced version of the planet's Mars-One lander, the AP reports.

SurgeWith a record number of COVID-19 cases in the United States topping 23 million, hospitals in many states are struggling to prepare for an onslaught of patients. The World Health Organization recently warned of a “dark winter” as hospitals prepare to handle record patient numbers.In Michigan, a record number of people are being hospitalized with COVID-19 in the state.“The people who are dying today are the people who will live in the worst possible fashion in the future,” said Dr. David F. Zucker, the medical director for the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.The rise in cases has forced many hospitals to switch from normal COVID-19 treatments to using intensive care units (ICUs) to manage non-COVID patients, placing them in the same rooms as coronavirus patients.On Wednesday, the number of patients in Michigan’s ICUs surpassed 2,000, a number not seen since mid-April.“We have never seen the type of demand on ICUs we are seeing now,” said William J. Hines, the president of Johns Hopkins University, where COVID-19 cases have surpassed 8 million.In some places, medical staff and staff members have had to work longer and longer hours, to keep up with the demand.“We are seeing things that we have never seen before,” said Dr. Howard S. Graff, the medical director at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.Graff also pointed out that some ICUs have had to send patients home to care for their sick relatives because they couldn’t manage their COVID-19 patients in their own homes.This week, one hospital director in Michigan had to tell patients in their final days that they were losing their beds.“We have to make some hard decisions to try to make sure that we don't reach a point where our resources are no longer available,” said Thomas E. Ricks, the president and CEO of Beaumont Hospital, in Michigan.In New Jersey, hospital directors have warned that it will be an “unprecedented” problem if they are faced with an increase of COVID-19 cases.In New York, where COVID-19 has claimed some 28,000 lives, New Jersey Gov.

The airline said its management was shocked by the death of Miss.Katerina Tchernishchaya, who was the daughter of Russian billionaire Mikhail Tchernishchaya, a billionaire with more than $9 billion in fortune.Tchernishchaya, who was also a top executive in the former Soviet state of Tajikistan, had become one of Russia's leading businesswomen and was the daughter-in-law of Tchernishchaya's late uncle, Mikhail Tchernishchaya.The two had a close business relationship as Tchernishchaya was also her mother-in-law, and they were very close.Katerina Tchernishchaya, the daughter of Tchernishchaya's late uncle Mikhail Tchernishchaya, is one of Russia's richest women who died in a plane crash in Germany while on vacation.The TIA spokeswoman said that the aircraft had developed a problem after landing and was reported to the air traffic control and emergency services.The plane landed at 11:48 a.m. in Freienbach, Bavaria in eastern Germany and had left the German city of Munich at noon.

January 4, 2006 - Israel’s Knesset has given its approval to the final version of the East Jerusalem Plan, a long-term project of Israeli government designed to expand Jewish population in the Palestinian territory in order to “balance” the demographic and demographic trends.The plan was originally designed by former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and the then head of Israel’s Home Front Command, David Cohen. The approved plan is in the shape of a five-year master plan of expanding Jewish presence in the area.Barak originally announced that the plan would be implemented at the beginning of 2005, but the plan was finally approved by Ehud Olmert, now Israel’s Prime Minister. In order to build the plan, the population growth of the Israeli population should increase, the Jewish population should increase and Israel should increase the size of the area which already houses the Palestinians of East Jerusalem to 200,000.At a time when the Palestinian population is in decline due to an Israeli blockade, the Israeli government decided to create its own solution in order to “balance” the demographic and demographic trends. The Israeli government would have the aim to increase the Jewish population to 60,000 by 2014. In order to achieve this goal, the Israeli government will have to create approximately 700,000 housing units in East Jerusalem. This housing shall be split in 200,000 units on either side of the separation barrier in order to create the Israeli towns that would be located at the boundaries of the towns where the Jewish and Israeli population will meet together in one large city.The Jewish population of East Jerusalem would include the Jewish towns in the East Jerusalem Area, the settlements, and the villages which already exist on the Palestinian side.The Palestinian population would be concentrated within the existing settlements.

The number of dead in a fierce battle in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, has risen to 81, and that is only a partial list.The group, Somaliland National Committee of Civil Rights and Justice (SNCRJ), said it has received reports that the battle was between government forces and anti-government fighters.It also said that many people were injured and thousands of property and weapons destroyed."The reports from our partners say that the fighting began after a meeting between two elders in the city center and led by security forces, in a bid to neutralize the rebel fighters," said the statement released on Sunday."As a result of the fighting, most parts of the city center, including parts of the business district, the main port of Mogadishu and its airport, and many public buildings have been razed and thousands of houses burnt."The statement added that several ambulances and humanitarian aid vehicles were damaged.It added that there are also reports that the attack involved several explosions in Mogadishu and the surrounding suburbs.It urged the international community to support the Somali government in its effort to restore law and order in the city.(

On 10 October, the exit poll was announced for Lithuania's Parliamentary election. The exit poll shows that the ruling Democratic Rally (D&R) party will lose to the Lithuanian Democratic Party for the first time in over half a century.The Lithuanian Democratic Party will not win its fourth consecutive term in power after it lost the October 9 poll to the Lithuanian Democratic Union (LDA) with 45.54% of the vote. The party will however still take the majority in the 80-member parliament as D&R did not enter into an electoral coalition with other parties, and will be able to work with the Social Democratic Centre (SSD).The D&R party currently holds 48 seats, a three-point increase for the last poll.

The Islamic State (ISIL) in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) claimed responsibility for a car bombing near the headquarters of a rebel group in Syria’s northern city of Raqqa, killing 10 civilians and wounding 20 more, according to a statement released Thursday.The bombing occurred early Thursday in the Syrian city where the jihadist group is based. The al-Rai hospital in Raqqa confirmed that 10 people were killed in the explosion.The blast occurred near a house belonging to an al-Jabha military faction, al-Hayyat al-Islam (Ahrar al-Sham). The wounded have been taken to a nearby medical center, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.A Syrian source told Sputnik that another 10 people were injured. The source added that the blast targeted an ambulance of Ahrar al-Sham’s military wing, as well as a vehicle of another rebel group, Nusra Front.The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported 10 people killed in the bombing.The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) claimed responsibility for a car bombing near the headquarters of a rebel group in Syria’s northern city of Raqqa, killing 10 civilians and wounding 20 more, according to a statement released Thursday.The bombing occurred early Thursday in the Syrian city where the jihadist group is based.

The United States should try a range of diplomatic tactics, including military, to ensure that Kim Jong Un doesn’t possess the capability to use nuclear weapons against its neighbours, a group of analysts said today.“Kim Jong Un has clearly seen that the United States doesn’t have any credible ability to deter him from using nuclear weapons and he has turned to the long game in order to achieve his goals,” says William Frey of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.This is not good news for North Korea, because now US forces will be in South Korea in case it decides to attack South Korea with nukes.That is all, no weapons tests or anything. He is going to be very worried about that. I don’t know how that will go. But I think that the US military is probably going to want to be very close to the base if Kim Jong Un tries something. That would probably be the end of the strategy of getting to Pyongyang.I think that the US would prefer to see an economic relationship, and that would also be something that we do have.The analyst thinks that any US military action against North Korea would probably lead to another attack by North Korea.And he warns that Kim Jong Un would have no choice but to invade South Korea if the US does anything to him.So I think that the US strategy will be to get as close as they can to South Korea. That will probably be to the port in Pyeongchang. I don’t know how that will go but that is part of the plan.But I think that the US and other nations should probably look at a range of diplomatic techniques, including military ones, in order to make sure that Kim Jong Un’s regime doesn’t have the capacity to launch a nuclear strike against its neighbours.North Korea may not be using nuclear weapons against US forces in the near future, but the chances of its regime going nuclear are rising every day.This could lead to Kim Jong Un trying to build nuclear weapons that have a greater effect than conventional weapons.

KABUL—At least five people were killed by a suicide bomber Saturday near an aid delivery facility for the people of Afghanistan.The bombing took place as trucks of food and water for the people of Afghanistan were being transferred into the town of Wola.The town is located roughly 10 kilometers (6 miles) east of the capital, Kabul.Mohibullah Shiekh, spokesman for the Ministry of Public Health, said five bodies were recovered and 14 people injured in the blast.The spokesman also said a number of wounded people were taken to the hospital in the town."They are in critical condition," the spokesman said, adding that some people have died.The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.

Oklahoma’s oldest and first public astronaut ever, William Haynes, has recently published an article in the Kansas City Star titled "Photographing a Corn Maze in the Air: William Haynes, an Oldest and First American."William Haynes’ story dates back to 1884. It was his first year in the U.S. Navy in the Panama Canal Zone. That year, he witnessed the first moon landing and captured the first photos ever taken of Earth from orbit.William Haynes is the only American astronaut to have had a photo and a film of the moon. It's also the only photo or film ever of the Earth from space.In 2010, Haynes became the first American to walk on the Moon in the Apollo 11 Command Module.

Photo courtesy of the Danish Rugby Football Union (DTU).Johan Olsen, the new Denmark national rugby team coach who won both the gold and bronze medals as captain of the national team in the 2002 World Cup held in South Africa, is not expected to do it again, according to the head of the Danish Rugby Football Union.“It is difficult to say whether this is an example for Denmark,” said sports chief Morten Sande, during the press conference on Tuesday evening.The former Danes captain and coach John Olsen won the world cup in South Africa after playing the opening matches for Denmark. Olsen has been appointed to replace former Danish rugby coach Jorgen Ostergaard for the upcoming World Cup 2003 that will be held in England. Olsen has stated that he will not be allowed to select his own players for the games.Former footballers Michael Hansen and Peder Zagadien have been appointed to help Olsen with his plans to win the World Cup title.The next World Cup in England will be held from 26th July to 9th August 2003.

Lawyers from the New Jersey based environmental group Earth Justice have lost the U.S. Supreme Court’s latest effort to block a lawsuit brought by youth activists over the failure to curb climate change.Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch were unavailable.The case comes just before Thanksgiving, which is often a big time for fundraising by the legal community. So it was a huge win for the plaintiffs, Earth Justice, which has been successful in other cases where they sued powerful groups to get more funding.One of the lawyers for the group, Michael Gerrard, told me in an email from Washington that he was “pleased that the Supreme Court declined to review this case”.It is hard to say what the group’s next steps will be, because that sort of thing rarely goes well for environmental causes: it is very hard to get enough people behind a case and it is also very hard to succeed in winning the U.S. Supreme Court.The New Jersey based group is already gearing up for its next Supreme Court fight. It has filed a second case, which will seek to block a coal-fired power plant from operating in New Jersey that is also seeking to go through the state’s judicial process.In case you missed it, last April, a group of about 75 youths filed a suit in the U.S.

Tunisia’s former prime minister, Jomaa Ben-Médine, announced the start of the “non-ideological” political party on Monday, his first post in the country.Jomaa Ben-Médine, who resigned in 2013 due to a sex scandal, announced the launch of the “non-ideological” political party at the beginning of his second visit to the country on Monday.#Tunisia's former prime minister launches political party amid resignation scandal. This week, Ben-Médine returned to #Tunisia to mark the start of the "non-ideological" political party pic.twitter.com/xHhFbzTj4R — Al Jazeera English (@AJEnglish) June 25, 2018The former prime minister’s resignation in 2013 sparked a crisis after a sex scandal broke out, leading to his ouster from power.Following the scandal, Ben-Médine and his family, including his wife and three daughters, were evicted from their luxurious presidential villa.Ben-Médine lost his political position and was sentenced to three years in prison in May 2015 before being pardoned by the Tunisian government a month later.During the scandal, Ben-Médine denied the accusations of corruption and defamation that his family faced, but the party nevertheless filed a lawsuit against him in the high court.He appealed and the same court upheld the decision to close the case, paving the way for Ben-Médine to run again for office.Following a new constitution in 2014, Tunisians elected former president Kais Saied as the new prime minister of the country.

A Libyan general has seized two major terminals in the country’s oil industry, two key sources said Monday. The move is expected to increase the risk of armed conflict in the country’s energy sector, the sources said.The two terminals, located at the town of Derna, are the country’s major refineries.The military commander was reportedly a senior official of the internationally recognized government, a move that could increase risks of confrontation between the two parties.The militia leader was reportedly acting with the government’s tacit support, two of the sources said. It was not clear whether the military commander was seeking to take over the government, but he was making the move with the government’s approval, the sources said.A government spokesperson had no immediate comment on Monday’s development.Libyan forces, led by a renegade general, have been trying to unseat the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), which operates in the country’s oil regions.

A new Gallup poll shows a sharp decline in Americans' confidence in their country, from a strong 90 percent saying the United States had an attractive future to a more modest 81 percent now.The "trust in U.S. leadership" index is the lowest since December 2001.One key finding: that the level of optimism about a U.S. outcome—from a negative 27 percent to a positive 19 percent—dissipates among young Americans. The "generation gap" between those under 30 and those over 65 has gotten wider during that period, according to Gallup.An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll also finds a sharp drop in young Americans' confidence in the U.S.Overall confidence level dropped from 94 percent to 72 percent.

IndustryA recent development in India’s fashion industry includes technology as one of the major trends shaping the future of fashion design. The advancement of technology is making it easier to create fashion wear and products which have already been incorporated in some of the leading brands. For instance, in 2015, Apple introduced the Apple Watch which is a popular technology based wear. The watch is equipped with different sensors which enable the users to monitor a lot of data about themselves. For example, the watch can send a message when the user is running out of time. There are apps available which are installed on the Apple Watch which can make the user stay connected with them anytime anywhere. Similarly, the smart watch can detect the temperature and can be adjusted according to the body’s needs. The watch can control the music and make call so that the user gets more information than can be communicated with human voice. These devices make fashion wear available in an even more sophisticated manner.The trend of using technology in fashion is also increasing as more consumers prefer to shop online. A study in 2016 reveals that almost 80% of all people today use computers to buy fashion and they also use technology to access their personal information. These devices enable the customers to stay connected with the brands they like.For instance, the Amazon app for android users, is a very popular application which enables the user to buy anything from Amazon.com even though not a huge number of people use this application for the purpose.The latest fashion trends also incorporate technology in their designs. In some cases, there is no visible change in the design but in some cases, there are changes happening. For example, an electronic wrist band such as an Apple Watch can be used to provide information about the wearer. Similar technology can be incorporated in the latest designs.With technology becoming more mainstream in fashion, consumers are not only consuming the latest trends but also buying them.In 2016, there were more than 70 million wearable devices that were sold. Some of these wearables even run software which controls the device. These electronic devices are becoming more and more popular.For instance, in 2013, a new Apple Watch was launched in order to provide an even more advanced level of functionality. This watch is able to collect data from the wearer and also be used to make calls and send text messages.The future of fashion is certainly going to be a lot of interesting developments involving technology and design.

to Quarter-FinalsSwitzerland's Sairaat Khan, right, holds the trophy after she defeated New Zealand's Rachael Haynes during the Women's Rugby World Cup Pool E match between New Zealand and New Zealand at International Stadium in Wellington, Sunday, Oct. 6, 2019. (AP Photo/Mark Baker)WELLINGTON, New Zealand (AP) — Defending champion Switzerland and her opponent in the women's World Cup quarterfinals, New Zealand, each scored four tries in a hard-fought 40-32 victory Sunday in a hard-fought Pool E match.The victory clinched Switzerland a spot in the World Cup semifinals.The two-time champions will face Japan, who lost to hosts England in a 29-28 semifinal victory.New Zealand coach Steve Hansen has a spotless record in the World Cup, having won all seven matches, including three in last year's semifinals. The Kiwis have reached the quarterfinals for six consecutive tournaments.It was a good day for the women's game as Australia clinched a 20-16 victory over New Zealand to advance and wrap up the Group B title with a 6-1 record.The only blemish for the Australians was when a penalty was given when a player appeared to push another player in the head but no penalties were given in a 30-minute delay.For the second straight day, Australia coach Dave Rennie chose to bench a key player for their quarterfinal in a bid to be at his best for the semifinal against the U.S.

The security situation across the northeast of Nigeria's Cameroon, where Boko Haram insurgency is active, has become more precarious. Recently, 130 schools were closed, due to the security situation.On Tuesday November 6, the Cameroon Information Ministry in Yaounde received a report on the security situation in some regions of the northeastern part of Cameroon, namely in Yaounde, Bassarac and Bambari.According to the security alert, Boko Haram has been fighting for decades against Fulani pastoralists living in that part of the country. Since 2011, Boko Haram has been battling with the Nigerian army in northern Nigeria. At the moment, the security situation in the northeast of Nigeria has become more perilous.In recent months, insecurity has worsened because Boko Haram members have started firing on government troops. At the moment, the security situation in the northeast of Nigeria is not yet stable.Cameroon government has set up the national security council with security chiefs from all regions of Cameroon.On October 29, 2016, the minister of defense, security and foreign affairs, Pauline Ndubamanya, in charge of security and external affairs in the country, said that President Paul Biya is deeply concerned about the security situation.According to him, Cameroon had always suffered from insecurity and there was no serious effort to combat it until recently. He called on the government and security chiefs in the country to increase their efforts to combat insecurity.Cameroon's external affairs minister also said that the government will increase its funding to the government of Cameroon, and this would boost its contribution in fighting Boko Haram.On October 26, the Cameroon army killed at least 27 Boko Haram fighters in two attacks in Bassarac and a neighbouring town. The security situation in Nigeria, where Boko Haram is active, has become more alarming.A similar report was released by the Nigerian Security and Intelligence Services on October 20. Nigeria, where Boko Haram fighters operate, has long suffered from insecurity.The Boko Haram movement is considered a terrorist organization in Nigeria and neighboring countries.

- ReportBERLIN — The initial investigation of the Germanwings pilot who caused the crash of a passenger plane into the Alps last year shows that a senior executive at Germany’s biggest airline has been accused of recklessly violating flight safety laws, the newspaper Die Zeit reported on Sunday.According to the report, Christian Smoltz, the chief of the management board of Swiss-based airline Swiss International Airlines, was aware of an inspection on one of the plane’s engines in 2009, but failed to implement it.The report cited several unnamed sources familiar with the matter, including an aviation source who also served as a witness in the initial inquiry in April.“This is an area in which Swiss International was responsible for several years,” the source said.In addition to the first official inquiry, another investigation into the crash, launched this past fall, revealed numerous shortcomings in Germanwings’ maintenance and control process.In 2015, Swiss International started a program in which employees were required to be informed on all Germanwings maintenance operations, according to the newspaper. But the airline did not submit maintenance reports to the regulatory agency until February 2016.

About 10,000 people have been evacuated from the town of Nogales by the United States Forest Service after flames from the area's last wildfire broke out in a nearby national forest, authorities said Wednesday."As of right now, the risk level for the fire is high," Nogales police Chief Joe Escalante said at a news conference.The fire is burning on both sides of the Colorado River, and was also threatening the town of Farmington, a city of some 10,000 people that lies below the river about 50 miles southeast of Salt Lake City, officials said.Two communities that are on the other side of the river have taken up emergency shelter in Phoenix.Nogales Police said there were no confirmed injuries or injuries to any firefighters or civilians.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — A former Khmer Rouge officer was arraigned on Tuesday at a central Cambodian court for questioning about alleged crimes during the Vietnam War.A phalanx of men in green jumpsuits, khaki shirts and dark trousers escorted Lt. Gen. Phong Sokol.He was arrested in Cambodia on Monday by Cambodian troops who arrived on military aircraft.Khmer Rouge member and former commander of the notorious Vietnam War-era army, the International Military Tribunal for the Former Khmer Rouge, (ITF) for the crimes committed at the hands of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, Phong Sokol. He was in the country of his own accord, without being asked to or seeking asylum.On June 28, a court announced that Phong Sokol will be transferred to Cambodia for questioning. He had been living in Cambodia for a decade.Phong Sokol led the Khmer Rouge regime from 1975-1979 and is a wanted fugitive under the International Military Tribunal for the Former Khmer Rouge and other countries.The tribunal ruled that the Khmer Rouge were responsible for more than 1 million deaths, mainly of civilians, during the Vietnam War.In a statement by his office, Phong Sokol said that while "he did not have any intention to incriminate the Cambodian government," he has nevertheless been asked to come for questioning due to an intelligence report regarding an event that happened years ago.Phong Sokol stated that his defense lawyer has already been called as a witness."

African leaders will gather in Ethiopia next week for a high-level gathering to explore how to boost intra-African trade, reduce trade barriers and increase intra-African trade.Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, South African President Jacob Zuma and President of the Senegalese National Assembly Ahmed Ousmanou, who are hosting the summit, will participate in a high-level forum on the sidelines of the G-7 Summit in Canada next week.The U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres has described Africa as "the most promising and promising continent of the 21st century." Guterres will attend the summit meeting and deliver a keynote speech."This is an opportunity to work together to accelerate and increase the level of intra-Africa trade, to reduce trade barriers, increase intra-African trade," Abe said.Abe said that as the largest landlocked African country, Ethiopia has a great opportunity to make use of the vast economic opportunities that the continent presents."The African Union and the International Monetary Fund will be here," he said."A free trade zone and an open market place within the region, to bring together all of the continent, as one market," Abe said.The United States has been working with other African countries to develop the continental trade framework and make it a success story. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson are attending the summit in Canada.Tillerson said that the summit will also feature an initiative to help Africa implement the U.S.-Africa free trade agreement (FTA) that Trump announced in April."The Africa Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) has been a real breakthrough," Tillerson said."Our goal was to help African countries accelerate the implementation of the agreement," he said."And we had to get the African Union, the IMF and all these other organizations working for that."Tillerson said the summit would also include discussions on security issues including "the threat of terrorism" from Islamic State, illegal migration and how to develop a regional response.The African Union has previously said the summit will deal with infrastructure and education as its top two priorities."I think that they will address the infrastructure," Abe said."They will definitely address education.

on June 30thThe U.S. Supreme Court announced yesterday that Justice Anthony Kennedy will step down, effective June 30th.Kennedy is the swing justice on the court, and it will be up to a group of appointees to act as a fifth vote in determining which cases the court will take up.Kennedy, 77 years old, has been on the court for 36 years.Kennedy has been considered one of the most influential court justices. But he is not the only one who is retiring. One Democrat will be stepping down to make way for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s replacement.But Kennedy’s exit leaves the court shorthanded for most of the term.Follow Kevin on TwitterSend breaking news and top stories to your inbox:TweetEmailLikeEmailWhat are the top stories that you'd like to see reviewed?Share with meWhat are the top stories that you'd like to see reviewed?Share with meWhat are the top stories that you'd like to see reviewed?

The U.N. Security Council has unanimously approved a resolution on Iraq, passed in the wake of last week’s attacks. The resolution calls for a military pullback by Tuesday from Iraq, but it does not call for the withdrawal of all foreign troops.The resolution has many advantages for both the Bush administration and for Bush and Cheney. For one, it will give the Bush administration more time to push its war plans in the Security Council, a move that might be opposed by the United States, China, or Russia, though both of those countries are bound by the same rules. For two, Bush and Cheney can now say that the Security Council has endorsed a military plan. The resolution also will give Bush and Cheney plausible deniability for the lack of action against Saddam Hussein, something that both administrations have attempted to use as an argument for action.The final version of the resolution, however, makes several concessions to the Iraqi government. The Security Council asks that Iraq produce, in five months, sufficient quantities of fuel for the country’s two largest cities and provide information on the arms it has stockpiled. It also asks that the Iraqi government not use the “fierce fighting and heavy fighting” of the war against the U.S.-led coalition. The Iraqi government can then appeal to the Security Council if it feels that it should have that right.The resolution also asks that U.N. troops in the country do not face any civilian casualties while carrying out the mission, that the UN military presence in Iraq be cut by half by December 1, and that U.N. military personnel operating within the country to protect civilian populations should remain until the end of the year.The resolution also asks the United States to provide all necessary logistics to the Iraqi government.

Islamabad, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 18th Dec, 2019 ) :Pakistan has strongly rejected claims made by Afghanistan that it is aiding the Taliban militants behind a series of deadly attacks that have struck the Islamic republic ahead of legislative and presidential elections.Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani claimed Thursday that "several hundred" Taliban fighters were responsible for the November 8 attacks which killed 28 civilians and wounded 79 others, and that the perpetrators were from Pakistani and Afghan military personnel.His comments prompted a furious denunciation from Pakistan, which has long fought Taliban violence."We reject such baseless claims as we categorically reject any group, including the Taliban, inimical to the security of Afghanistan," Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said in a statement, adding that the Pakistani military and security forces "never engage in acts of terrorism".Qureshi said Afghanistan's President Ghani's claims were "not only unfounded but also dangerous"."The recent attacks in Afghanistan are a clear message that the international community is not safe and secure," he added.Pakistan has long blamed Taliban attacks on Afghanistan, often including deadly suicide bombings, on Pakistani troops and intelligence.Pakistan and Afghanistan agreed in 2016 to cut all ties and relations over the violence in the region, but have continued to be involved in military operations against the Taliban.Since September 2014, Afghan security forces have killed at least 17 Pakistani troops during operations against Taliban strongholds, according to Pakistani security sources.

Lebanon's startup community is not just a great place to set up shop, but also the perfect place to make real impact on society.It's also a place where the business-minded people with good ideas can find support, and the ones with no ideas can get support from the community.Startups have a long-standing and close relationship with startups and with the community.In fact, the most successful entrepreneurs here have often come from the community. Most notable has been the case of the Lebanese startup of Echos Digital Media.Lebanese startups have been part of social initiatives in different ways, starting with a local nonprofit that helped the poor get mobile phones for them, then with a charitable charity that provides water.While there is obviously an element of profit-making involved in some of the ideas, the idea of starting a business in a country like Lebanon involves far more than just making a quick buck.It is not surprising that some of the first and most successful entrepreneurs here come from the communities that they are trying to impact.For the new arrivals to Lebanon, and all of those already here, it can be challenging to navigate the startup world. There are many great resources to get an idea started, but the hard part is getting it funded. There are also a lot of things that you might want to know that you don’t realize you need or can’t afford to do yourself or the startup doesn’t need to pay you to do it.Lebanon, like many countries around the globe is suffering a financial crisis and is trying to fix it one piece of the puzzle at a time. In many of the developing countries, the government’s only interest is in ensuring that the companies and industries are creating the jobs that they can’t hire locally.However, in some cases, the companies have to spend more money than they would like, or the companies have to invest even more money to try to create jobs, not just the people that are employed in their businesses.

A child soldier is interviewed by a doctor as he is released by the transitional government authorities from Aruwak military camp near Aruwak in Unity state, southern Sudan, Tuesday, March 31, 2020. More than 300 child soldiers were released Tuesday after surrendering to the transitional authorities in South Sudan. (AP Photo)More than 300 child soldiers were released Tuesday after surrendering to the transitional authorities in South Sudan, a senior government official said.“It is true that some of those were child soldiers recruited as the government was going into a security operation,” the official told The Associated Press. The official spoke on condition of anonymity as he was not authorized to speak with the media.The U.N. has estimated more than 8,000 child soldiers in South Sudan, where a civil war broke out between government forces and rebels in 2011. The new South Sudanese government began an offensive against the rebels in December.South Sudan’s child soldiers also include an estimated 300 fighters recruited through kidnapping, an official said.Some of the abducted fighters were members of rival ethnic groups such as the Acholi and Nuer, who now make up about 2% of the 4.1 million South Sudan population, according to the U.N. Child Soldiers Watch.A child soldier in South Sudan poses for a photograph, in Aruwak, Unity State, southern Sudan, Tuesday, March 31, 2020. More than 300 child soldiers were released Tuesday after surrendering to the transitional authorities in South Sudan. (AP Photo)South Sudan’s child soldiers also include an estimated 300 fighters recruited through kidnapping, an official said. South Sudan’s child soldiers also include an estimated 300 fighters recruited through kidnapping, an official said.South Sudan’s child soldiers also include an estimated 300 fighters recruited through kidnapping, an official said.The U.N. Child Soldiers Watch has expressed concern about the abductions and the subsequent abductions of child soldiers and has called on security forces to help track down abductees, rescue and release them.

ATHENS, Greece — Thousands of Greeks joined the streets in grief as a huge fire raged out of control. They mourned the victims, joined in the march to a government office and burned a sign on the wall: "Stop the fire."The town of Mati was the worst hit, with the governor reporting that over 150 homes had been destroyed, and that many more may be lost.The cause of the fire is unknown and authorities don't think it will be under control until at least Friday. But hundreds of fires have broke out across northern Greece for years, and the authorities expect to get an accurate picture of the cause in two or three days.

By The Associated PressTHE HAGUE - Police have arrested a man suspected of setting a fire in the Dutch embassy in Turkey in October, one of the first cases in the European Union in which authorities detained a suspect from abroad.Dutch police spokesman David Kriek said late Wednesday that officers took a suspect into custody in the northern port city of Rotterdam where a search turned up several fire bombs.Kriek said the police have launched an inquiry into why the suspect might have started the blaze that destroyed the embassy.The embassy building was evacuated following the fire that broke out October 14.The man arrested is not accused of any crime and his lawyer said on Wednesday he would defend him.Police spokesman Bart De Wege said an official Dutch inquiry into the case would also be launched, although he said there was no indication so far the culprit had any links to the Netherlands.The Netherlands has had a reputation in recent years for trying to deport non-Europeans to their homelands, including Turks convicted of crimes.

With the spread of the bird flu in southern and southeast Asia, the authorities have been scrambling to fight the spread of the virus that causes the illness.In Thailand, the number of cases has risen to about 250 and the authorities have started to vaccinate the people. In the Philippines, the flu death toll has doubled with deaths recorded in every province.Experts warn against over-battling the virus since it is still not known to be fully understood, causing a lot of fear among the public.Meanwhile, other countries across the region have stepped up their efforts to fight the virus.Meanwhile, South Korea is seeing a sharp rise in infections from the new strain of bird flu. On Wednesday, health authorities in the country confirmed that the flu has spread to the rest of the country.The country's Health Ministry said that the new strain of the virus has already reached at least 35 people in a city of more than 500,000.Health officials say that so far they have only found the virus in samples from one man.South Korean officials warn the public to maintain preventive measures, including maintaining an extra distance from people who show symptoms of bird flu, avoid close contact with wild birds and disinfect all contact surfaces after visiting wild bird areas.Meanwhile, Thailand's Agriculture Ministry announced it would deploy 150 million baht to support the country's farms affected by the outbreak of bird flu.However, the move did not go over well with some, as residents were already experiencing the effects of the disease.

TURNOVERThe European Union has agreed on a deal with Turkey to send back migrants to the Turkish mainland, the 27-nation bloc said in a statement.The bloc said Turkey has agreed to take in about 1,000 migrants, while the rest will be sent back to the Mediterranean.The EU also said the deal will include "structural reforms" that will help the bloc's troubled eastern member states.The bloc is deeply divided over how to deal with the growing influx of migrants. It is trying to find a balance between the needs of the EU's poorest members, who are bearing the brunt of the burden, and those of larger, wealthier member states, particularly France.The deal also includes some form of visa-free travel to Turkey for EU citizens, as Turkey is still a NATO member, and will be able to apply for EU membership.It will also help the bloc's poorest member nations, including Greece.The bloc's governments still need to sign off on the agreement.Turkey hosts some 3.6 million migrants and refugees from Syria, Afghanistan, the Middle East and Africa, of whom a third come from the camps on the border with Greece. Turkey says some 3,000 people are now living in its camps on the border.EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan signed the deal at a summit in Brussels, with EU leaders saying they wanted to avoid sending the migrants to Greece.Erdogan said the migrants should go back to their countries instead of being transferred to the EU.The deal needs approval from the Council of EU governments, the group that sets the bloc's foreign policy agenda, and the EU parliament, the European Parliament.

The Russian state's provocations along the Eastern Front have increased to Cold War levels, according to a new report by the Moscow Carnegie Endowment.In the first six months of 2016, the Kremlin escalated tensions in Ukraine, Georgia, and the Caucasus, by conducting military operations in Belarus, Crimea, and the Donbas region, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace report said.The research also said that the Russian use of mercenaries in the Donbas and Crimea region has resulted in the civilian deaths of civilians by Russian forces.In March, a military conflict broke out in Donbas with Russian-allied separatists who are fighting for the independence of Donbas.

Protesters(Last Updated On: August 22, 2019)New Delhi, Aug 22: Indian Parliament was once again disrupted by the protesters as many of them have gathered in their thousands to protest against the amendments tabled in the Lok Sabha which has been tabled in the Rajya Sabha too.The ongoing protests in India against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act have been going on for over three months now.

00:30:00The Federal Emergency Management Agency is helping jurisdictions prepare for Hurricane Isabel, which is expected to hit U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and the northern Bahamas early next week."We've already been working with some of these jurisdictions," said Bush, as he visited Puerto Rico in preparation for Hurricane Isabel. "So we've been able to have some of our folks down there. We're going to be working with some of our folks down here. And we'll probably be helping a couple of them out. But just in order to get them started and prepared, we are sending our folks down."Bush is touring the island as he works to bring aid to the victims after Tropical Storm Irma slammed the island last week and killed at least one person. Bush also toured the storm-ravaged Florida Panhandle. He has visited four of the most affected areas, including the Panhandle's devastated Panama City.The latest estimate is that Hurricane Isabel will make landfall between the Virgin Islands and the northern Bahamas on Tuesday morning and could be the most powerful hurricane to ever hit the Caribbean in recent memory.Officials are preparing for the worst and are working to get supplies to hurricane victims as fast as possible.

Venezuela’s chief prosecutor is seeking legal action against top Supreme Court justices for their actions during the government’s brutal crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.Venezuela’s Chief Prosecutor Tarek William Saab on Friday filed a complaint with the Supreme Court’s disciplinary commission accusing several of its members of usurpation of power, defamation, disobedience to their oath, the constitution and treason.“As Prosecutor of the Venezuela’s Law and order of the Judiciary I demand and declare from this platform and in the presence of these justices that you must immediately suspend and suspend until the conclusion of this prosecution the operation carried out on August 29 and 30, 2020,” Saab said in a video posted on Facebook that included footage of protests that erupted in the country in response to the decision to cut the monthly salary of teachers to a fraction of the cost.Venezuela’s constitutional court has not ruled on Saab’s request but his action could be the start of a more dramatic conflict within the government that could prove crucial in determining the future of the oil-rich nation.The action comes as opposition members of congress have rejected a motion by a parliamentary delegation to try and impeach five opposition-friendly Supreme Court justices, most of whom had overseen harsh anti-protest laws. Some said their action was retaliation for the decision of the top court to reduce the salary of teachers by half during one of the biggest waves of anti-government protests in the country’s history.The protesters chanted the term “el hombre al que esta perdido,” or “the man who fell asleep” in reference to the five Supreme Court justices.“I want you to understand this,” Venezuelan lawyer Edgar Zambrano said in video filmed by the prosecutor. “This is not a joke. You and your fellow magistrates were complicit in the killing of two people, in the face of international support. And you are asking that the president not be given the opportunity to investigate these crimes and hold the perpetrators accountable?”

President Barack Obama on Thursday said he would “treat Hamas,” meaning Israel, with the same patience that Palestinians have been granted during a 25-year conflict.Obama also said he wanted to give his advisers time to “see exactly what was happening in the region before making any decisions on anything.”He also said he did not have a “moral obligation” to take a stand on Israel or Hamas before he assumed office.Obama said his goal was to bring calm to the region and “for peace to occur in the long-term.”But he also said he was committed to helping his advisers “to see how we can support peace in the region and in a way that helps bring about long-term peace in the region.”Obama’s remarks in Washington came the same day that Israel launched “Operation Protective Edge,” the biggest offensive so far in Gaza.Obama said he was concerned about the possibility that the military could have been used without a specific mission, but he was also convinced of the value of the operation, which included nearly 8,000 troops.“If it wasn’t for the incredible bravery of some of these people, I doubt that we would have had this chance to come and go after those weapons,” Obama said.Israeli Defense Minister Ehud Barak said that the military operation was justified.“This operation was necessary for the security of the region,” Barak said. “It wasn’t directed at anyone.”Defense officials and senior Israeli officials have said that Israel’s aim in the operation was to prevent Hamas from establishing and expanding its rockets and artillery capabilities.Israeli leaders have indicated that they wanted the operation to be limited, to a few dozen soldiers, but military officials say Hamas can fire up to 2,000 rockets from the Gaza Strip daily, and their rockets could hit targets in southern Israel.Barak said the military action was intended to eliminate the infrastructure Hamas had used to prepare for potential rocket attacks.Barak also said that Israel would send troops to the Palestinian territories in order to prevent a repeat of the June 2008 offensive known as “Blue Sky.”

and Town Councils on SundayMalawi people will go for polls on Sunday to elect the president, lawmakers, local councilors and town councilors. The vote will be on the basis of single member districts. The polls were originally scheduled for last week but were delayed over fears of COVID-19 spread.The election is set to run until May 22, 2021.The presidential vote will be held in 24 constituencies – Malawi’s Parliament – out of 27 constituencies; all of the 36 provincial council seats and all of the 36 district councillors.In Parliament, there will be only four seats for the presidential vote, two for each of the 12 constituencies, and one for each of the 18 districts, making a total of 24 for the vote. There will be five of each in the Senate, of which two will come from the four parliamentary constituencies; Malawi’s two vice-presidents.The number of constituency seats is therefore 23. In the Senate, there will be 24 members – four for each constituency, two for each of the six parliamentary districts, and one for the four senators.There are three positions of each of the 36 district councilors, four of each from two of the 13 districts. The number of constituency seats therefore is 36.In each of the six parliamentary districts, each councillor will have one vote – one from each of the five districts. Of the six districts, Malawi will elect four parliamentary seats, and the remaining four districts will elect four district councillors for each of the six districts.
